article_tags: [Climate change, Florida, Climate change, Environment, US weather]
description: In this extract from Rising, Elizabeth Rush explains ‘sunny day flooding’ – when high tides can cause low lying streets to fill with water
og_fields.og:description: In this extract from Rising, Elizabeth Rush explains ‘sunny day flooding’ – when high tides can cause low lying streets to fill with water
og_fields.og:title: Meet America's new climate normal: towns that flood when it isn't raining
text:
I spend the afternoon in Shorecrest, a neighborhood a couple of miles north of downtown Miami. To get there I leave the beach behind and drive past Arky’s Live Bait & Tackle, Deal and Discounts II, Rafiul Food Store, Royal Budget Inn, Family Dollar and Goodwill. As I continue north, the buildings all lose their mirrored glass and their extra floors, until most are single story and made from stucco.
It isn’t raining when I arrive in Shorecrest, and there isn’t a storm offshore; the day is as clear and as blue as the filigree on a porcelain plate. But the streets are still full of water. I watch as a woman wades ankle deep across Tenth Avenue. She has gathered her long russet-colored skirt in her right hand, and in her left she holds a pair of Jesus sandals. When she reaches the bus stop, she sits and puts her shoes on. 
“We get flooded with just about every high tide,” the woman tells me. “And if the moon is big it’s worse.”
All along the east coast, from Portland, Maine, to Key West, “sunny day flooding” is increasingly frequent. Many places in the Sunshine State are so low lying that high tide – when coupled with something as innocuous as a full moon – can cause the streets to brim with water. Sometimes the tide simply rises above the seawalls and starts to spill into the roadways; in other cases it enters the neighborhood through the storm-water infrastructure belowground. The very pipes designed to reduce flooding by ushering rain out instead give salt water a chance to work its way in.
In Shorecrest I spend a minute watching the bay burble up through the street grate and on to Northeast Little River Drive before whipping out my camera and snapping half a dozen photos. Just then a man walks up behind me, peers down, and says: “I’ve seen fish come swimming out.”
“No, you haven’t!”
“I have,” he says, pushing his sunglasses up. “I’ve been here 20 years. When I first moved we used to flood once a year, maybe twice. Now it’s constant.” His name is Robert Cisneros. He grew up in Cuba and moved to Florida in 1962, dropping the final “o” in Roberto. He thought the name change might help his fledgling boat repair company succeed.
Robert points to his house and his yard, which are catty-corner from the drain we stand by, and says: “I used to have a nice garden here, and now you see how it is. The water comes in and sits. And everything dies because of the salt. It’s not rain that floods this place. It’s the ocean. I just bought some stones to put here to try to keep the water out. But other than that, what can I do?”
I ask if the city is helping the neighborhood come up with short-term solutions. Robert gets upset. “I think they need to raise the street. They need to install pumps. But those kinds of things only happen on the beach. They’re not giving any of us here any relief.”
Like Miami Beach, Shorecrest was built atop a former wetland. On the strip, where billions of dollars in real estate investment are at risk, the government is using a mixture of property taxes and municipal bonds to invest in formal sea level rise adaptation. But in Shorecrest, Hialeah, and Sweetwater – low to middle-income neighborhoods where the majority of residents are people of color – residents are expected to remove their shoes and wade through the water.
Robert shakes his head in disbelief. “I wanted to leave this house to my kids, but soon it’s going to be worthless,” he says. On his stoop sit two pairs of rubber boots, ready for the flood that is already here.
****
The following Friday I return to the Cox Science Center at the University of Miami. In the parking lot I sit in my rental car as the past decade of storms goes thundering through my mind. I see large waves pulsing into New Orleans’ Lower Ninth Ward. Roiling chocolate milk ripping homes off their foundations in Oakwood Beach, Staten Island. Family cottages in the Rockaways in New York turned into aquariums during Sandy.
I remember walking through the Lower Ninth five years after Katrina. The storm’s eerie language was still clearly legible on one house’s laminate siding: a painted X, its upper quadrant marked to show one dead in the attic. On the next building, a lighter, more haunting X showed two dead on the ground level. Someone had attempted to scrub it away, to remove the memory of the killing wind, the way the water deformed the foundation and window frames, the lives it took.
I start descending the poorly lit staircase to the basement of Cox, where the geology department is – fittingly – located.
The atmosphere down in the office of the department’s chair Harold Wanless, or “Hal”, is more in keeping with my mood. Perhaps it’s also in keeping with Hal, whose decades of research on sea level rise have earned him a reputation for cataclysmic prediction. He is wearing the same taupe suit as the week before. The skin below his eyes is the color of charcoal, and the rest of his face sags, too. Still he manages a smile. Up close it is hard to imagine that the media has nicknamed this good-natured septuagenarian “Dr Doom”.
Hal pushes some of his scattered papers aside so I can set up my recording device. I have my question, just one, prepared: “What single event woke you up to the reality of sea level rise?”
“You know, 20 years ago I never thought I would end up seeing the rise because everything, all the projections at that time, really didn’t ramp up until well into the 21st century. But then I started going out to Cape Sable.” Cape Sable is the southernmost part of the mainland; it reaches into the Florida Bay like a swollen hook. “Out there the beaches were disappearing, mangroves were moving in, tiny channels turned into huge rivers in a matter of years. Even the roseate spoonbills started abandoning their nesting grounds. I had never, in my life of studying the geology of the coast of Florida, seen anything like it. That is when I knew in my gut that the early predictions were wrong and that sea level rise was unfolding a lot faster than any of us ever imagined.”
“What comes next?” I ask.
“We have to start relocating the things we value,” he says. “Like the Smithsonian Institution, which is sited on top of an old marsh. We have to make seed banks, a global archive for the future, and we have to move our power plants, in order to maintain a functioning society. We have to start lining the trash dumps that line our shores, we have to start preparing for inundation. Remember, the last time carbon dioxide levels were the same as they are today, the ocean was one hundred feet higher.”
The last time carbon dioxide levels were this high was during the Pliocene epoch, 2.6 to 5.3 million years ago, when megatoothed sharks prowled the oceans. The last time carbon dioxide levels were this high, the tectonic plates beneath India and Asia collided, forming the Himalayas. The last time carbon dioxide levels were this high, California’s Sierra Nevada rose up and tilted its granite face west. The Alps folded and thrust their splintered rock toward the sky. The last time carbon dioxide levels were this high, armadillos migrated north across a newly formed land bridge between today’s North and South America. Dogs headed in the opposite direction. But no one can remember these things, because humans didn’t exist.
I leave Hal’s office and drive back across the bay. That night the moon is big and full, making the ocean weightier. The salt water unspools in the streets and continues drowning, by degrees, the low-lying land that lines our shore. Soon, I think, if Hal is right, all of this will be underwater, not just temporarily, but for good.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. For The Guardian, reporting on the environment is a  priority.  We give climate, nature and pollution stories the prominence they deserve, stories which often go unreported by others in the mainstream media. At this critical time for humanity and our planet, we are determined to inform readers about threats, consequences and solutions based on scientific facts, not political prejudice or business interests. But we need your support to grow our coverage, to travel to the remote frontlines of change and to cover vital conferences that affect us all.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

[{u'author': u'LocknessMunster', u'text': u'Starling populations are crashing as well.Down 60% in Denmark in the last 40 years for example.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530504869000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17443130', u'in_reply_to': u'117647709', u'id': u'117687848', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Johnk860', u'text': u'You have a weakness, and it is not the inability to see incremental change. It is the inability to state that, uncatagorically, there are too many people on the planet and, therefore, no room for other species (unless they are food for people). Decades ago, the ZPG movement fought for understanding, while the religious claimed that any attempt to stem population was against god's law. e.g. The Roman Catholic Church maintains that, not only is abortion banned, but all forms of birth control, including that which merely prevents insemination (such as condoms), are immoral. Without some pushback on these dictums, we humans will, therefore, overwhelm the planet and doom our species to collapse, if not extinction. Wake the hell up and address the cause and not the symptoms of the disease or the results of the plague that we are.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530501945000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17263877', u'id': u'117687568', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TheBorderGuard', u'text': u'Western toads (Anaxyrus boreas) once were commonplace in southern California suburbs, coming out at dusk to feed upon invertebrates in lawns and flower beds.
Alas, no more. The pools where they once bred are gone, and also, I fear, many of the species which supported them. It seems but a minor thing, but I miss these creatures, and I do not think they shall ever return.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530498291000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13487653', u'id': u'117687207', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'heartfulembrace', u'text': u'how much less serious disease would there be if such hostile and dangerous practice were halted..?And I do mean among the lesser percentage yet much much larger number of the general population.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530495901000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14257940', u'in_reply_to': u'117686847', u'id': u'117686948', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'heartfulembrace', u'text': u'where did your survival instinct go? Down the toilet?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530495166000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14257940', u'in_reply_to': u'117686325', u'id': u'117686855', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'heartfulembrace', u'text': u'funigicides, insecticides, and herbicides.... what could possibly go wrong?
oh yeah the farmers get all the most serious diseases at twice the rate of the rest of the population. Plus generational damage and injury.
how much less serious disease would there be if such hostile and dangerous practice were halted..?
not forgetting twice the amount of food than is needed is produced globally for those that say the change necessary would cause starvation.... duh!
I've also noticed it is usually the farmer's employees that are sent out to do the spraying.Is it not time the workers were forced to wear protective clothing or would that make the dangers too obvious, too embarrassing, or too bloody damning?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530495084000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the change necessary', u'effect': u'starvation'}], u'author_id': u'14257940', u'id': u'117686847', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CompleteIdiot', u'text': u'Well Australia is a very big place, but here in suburban Brisbane insect snd bird numbers and diversity have decreased. Its difficult not to attribute this to the expansion of cities and the loss of gardens as people build ever bigger houses.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530494054000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1516706', u'in_reply_to': u'117629132', u'id': u'117686737', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'hollieollo', u'text': u'The one material fact missing from an excellent article is over population. It is the elephant in the room for liberal politicians, because it impinges on the very idea of controlling population.However, in his masterpiece television programme "How many people can live on planet Earth?", Sir David Attenborough no less, presents us with some pretty indigestible facts about over population. Briefly, our population is gaining size exponentially. The revised projection for 2050 is 9.7bn. That is another 2.7 billion in around 40 years. If current trends continue, we are looking at 11.2bn in 2100.We already need the equivalent of one-and-a-half Earths just to stand still. Finite resources are running out. Therre is the same amount of water now as there was 3.5bn years ago, and the same percentage of fresh water at 3%. We are already overusing that and starting to tap into underwater reserves. There are the first signs of war in places like Africa where rivers are being diverted upstream, vast lakes are shrinking to nothing and the population in those very same areas are the same one predicted to grow the most.Of the 2.2bn increase by 2050, more than half of that will be in Africa. Where are they all going to go? They are already beyond salvation with droughts, famines and disease. Trillions of Dollars has been pumped into that continent and still they do nothing for themselves. Now we are seeing the beginnings of a mass migration movement from Africa into Europe, which will displace the indigenous populations. The word White Genocide is now being used in reference to unsustainable and illegal migration from Africa. Is it any wonder therefore, that the first victims will be wildlife? That will be the first to go, followed by natural forest, woodland and just about any greenery. Climate change will exacerbate all these things until humans are stood shoulder to shoulder in a world stripped of all resources.That is the legacy we leave our children and grandchildren unless we act now.Migration must be stopped or we will all go down with the sinking ship.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530465747000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it impinges on the very idea of controlling population', u'effect': u'it is the elephant in the room for liberal politicians'}], u'author_id': u'3235371', u'id': u'117677231', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'unprogressive', u'text': u'Thanos was right.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530492194000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4676839', u'id': u'117686543', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'They like thistles and knapweed.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530464769000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117672077', u'id': u'117676433', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bobkolker', u'text': u'Every last change be it small or great occurs according to natural physical laws. The natural world cannot disappear because the only world we can be in the the "natural world", i.e. the world operating according to the laws of physics.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530490619000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10040668', u'id': u'117686325', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bobkolker', u'text': u'The world has changed constantly for the last 4.25 billion years. The notion that there is an ideal state of the world to which we can return and stay is simply nonsense. It is in our interest not to introduce pollutants or toxic substance into our environment, but the idea that we can "save the world" is simply absurd. Compared to nature anything humans are capable of doing is feeble. No matter what we do or don't do the world will change and some of the changes will be harmful or hazardous to humans.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530490461000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10040668', u'id': u'117686308', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'I do agree over the gardens. I have planted to ensure that there are flowers of some kind all year round - you can see the first insects out as early as January on a warm day. I confine doubles and frillies to pots near the house where I can enjoy them, while the borders are more traditional cottage garden plants. Up behind the trees there is an area where I allow weeds to flourish out of sight, and I excuse the lack of tidiness behind the shed as giving places for small mammals and insects to hibernate.
But I have a fair-sized garden; so many houses have such tiny gardens now, and they need to be both playgrounds for children and somewhere for the adults to enjoy. You can do the same thing on a small scale, but you need to plan very carefully, and not everyone has the time or interest to do so, they work hard all day and just want somewhere to sit down that isn't too much work, and I don't think it's fair to blame them for that.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530464582000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117655899', u'id': u'117676280', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'hand wringing is not enough- we should have the bravery and nobility to be the activists of change.If we just sit back, fatalistic and resigned we remain consumers- this is not a time to demand others act.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530490086000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'id': u'117686247', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Flashbleu', u'text': u'Yes. When he grows up he'll just ignore the mess around him and sneer at anyone who doesn't. Like you.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530487411000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16769876', u'in_reply_to': u'117684508', u'id': u'117685782', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Annalisa Alvrus', u'text': u'Because maybe we learned what not to do?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530463985000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100518723', u'in_reply_to': u'117661864', u'id': u'117675688', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mizzentop', u'text': u'I agree its sad but no more sad than cars running over animals on our roads. Deer, badgers, hedgehogs, rabbits, foxes, frogs etc. 
I understand mowing machines and I actually doubt this story as the practicality of a mower leaving the body intact and just taking off the legs of a young deer is highly unlikely. If its true, it would be a very unlucky oneoff. Plenty of car owners killing these animals every day though.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530485372000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18043724', u'in_reply_to': u'117675298', u'id': u'117685262', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'The birthrate of the whole world needs to drop. People are living longer, they therefore need to work longer. Bringing more from abroad into a small island is ridiculous - they too grow old. Plus more and more jobs are becoming automated - what do we do with all the extras when their jobs go?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530463898000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117671884', u'id': u'117675615', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mizzentop', u'text': u'I find these articles frustrating as the central themes are important but the anecdotal “evidence” is often just wrong.
The piece about the fields that used to be cut for hay not being cut for silage was presumably intended for us to conclude that cutting a field for hay was fine but silage somehow isn’t. Does George realise that the EXACT SAME machines mow grass for hay AND silage?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530484970000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18043724', u'id': u'117685147', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ronan Fitzsimons', u'text': u'I've noticed exactly the same in Belfast, south County Down and Donegal', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530484960000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13833586', u'in_reply_to': u'117605987', u'id': u'117685144', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Annalisa Alvrus', u'text': u'No we can’t legally cull humans although stopping population growth would be one of the biggest steps humanity could take toward a sustainable future. Unfortunately we don’t seem to be doing anything along those lines.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530463893000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100518723', u'in_reply_to': u'117675093', u'id': u'117675610', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'I haven't gone after greenfly in years; I do admit to spraying soapy water at blackfly on the beans if they get too bad, but this year they've been OK.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530463746000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117671855', u'id': u'117675461', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Flashbleu', u'text': u'Oh yeah, it's all the fault of those pesky cats with their pesticides and plastic grass.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530483112000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16769876', u'in_reply_to': u'117678661', u'id': u'117684629', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'The story of the deer is heartbreaking, and unnecessary. Maybe the field was one of these enormous prairie-like ones in East Anglia, where the machines get up to quite a speed. A couple of days ago our neighbour cut one of his hayfields - with a large triangle of uncut grass in the middle. It contained a young roe deer fawn - unusual, they normally leave them in the margins by the woods and you need to take a lot of care dog-walking. But it was a reasonable sized field with part of it a steep hillside, surrounded by hedges, the tractor driver did well to notice it but he can't go as fast as all that so he does have time to look.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530463575000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'id': u'117675298', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'pinkhorse1', u'text': u'Another sixth form essay.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530482810000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14455062', u'id': u'117684508', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'anon-113452a530181', u'text': u'Populations of butterflies, hoverflies, flies, bees of all species and beetles in my North London back garden are down but not out. I'm on my second wildlife garden here and it has nurtured generations of sparrows, coaltits, blackbirds, chaffinches, robins and wrens. The earthworm population is healthy. But numbers of swifts have noticeably plummeted, and the only place locally where insect life seems to thrive is Lea Valley park - and that only seasonally. 
Ultimately, globalised capitalism with its emphasis on growth and resource overuse is hugely to blame. So are the vast agrochemical conglomerates such as Monstanto, which have stupefied farmers into complying with their noxious products. These are driving much of the damage. However, given that we humans number over 7 billion and don't all work in finance or pesticides manufacture, behaviour change on a gargantuan scale could help.
As consumers and as stewards, we need both to consume wisely and to rewild and wild our habitats locally. Support local farming initiatives that are sustainable. Grow your own - think of it as Victory Gardens for biodiversity. Create a wildlife garden full of nectar- and pollen-rich plants and guerrilla garden in your neighbourhood. Pay particular attention to soils to ensure that they're biologically viable - the soil microbiome is of the essence. Collect rainwater. 
Yes, numbers of species are down, but to some degree 'if you build it, they will come'. So build.
Yeats's Lapis Lazuli is a remarkable poem about tragedy, destruction, annihilation and what it takes to revivify and rebuild. He uses the word 'gay' in its old sense, of buoyancy and lightheartedness, hope and understanding of cycles:
BQSTART
On their own feet they came, or on shipboard, Camel-back, horse-back, ass-back, mule-back, Old civilisations put to the sword. Then they and their wisdom went to rack: ... All things fall and are built again And those that build them again are gay.
BQEND
Our civilisation is teetering under the onslaught of halfwits like May and Trump, and toxic models of prosperity. Economies link directly to resource use and to the health of our environments. We must (I feel) start bottom-up. We must ensure our children value natural riches and don't spend all their time thumbing screens. It is not impossible. But time for meaningful change is tight.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530480068000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1759344', u'id': u'117683174', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Annalisa Alvrus', u'text': u'Human activity is NOT natural! It is cultural. That is the problem - we have removed ourselves from the natural order and we have become immensely destructive because of just that! You don’t get up out of a nest in a tree every morning and climb down and go look for some fruit or grubs to eat. You sit in a house and cook food you bought at a store. This is not natural! And our immense reproductive rates are not natural either. Human population growth needs to be curbed ASAP as a first step toward restoring balance to the planet.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530463513000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'just that', u'effect': u'we have become immensely destructive'}], u'author_id': u'100518723', u'in_reply_to': u'117674022', u'id': u'117675255', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paddly', u'text': u'Intensive farming and insecticide use do not on their own explain the massive reduction in insect numbers. My guess is that fluctuation in weather patterns are upsetting rhythms genetically hardwired into the DNA of insects. That this disrupts their often complex and precise life cycles of many insect species. Unlike humans many insect species are simply not adaptable to climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530478888000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16680187', u'id': u'117682551', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'My mother bought Silent Spring when it came out in, I think, 64, and it made a great impression on me as a young teenager. I have been interested ever since, though I get very frustrated by some "green" initiatives which are long on emotion but short on science. I also come from a farming background, and have lived all my life in the country except when at uni.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530463221000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117674532', u'id': u'117675175', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gewgaw', u'text': u'What we'll probably get is another series of Love Island.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530478848000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2412198', u'in_reply_to': u'117621601', u'id': u'117682523', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'“Climate change is making it harder to revive damaged land”https://www.hcn.org/issues/50.13/climate-change-climate-change-is-making-it-harder-to-revive-damaged-landscapes', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530463210000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'117675170', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gillian Smittony', u'text': u'BQSTART
"Gallup found 14% of the world's adults -- which translates to nearly 710 million people -- saying they would like to move to another country if they had the opportunity. [...]  One in five potential migrants (21%) -- or about 147 million adults worldwide -- name the U.S. as their desired future residence. Germany, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Australia and Saudi Arabia appeal to at least 25 million adults each. These same countries have been top desired destinations for the past 10 years. In fact, roughly 20 countries attract more than two-thirds of all potential migrants worldwide."
BQEND

https://news.gallup.com/poll/211883/number-potential-migrants-worldwide-tops-700-million.aspx
These numbers might be on the low side.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530478833000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17985786', u'in_reply_to': u'117680127', u'id': u'117682513', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'No. Don't you know why they wash chickens in chlorine? It makes it safe to eat even if it is diseased or has gone off. The US has no laws to protect chickens - federal law does not define them as animals. Chicken farmers can treat them as badly as they wish, keep them in filthy conditions, and still produce food which can be legally sold. One of the reasons Americans have lower life expectancies than Europeans is that much of their food is of poor nutritional value. Of course, you can get excellent food in the US, you can find food produced with all attention to animal welfare, some states have animal welfare laws as good as anywhere on Earth. But we can already import those things if we wish. The things we cannot import are produced by the torture of animals, and by much lower paid workers than here, and are proven to be lacking in nutrients. 
You completely miss the point. Many people cannot afford to buy the best even now - but even the cheapest food is produced by people paid at least minimum wages, on farms where the welfare is supposed to be high - and even in the worse cases cannot be as bad as in parts of the US, as they would be legally unable to sell their products as they cannot disguise their deficiencies with chlorine - and has a higher nutrient density than the majority of US products. You are saying that their health is unimportant as long as those who can afford it can eat better food - which, in a country with a national health service, is a false economy as well as downright elitist.
Also, you may be quite happy to think of animals in other countries being tortured, their workers underpaid - it's their culture, after all. No, all cultures are not equal, and those which see no problem in harming animals or their fellow humans need to be encouraged to improve. Sadly, that includes the US. We may not be able to force improvement on anyone, but we should not allow anything into the UK which undermines the standards that we held long before we joined the EEC, as it was, and have improved since. We need to be looking to improve standards further, not to indulge in a race to the bottom, nor to use unnecessary energy moving anything round the planet which could be produced locally. 
Economically, we also need to decrease imports and increase exports. The world market in food will dry up, and within the lifetimes of most now alive. If we are not producing enough of what we can grow to feed our already excessive population, and their probably even more excessive children, what happens to them when we run out of international credit? You are unaware of the concept of food security?
Yes, it is up to us, and we do not need to add to the mistakes we see around us. You are trying to save one small area while the rest of the world becomes devastated - it cannot work. The globe is an interconnected system. We need to use the best possible practice to feed our people while keeping enough connected corridors of wildish areas for our other species to survive. This will require active management, and may well need the culling of some species to manageable numbers to make room for all. Legally, that will not include humans. Yet.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530463013000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117673399', u'id': u'117675093', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gubulgaria', u'text': u'Meat and dairy production takes up over 4/5 of farmland, but produces less than 1/5 of our calorific intake.
If we all went vegan, we could give three quarters of our farmland back to nature and still produce enough food for everyone.
However much we devastated the remaining quarter with chemical intensive farming (and modern vegans are far more fussy about the chemicals, and far less fussy about the perfect appearance, than average consumers), the overall impact on biodiversity would be hugely positive.
If eating meat is the most fun you have in your life, and you think it's worth the destruction, fair enough, but there's no controversy over whether it is destructive or not. Don't we have some common ground? I would like to see free trade in agriculture post Brexit which would mean folk would be free to buy British (whose standards were the best in the world) or opt for cheaper fare - USA chlorinated chickens. So long as it was all honestly labelled and consumers were informed there'd be cheaper food for those on a budget, and a wonderful countryside that you paint a picture of, paid for by those who were willing to pay for (niche) UK food products - produced to the highest standards. 
We would have a countryside geared to maximising your singing skylarks with a sideline in producing food. The countryside would also be a far nicer place and fair bit of new housing with good broadband could lead to a new countryside dwelling white collar worker class who maybe only go into the office one day a week. 
A countryside producing less food, but earning a living by being beautiful and attracting people from the cities - who'd pay higher property taxes than the locals.
And as for foreigners with different (lower) food standards - so long as consumers know - then what's the problem? Foreign standards are up to foreigners. 
Brexit will change things. It's up to us how they change now.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530457550000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the countryside', u'effect': u'a new countryside dwelling white collar worker class who maybe only go into the office one day a week'}], u'author_id': u'4313548', u'in_reply_to': u'117672488', u'id': u'117673399', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Aseoria', u'text': u'There used to be tons of roadkill around here. Just admiring its strength and tenacity.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530470003000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1026641', u'in_reply_to': u'117663237', u'id': u'117679360', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'At the moment the effects of climate change on land are far smaller than all the other damage we are causing. The sea is different, but there again it's not just the CO2 levels or even the warming of even the deeper ocean; overfishing and dumping of waste are killing the oceans, on which we all ultimately depend. We have been doing immense amounts of damage; but you're right, slowly climate change will overtake the rest.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530456884000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117653259', u'id': u'117673232', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NewView4U', u'text': u'FANTASTIC I wish there were a million people like you in high places with the courage and where with all to execute a big reverse in population explosion Like a trillion ants on an ice cream cone that is the equivalent of humans on the earth I feel your pain', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530469254000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100518880', u'in_reply_to': u'117677231', u'id': u'117679078', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'Gove's plans - to start 2022, we will continue the current subsidies until then - are to increase the grants towards preservation, while removing the grants which are paid to landowners purely on the size of their holdings. He intends to target the things that most need subsidies, which should always have been the point. Don't forget that we paid a lot more into the EU than we received back in grants! 
The Conservatives, unlike the purely urban Labour, have always been a party of two halves, the party of rural areas from great landowners to village dwellers, and the party of business, increasingly big business. Up to a point, it made sense; unless the country has some spare wealth it cannot do much to conserve the countryside or anything else. But today the problem is that the two halves are in many ways incompatible - and the wrong half is in the ascendancy. But they are still a better bet than the alternative, the clue's in the name.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530456426000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117657378', u'id': u'117673092', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'VJP2017', u'text': u'I have an extensive pollinator garden, very few pollinators.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530468879000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17958808', u'id': u'117678927', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NewView4U', u'text': u'It breaks my heart and my way of being as I try to minimize my demand on the planet and its' resources I try to not waste I reuse everything as much as possible I've never purchased additional storage containers or wraps and bags as you receive them free with every product you purchase just reuse everything But cut to the chase Humans are basically a severe incurable cancer We will destroy this planet no matter how hard we try not to which we really don't try not to at all even though the propaganda says we are making great strides to curtail the damage Let's see everyone set the air conditioner at 85 and use a small fan to keep comfortable during heat and keep thermostat at 60 during horrible winters and wear heavy clothes That won't happen but I do it I drive a car once a week 5 miles tops to get supplies and I conserve So the cancer known as human will endure and destroy this planet but know one will ever know as they say easy come easy go', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530468846000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100518880', u'id': u'117678912', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'Illegal to catch great crested newts without a licence; yes, I played with them as a child in the 50s, some years ago they were close to extinction. So far, we've saved them, and the otters and water voles which were going the same way - but we've lost 90% of the hedgehogs, maybe you could bring yours home?
Don't know how long since you were last here, but many frogs, toads and newts of all kinds have died off in the last decade; I remember my son once counting 78 frogs in our garden, he was about 8. He's now 40, this year I saw 9. We've lived here 35 years, when we arrived we were deafened every summer by cuckoos - I last heard one 7 years ago. Living next to an organic dairy farm with wide field margins full of flowers, and near woodland, we do relatively well for insects, but nothing like either the types or the numbers they were. We used to get our house filled with magpie moths every time we opened the windows - there were 2 in here last night. I think you will have a shock - my son now lives in the US, came back this spring for the first time in 4 years, and even in that time he was shocked at the decline he saw.
Isn't the wetta endangered?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530455870000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117657477', u'id': u'117672934', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'VJP2017', u'text': u'Humans in USA are already being legally culled, due to the price of and access to health care, including birth control and abortion; and by personal choice with the increase of suicides.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530468639000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the price of and access to health care', u'effect': u'humans in usa are already being legally culled including birth control and abortion and by personal choice with the increase of suicides'}], u'author_id': u'17958808', u'in_reply_to': u'117675610', u'id': u'117678826', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'tjt77', u'text': u'its good idea to leave a few areas alone and allow what we call 'weeds' to grow, so that unseen (and hence usually un-noticed) life has a chance to survive.. much to the disdain of my neighboring ranchers, I leave certain areas untouched so the seasonal thistles and other 'annoying' plants to humans all have their place to exist..the larvae of butterflies such as 'red admirals' need thistles to survive.. Im fortunate enough to have enough land and sufficient remoteness to allow wildlife to flourish.. as well as zero road traffic within several miles.. different sounds in different seasons here.. the frogs have now done their bit for this year until fall, and now its time for the insects to provide the dominant night sounds..', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530455378000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2686622', u'in_reply_to': u'117672077', u'id': u'117672812', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'Do try looking up some facts. The sun is expected to run out of hydrogen some 4.5 billion years in the future. Humanity will not exist, no species lasts anything like that long. 
It is entirely possible that humanity's future is less than a century because of the destruction we are wreaking around us. Unless we take world-wide action very soon, so many will die in the next century that our civilisation will be lost, even if enough survive to continue the species. Nature eventually destroys plague species, and starts over.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530455277000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the destruction we are wreaking around us', u'effect': u"that humanity 's future is less than a century"}], u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117657628', u'id': u'117672784', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ann odonnell', u'text': u'Glad to hear they are still about.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530468367000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14892594', u'in_reply_to': u'117671819', u'id': u'117678715', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'Not really, not yet. The rate of wildlife decline is far faster than anything the changes to the climate can explain, and is down to much more obvious human intervention - chopping down trees, ploughing up land, building houses, global trade transferring pests from parts of the globe where they have natural controls to where they have none, and so on. Climate changes are so far only a relatively minor cause of problems - as the effects increase, particularly the lack of fresh water in an increasing number of places, it will make bad worse. But it plays little part in most extinctions and shortages so far.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530455005000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117657717', u'id': u'117672716', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ann odonnell', u'text': u'Co. Antrim by the sea.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530468336000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14892594', u'in_reply_to': u'117672521', u'id': u'117678698', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gillian Smittony', u'text': u'We cannot allow our green and pleasant land to become a land of concrete and tar devoid of natural spaces in order to accommodate the hundreds of millions of people being added to the developing world every decade.
It's the exact opposite of where we should be heading. We should be rewilding and allowing our native species to recuperate.
The UK population was 59 million in the 2001 census and has now risen to 66 million in spite of restrictive immigration policies and it's almost certain to hit 70 million in a few short years.
If you open the doors wider how high do you think it will rise over the next century? 100 million? 150 million?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530454921000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17985786', u'in_reply_to': u'117657914', u'id': u'117672698', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'McNairoplane', u'text': u'Ever heard of Malthusian theory?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530468284000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4493731', u'in_reply_to': u'117677231', u'id': u'117678680', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'6/29/18 C02 ppm was 411.54. Current yearly C02 ppm increase has been between 2-3 ppm.
This is a catastrophic rate of increase. It isn't slowing down. It is increasing year over year.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530454907000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13899889', u'id': u'117672694', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'McNairoplane', u'text': u'Not from my garden it isn'tI have 2 different bees nests, hedgehogs, squirrls and frogs and slowworms....what more can you ask for?But for the intervention of my neighbours cats it would be a little part of paradise...but CATS!!Kill everything they can catch and stress those they don't!', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530468239000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4493731', u'id': u'117678661', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'Humans have created an economic system that cannot take account of long-term disadvantages. In a globalised world we could change that to put a value on the natural world, but do very little to do so.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530454628000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117658125', u'id': u'117672623', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'OneNation2', u'text': u'I mostly agree with you. But "active management" does worry me. It presupposes that we have sufficient understanding of an interconnected system whose complexities may well be beyond our comprehension. Outcomes could turn out to be quite the opposite of what our management intervention intended.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530468118000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10932291', u'in_reply_to': u'117675093', u'id': u'117678603', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'No, he is absolutely correct. The world is overpopulated, but the UK is one of the worst affected places. It would be bad enough if we'd not allowed in a single person in the last 20 years, our population was already twice the sustainable level; as we've allowed in millions, all wanting food, homes, energy and fresh water, we have made bad worse. We need to make ourselves as unwelcoming as possible to everyone, and remove any financial incentive to have children. Every new immigrant, every baby born is a pile of dead trees, plants, fungi, insects and fish. None of them worth it.
If everyone who voted to remain packed up themselves and their families and moved out it would be a step in the right direction. Sadly, they seem determined to stay.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530454524000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117661439', u'id': u'117672601', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'Plenty about, wherever do you live?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530454130000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117668659', u'id': u'117672521', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bernadette Bowles', u'text': u'NO NO NO.
You have absolutely no understanding of the UK landscape. It has not been natural in millennia. There is nothing genuinely wild in the UK except the tops of the highest mountains. Monbiot is moaning about sheep - sheep created the landscapes of the Downs and the Cotswolds, the Peak and Lake Districts. Traditional farming worked very well with most of the wild species around; indeed, the hedges which kept farm animals from straying gave increasing numbers of habitats for any number of wild creatures; the habit of coppicing woodland rather than outright felling allowed fungi, lichens, insects, woodland flowers and so on to remain established for centuries; the close-cropped grasses of sheep farms allowed rare and delicate species of plants and insects to become locally common; flower-filled hay meadows encouraged pollinators to orchards full of fruit trees.
The world market produces cheaper food because many countries have few rules on animal welfare - and ignore those they do have - and are ploughing up the habitats of rare animals and plants to feed an excessive world population. If you think we should try to encourage that, you are seriously sick. Your mindset is that of the EU - encourage Indonesia to kill orangutans to give us environmentally friendly diesel. It is a mindset which is responsible for global ruination, all these dirty ships sailing round the world to save pennies, exporting our own environmental destruction.
In the UK, we have some of the world's best farming land, we have some of the toughest rules on animal welfare - which we could and should make tougher once out of the EU - we should be setting standards for other countries to follow if they want to sell to us. You are also saying it is absolutely fine for poorer people to eat food of low nutritional value, pumped full of assorted chemicals, as long as those who can afford it can still have access to the best stuff and great views. Live in Islington, do you?
Plus, if you think beyond the end of your own nose, what of the future? We are, and have been for centuries, a debtor nation. Moreover, we are one with a population more than twice a sustainable size, moving into a vastly overpopulated world where fresh water for irrigation will be a cause of war within a couple of decades, and climate change may destroy the ability of some of the world's largest farming areas to produce at anything like current rates. All countries will struggle to feed their people; world markets will be expensive and suffer from frequent shortages. Then what happens to the bulk of the UK population? We've let in people from hither, thither and yon, they have children, and will have grandchildren - even if we do all we can to feed our own population we cannot hope to do so. If we turn ourselves into a nature theme park with an organic farm for the privileged, millions will starve. 
We have to not only discourage as many people as possible from coming or remaining here, we have to combine producing much more of our own food with protecting what is left of our natural world. We can do better, and many farmers do; the dairy farm next door has wide margins of wild plants around all its fields, currently a picture of purple, white and yellow; mixed hedgerows scented with honeysuckle and roses, soon to be packed with blackberries and haws, grass and crops are both fertilised with slurry from the winter housing of the cattle and the milking sheds, new stands of trees - mainly hazel - in awkward corners are already full of bluebells, anemones and foxgloves. He's been farming like that all the 35 years we've been here, long before it was fashionable. And while there are far fewer butterflies and moths than there used to be, the cuckoos and the grey partridge have gone, and the kites have pushed out the kestrels which used to hover over every field, you will always see some butterflies whenever you walk through, the swifts are still chasing them, skylarks are still singing, and deer, foxes and stoats are frequently in evidence. It can be done, and we need to do it.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530453990000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'many countries have few rules on animal welfare and ignore those they do have', u'effect': u'the world market produces cheaper food'}], u'author_id': u'10257236', u'in_reply_to': u'117669598', u'id': u'117672488', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'davesoul', u'text': u'The tests are a Shan', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530453681000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3170619', u'in_reply_to': u'117611143', u'id': u'117672417', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'packc47', u'text': u'I admit I have recently resorted to Roundup to help with the perennial weeds in part of my garden that I would like to use. I have left a large part of the garden wild and using roundup hasn't damaged the wildlife . In actual fact the weeds still keep coming but it gives me a head start. I wouldn't use it in a small garden.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530453550000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3786343', u'in_reply_to': u'117631307', u'id': u'117672384', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'packc47', u'text': u'I dont trust Gove. I hope he is successful in this area however. I still wouldn't vote Tory though. Its the left wing people who have always been concerned about nature and we have had mainly Tories in government since the war.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530453076000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3786343', u'in_reply_to': u'117635138', u'id': u'117672232', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JeanClawedBrexit', u'text': u'Personally I think we have gone past the point of no return.
Calamity awaits. Even if every single one of us including the super rich put on a hair shirt. Can you IMAGINE the hollywood glitterati agreeing to live frugally ? Beyonce dumping her Nefratiti outfits ?', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530452881000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18023934', u'id': u'117672165', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'disqusagain', u'text': u'I agree and there seems to be a lot of waste land and derelict buildings in and around towns and cities. It is also startling the immense size of some of the developments one wonders if they will ever manage to fill in a rapidly changing demography..', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530452870000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16078791', u'in_reply_to': u'117671902', u'id': u'117672161', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'packc47', u'text': u'I have ivy on a wall. its a massive food source for wildlife but needs managing. Germans encourage it on their buildings to help with insulation. It is used by small bird as a nesting place especially wrens. I cut it hard back twice a year. It doesnt damage modern mortar nor does it damage trees. My problem with it is that it has spread from neighbouring trees onto the ground and is taking over the garden.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530452859000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3786343', u'in_reply_to': u'117653708', u'id': u'117672157', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mothercourage', u'text': u'Great article, although very sad indeed !I can hardly believe that Monsanto and Bayer have merged !However I think that, far from it being more powerful, they have had to cut their losses and merge because they know that their 'number is up' !Ie that the world view has changed against them, thanks to this kind of in depth journalism !Global warming is very real and a multi-faceted problem !The car industry of course has a big responsibility, but then so do Govts, around the world, but also its the power of the people to demand these changes that will ultimately matter the most ! These changes need to happen as a matter of urgency, everyone !', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530452659000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they know that their number is', u'effect': u'that far from it being more powerful they have had to cut their losses and merge'}], u'author_id': u'3944171', u'id': u'117672099', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'packc47', u'text': u'I found some Ragwort in my garden. I dont see many bugs on the windscreen these days.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530452471000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3786343', u'in_reply_to': u'117660364', u'id': u'117672041', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JeanClawedBrexit', u'text': u'Voted out. Call me a gammon. Call me a "volk nationalist" if you like. (No time for "the Queen & the Armed forces" kind of nationalism).
Immigration high on the agenda for voting out. High on the agenda for being against immigration ... overcrowded country, and particularly in relation to having space for wildlife. I know a lot of people like that. "Right wing" on immigration but pretty passionate about wildlife, the environment and animals.
If you pigeon hole people you won't get any improvement.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530452412000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18023934', u'in_reply_to': u'117605987', u'id': u'117672026', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: The creatures we feared our grandchildren wouldn’t see have vanished: it’s happened faster than even pessimists predicted, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
og_fields.og:description: The creatures we feared our grandchildren wouldn’t see have vanished: it’s happened faster than even pessimists predicted, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
og_fields.og:title: Our natural world is disappearing before our eyes. We have to save it | George Monbiot
text:
It felt as disorienting as forgetting my pin number. I stared at the caterpillar, unable to attach a name to it. I don’t think my mental powers are fading: I still possess an eerie capacity to recall facts and figures and memorise long screeds of text. This is a specific loss. As a child and young adult, I delighted in being able to identify almost any wild plant or animal. And now it has gone. This ability has shrivelled from disuse: I can no longer identify them because I can no longer find them.
Perhaps this forgetfulness is protective. I have been averting my eyes. Because I cannot bear to see what we have done to nature, I no longer see nature itself; otherwise, the speed of loss would be unendurable. The collapse can be witnessed from one year to the next. The swift decline of the swift (down 25% in five years) is marked by the loss of the wild screams that, until very recently, filled the skies above my house. My ambition to see the seabird colonies of Shetland and St Kilda has been replaced by the intention never to visit those islands during the breeding season: I could not bear to see the empty cliffs, where populations have crashed by some 90% in the past two decades.
I have lived long enough to witness the vanishing of wild mammals, butterflies, mayflies, songbirds and fish that I once feared my grandchildren would not experience: it has all happened faster than even the pessimists predicted. Walking in the countryside or snorkelling in the sea is now as painful to me as an art lover would find visits to a gallery, if on every occasion another old master had been cut from its frame.
The cause of this acceleration is no mystery. The United Nations reports that our use of natural resources has tripled in 40 years. The great expansion of mining, logging, meat production and industrial fishing is cleansing the planet of its wild places and natural wonders. What economists proclaim as progress, ecologists recognise as ruin.
This is what has driven the quadrupling of oceanic dead zones since 1950; the “biological annihilation” represented by the astonishing collapse of vertebrate populations; the rush to carve up the last intact forests; the vanishing of coral reefs, glaciers and sea ice; the shrinkage of lakes, the drainage of wetlands. The living world is dying of consumption.
We have a fatal weakness: a failure to perceive incremental change. As natural systems shift from one state to another, we almost immediately forget what we have lost. I have to make a determined effort to remember what I saw in my youth. Could it really be true that every patch of nettles, at this time of year, was reamed with caterpillar holes? That flycatchers were so common I scarcely gave them a second glance? That the rivers, around the autumn equinox, were almost black with eels?
Others seem oblivious. When I have criticised current practice, farmers have sent me images of verdant monocultures of perennial ryegrass, with the message: “Look at this and try telling me we don’t look after nature.” It’s green, but it’s about as ecologically rich as an airport runway.
One reader, Michael Groves, records the shift he has seen in the field beside his house, where the grass that used to be cut for hay is now cut for silage. Watching the cutters being driven at great speed across the field, he realised that any remaining wildlife would be shredded. Soon afterwards, he saw a roe deer standing in the mown grass. She stayed throughout the day and the following night. When he went to investigate, he found her fawn, its legs amputated. “I felt sickened, angry and powerless … how long had it taken to die?” That “grass-fed meat” the magazines and restaurants fetishise? This is the reality.
When our memories are wiped as clean as the land, we fail to demand its restoration. Our forgetting is a gift to industrial lobby groups and the governments that serve them. Over the past few months I have been told repeatedly that the environment secretary, Michael Gove, gets it. I have said so myself: he genuinely seems to understand what the problems are and what needs to be done. Unfortunately, he doesn’t do it.
Gove cannot be blamed for all of the fiascos to which he has put his name. The 25-year plan for nature was, it seems, gutted by the prime minister’s office. The environmental watchdog he proposed was de-fanged by the Treasury (it has subsequently been lent some dentures by parliament). Other failures are all his own work. In response to lobbying from sheep farmers, Gove has allowed ravens, a highly intelligent and long-lived species just beginning to recover from centuries of persecution, to be killed once more in order to protect lambs. There are 23 million sheep in this country and 7,400 pairs of ravens. Why must all other species give way to the white plague?
Responding to complaints that most of our national parks are wildlife deserts, Gove set up a commission to review them. But governments choose their conclusions in advance, through the appointments they make. A more dismal, backward-looking and uninspiring panel would be hard to find: not one of its members, as far as I can tell, has expressed a desire for significant change in our national parks, and most of them, if their past statements are anything to go by, are determined to keep them in their sheep-wrecked and grouse-trashed state.
Now the lobbyists demand a New Zealand settlement for farming after Brexit: deregulated, upscaled, hostile to both wildlife and the human eye. If they get their way no landscape, however treasured, will be safe from broiler sheds and mega dairy units, no river protected from runoff and pollution, no songbird saved from local extinction. The merger between Bayer and Monsanto brings together the manufacturer of the world’s most lethal pesticides with the manufacturer of the world’s most lethal herbicides. Already the concentrated power of these behemoths is a hazard to democracy; together they threaten both political and ecological disaster. Labour’s environment team has scarcely a word to say about any of it. Similarly, the big conservation groups have gone missing in inaction.
We forget even our own histories. We fail to recall, for example, that the 1945 Dower report envisaged wilder national parks than we now possess, and that the conservation white paper the government issued in 1947 called for the kind of large-scale protection that is considered edgy and innovative today. Remembering is a radical act.
That caterpillar, by the way, was a six-spot burnet: the larva of a stunning iridescent black and pink moth that once populated my neighbourhood. I will not allow myself to forget again: I will work to recover the knowledge I have lost. For I now see that without the power of memory, we cannot hope to defend the world we love.
• George Monbiot is a Guardian columnist
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

There is also the future and all of the things that have not been tried yet.
