No census has been done. There could be a million explanations for the decline, some serious, some not.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528198464000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4132762', u'in_reply_to': u'116608146', u'id': u'116623589', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Toiletcleaner', u'text': u'"You appear to be a very angry individual. Perhaps I was like you in the past. Now I try to take a different approach I try not to rant at people. Experience has taught me that it is counter productive."
I'm not angry at all! You'll note that I was suggesting everyone should calm down with their apocalyptic views.
"On the one hand you brag about your tiny carbon footprint and low consumption of resources and production of pollution"
Let me guess - I was 'virtue-signalling'?
"on the other you argue that the catastrophic collapse on several bird species has nothing to do with global warming."
Well, no, to be fair I said no such thing. In fact I've clearly said that it may well be related.
"You have me certainly confused me as to what you think is happening. To begin with I thought you had decided that nothing of significant is being reported in this article."
Alas, again, I didn't say that. My comments were about the tone, not the message.
"I don't agree with you. Something serious is occurring. The causes may not be 100% clear but it is high probability that higher sea temperatures driven by global warming is causing fish species to move elsewhere in search of cooler water."
I don't think the seas are warmer around Scotland. If the fish went south, so could the seabirds.
"Another factor could be overfishing but that is a problem the birds have had to cope with for at least half a century so why is the current dramatic decline in bird populations only apparent now."
Salmon farming, would be my guess.
"Pollution of the oceans with plastics and other pollutants is another possible factor."
A fair certainty, I'd say.
There is some evidence that would support the theory that we are approaching a critical point and that we could be on the verge of a collapse in the global environment.
They said that in the 80s. I changed my lifestyle and brought up my family accordingly - I don't see many other people doing the same thing, unfortunately.
"How many species can we afford to lose before the ecosystem collapses.Science is telling us that the rate of species decline even extinction is accelerating. Some scientists studying some specific ecosystems think that we are at the point where the loss is becoming exponential. Coral reefs and the high Arctic are two areas of very serious concern currently."
I agree. I've been saying as much for decades. I did something about it, like I said. Also like I said, coming here and wringing your hands is not going to help. How many posters, complaining about it, have toned their Western-consumerist ways right down? No, they come here and blame population, blame the southern and eastern hemispheres; blame anything but themselves.
"Shed your anger doing some serious study may help. Do an MSc on ecology or something you will probably find it very interesting if a little frightening."
That's just what I need, to go with my frugalist vegan permaculture lifestyle. Thanks for the suggestion.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528198337000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'higher sea temperatures driven by global warming', u'effect': u'fish species to move elsewhere in search of cooler water'}], u'author_id': u'4132762', u'in_reply_to': u'116608959', u'id': u'116623451', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CaptainChien', u'text': u'Found out one thing they do with it; run the RSPB nature reserve at Sumburgh head...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528191825000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3773656', u'in_reply_to': u'116596342', u'id': u'116617160', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'You may be right about people not being willing to change their minds. I tend to try and debate them (as politely as possible) because there are some people who really just don't know and are willing to be convinced and some will read these articles so carefully rebutting every point is a frustrating but necessary task!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528185770000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"there are some people who really just do n't know and are willing to be convinced and some will read these articles so carefully rebutting every point", u'effect': u'to try and debate them'}], u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'116610167', u'id': u'116612088', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Roger Hofer', u'text': u'Yes, there is. And yes, it's shocking. It's not that we mean bad. A cancer cell mass doesn't _mean_ to kill its host. It does, though.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528184655000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14972135', u'in_reply_to': u'116546331', u'id': u'116611383', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Roger Hofer', u'text': u'Too many people. Too much stuff. Too little concern. There's a lot of things that are driving this perfect storm. There's one that will calm the waters, though - collapse. I still wonder if I'll die of climate change in some way... and I'm one of those well-to-do white guys. Yeah, probably.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528184131000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14972135', u'in_reply_to': u'116548797', u'id': u'116611104', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Roger Hofer', u'text': u'Yup. You got it.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528183857000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14972135', u'in_reply_to': u'116558206', u'id': u'116610950', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Roger Hofer', u'text': u'I live in Silicon Valley. I work as an engineer for a not-so-little company called AMD. Look, don't paint all of us here with one brush, man. I literally spend HOURS AND HOURS a week reading about what is going on with respect to climate change. In my cubical is a hand-made magnetic sign that reads "There is no planet B" with a moldering Earth on it. I well know what is going on. I cried and cried in 2016 as the El Nino wiped out 60% of the coral in the Great Barrier reef. Only an uninformed moron wouldn't know we stand at the precipice of our demise at this point. Yet what am I to do? I can't make miracles happen. I can stop driving and stop eating meat--and I've done so to some extent--but that's not going to matter if the politics of the entire world don't address this. We have a mindset called capitalism that has infected the hopes and dreams of billions running rampant. There is absolutely no end in sight either. We are literally signing up for our own demise, and I watch it day by day get worse. I watch the floods, the fires, the methane concentration, the CO2 concentration all increase yet remain impotent to make any difference. And I know millions of people are like that. It's not the consciousness of the few that will change this battle ship's course. It's going to require a massive global effort, and honestly, I don't see it happening... at least until death is knocking loudly at all our doors. And then it'll be too late. Then we'll try to repair what we've done, but by then the tipping points will be so tipped that nothing we do will help. Then we'll just be in a mode of survival. People think that these ideas are the sole purview of a science fiction post appolocylpic disaster movie, but I think we're watching it happen now. This is a nightmare that is just getting started, and all I can say is that I'm glad I don't have kids because, honestly, I don't think I could handle this truth if I had. I'd just stick my head in the sand too because some things are too sad to know.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528183650000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'some things are too sad to know', u'effect': u"i 'd just stick my head in the sand too"}], u'author_id': u'14972135', u'in_reply_to': u'116550580', u'id': u'116610831', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Roger Hofer', u'text': u'In my view, your suggestions are too conservative. We need some serious changes, and I don't see a single shred of evidence anything meaningful is happening now to avert what is to become the unraveling of civilization itself if we don't get a handle on it.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528182468000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14972135', u'in_reply_to': u'116553570', u'id': u'116610331', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Roger Hofer', u'text': u'Yeah like a million years ago before we were a species even. Good lord why bring that even up? No one is claiming here the Earth is doomed are they? WE--you and I--are doomed if we don't change course, and there is no indication at all we are going to do so in time right now. And when I say doomed, I don't even necessarily mean extinct. I mean the human population will crash by 95%+ and the remaining people will be shoved back hundreds if not thousands of years living poleward. Advances in almost every field would be halted for a long time, and the planet we knew would effectively be gone forever.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528182213000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14972135', u'in_reply_to': u'116554504', u'id': u'116610243', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Roger Hofer', u'text': u'Don't bother trying to convince them. I've noticed one thing about people who can't handle the truth about climate change: they also can't handle changing their minds. As the old die, hopefully, the young will tackle this, but at the speed it's progressing, I have my doubts. Humanity may well not be capable of responding fast enough to what is going on just like the other creatures have not been able to. It takes a human--and the dead ideas of the older generation--70 years to die, and we just don't have that long. Never, ever give up trying to live a better life.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528178005000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4340549', u'in_reply_to': u'116549486', u'id': u'116609232', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'climbertrev1', u'text': u'I first went to Koh Samui, Thailand in 1979. I had the experience of a lifetime snorkeling over a coral reef next to Laimai beach. The clarity of the water, the technicolour magic of the corals and the many species of associated fish. The water was so clear that when I swam off the reef edge I experienced vertigo.
I returned a couple of years ago. There is no coral reef next to Laimai beach all thats left is an expanse of bleached dead white rock. There is very little live coral left in the entire gulf of Thailand. The water is simply too warm for corals to exist let alone thrive. What coral is left is bleached and probably dying. The clarity of the water is much diminished. Plastic debris is in evidence everywhere. The Thai media has suddenly woken up to the menace of plastic pollution. The death of the whale, reported in Thailand in the last few days, with dozens of large plastic bags in its stomach has raised the profile of the threat considerably.Translating concern into concerted action may take a little longer but at least they have made a start by acknowledging the problem.
The other big change from 1979 is that back then the sea food was fantastic. Now it is almost non existent beyond farmed prawns and other farmed species. A lot of the so called sea food restaurants are selling red mullet that is actually a species of farmed freshwater fish. If you go fishing you will be extremely fortunate to catch anything over 250 grams.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528177737000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4340549', u'in_reply_to': u'116549501', u'id': u'116609173', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'climbertrev1', u'text': u'Why do humans have to tag these birds, what is the point?

Perhaps I was like you in the past. Now I try to take a different approach I try not to rant at people. Experience has taught me that it is counter productive.After reading and re-reading your posts you are not presenting any kind of coherent view. On the one hand you brag about your tiny carbon footprint and low consumption of resources and production of pollution on the other you argue that the catastrophic collapse on several bird species has nothing to do with global warming. You have me certainly confused me as to what you think is happening. To begin with I thought you had decided that nothing of significant is being reported in this article.I don't agree with you. Something serious is occurring. The causes may not be 100% clear but it is high probability that higher sea temperatures driven by global warming is causing fish species to move elsewhere in search of cooler water. The prey that support the bird species in decline are now out of their hunting range.Another factor could be overfishing but that is a problem the birds have had to cope with for at least half a century so why is the current dramatic decline in bird populations only apparent now.Pollution of the oceans with plastics and other pollutants is another possible factor.
The environment locally and globally is coming under serious pressure. There is some evidence that would support the theory that we are approaching a critical point and that we could be on the verge of a collapse in the global environment.
Paul Ehrlich once used the analogy of being on an aircraft mid ocean. You look out of the window and watch one of many rivets holding the aircraft together parting company with the plane. No need to worry there are lots of other rivets the plane was definitely over engineered it has more than enough rivets to prevent the wings falling off and the aircraft plunging into the ocean. Then you notice another rivet ....and another rivet ...and how do you feel when you notice that the rate of rivet loss is accelerating? How do you feel when you begin to observe exponential loss of rivets?The aircraft is of course the ecosystem the rivets represent the individual species that help the system function. How many species can we afford to lose before the ecosystem collapses.Science is telling us that the rate of species decline even extinction is accelerating. Some scientists studying some specific ecosystems think that we are at the point where the loss is becoming exponential. Coral reefs and the high Arctic are two areas of very serious concern currently.
Shed your anger doing some serious study may help. Do an MSc on ecology or something you will probably find it very interesting if a little frightening.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528176433000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'higher sea temperatures driven by global warming', u'effect': u'fish species to move elsewhere in search of cooler water'}], u'author_id': u'4340549', u'in_reply_to': u'116564680', u'id': u'116608959', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'climbertrev1', u'text': u'Politics is the art of the possible. The honest answer is not that much. You can choose and engineer it so that you do not have any children. That is relatively easy you have control over that. Beyond that you have little or no control. You can lobby for global and local population control and reduction you can support politicians and policies that penalise having children. But beware even that is not going to be easy. In the UK it is now policy that the state should not be encouraging anyone financially to have more than two children. There is already a backlash against this based on child poverty arguments. Deterring people from having lots of children and withdrawing state financial support can be shown to be placing more children in poverty.Evidence demonstrates that the best way to reduce population growth in developing nations is to develop those nations. Educating women appears to be the crucial factor followed by the availability of effective methods of contraception.
Changing your own consumption behaviour will have positive environmental impacts. Reduce, reduce and reduce further your use of resources and production of pollutants. Lobby for others to do the same. Lobby for government action to curb harmful environmental practices. In real life and everything.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528144373000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14691022', u'in_reply_to': u'116583791', u'id': u'116602328', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesValencia', u'text': u'"The majority of nations are to blame regardless of prevailing ideology or economic system" - agreed. It goes deeper than capitalism vs. socialism. 
Both systems aim for "more". Of course capitalists won't agree because they delight in painting socialism as "hair shirts and misery for all" - not at all: socialism means "the best possible standard of living for everyone".That's why socialism can also lead to over-exploitation and environmental collapse.
As for capitalism: this says "create wealth as a return on property, the best for the individual, within the rule of law and protection fo property in all its forms". Conservatives usually go along with this which is why conservatives are often capitalists.Capitalism / most conservatives are therefore likely to over-exploit the environment too because the prime concern is the individual.
There is a difference between the two though:• Socialism is based on reason (whether reason is correct is another matter note), in that planning, legislation, and regulations are the tools to make things as best as possible for everyone. Cooperation, not competition. The Pyramids rather than the Forth Bridge.As a result, socialism is better at looking ahead.
To cut a long story short, both systems can, and have, destroyed ecosystems. But socialism is more likely to recover.
And let's not forget: we're used to hearing "Berlin wall! Socialism is dead! The free market rules now forever!"This is quite wrong: Socialism is in fact three sorts:• Anarchism : everything decided in common without leadership.• Communism: autocratic socialism where "experts decide all: the central committee. With an added twist: this is meant to be a temporary phase transforming society so that is is ready to become anarchist.• Democracic socialism / social democracy: The de-facto form of government around the planet, includin the good old USA (social support, controlled imports / exports: the market harnessed in the best interests of all).
Only Monaco, Andorra, Russia to some extent, China, alright a few others are not some approximation to democratic socialism. But many people, not least the right, like to pretend this is not the case.
That dragged on a while: Just to say, both socialism and capitalism (conservatism) can destroy the environment. But only with one (capitalism) is it inevitable and irrecoverable.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528144007000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'socialism', u'effect': u'over collapse'}, {u'cause': u'they delight in painting socialism as shirts all', u'effect': u"of course capitalists wo n't agree"}, {u'cause': u'the prime concern is the individual', u'effect': u'capitalism conservatives are therefore likely to over exploit too'}], u'author_id': u'3761271', u'in_reply_to': u'116561299', u'id': u'116602163', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'Our species is of course part of the ecology of planet earth, the big problem is we don't see it that way. Probably one of the most harmful tools we ever developed was 'science' i'm not anti science but we just never took responsibility for the wonderful advantages it gave our species. i.e. our own discipline in both breeding & consumption. the two go hand in hand.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528138625000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'116577935', u'id': u'116599640', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u''Gulls' covers a lot of species - which ones are pests - kittiwakes are really struggling. I never said gulls were big cats - I was using a well known group of animals to demonstrate that the wildlife decline that is talked about in this article is not uniquely affecting these species - it is global and across all trophic levels and animal groups - that is what is catastrophic, that it is near universal across species, ecosystems and continents. 
Secondly, some species of gull are vital links in the ecological chain - using an example from the other side of the world - Norfolk Island. Gulls (and other sea birds filling the same niche) which were hugely common until invasive introduced rats, cats and mice started causing large declines in their numbers (primarily through predation of chicks). There are still thousands of them, however, their numbers have dropped on Norfolk Island (but not as much as the Kittiwakes mentioned here) - this has led to significant drops in bird guano which has meant that the soil on the island isn't getting the necessary phosphorous every year to help the island's keystone plant species - the Norfolk Island Pine tree that (until humans came along) forested most of the island and nwo the remaining pines are struggling in part due to a lack of phosphorous which they go from bird droppings - from birds that you would think are common enough and a pest.
A 90% drop in a key nutrient cycling species does have an impact. 
Of course not all aniamls have a large ecological impact (keystone species have a much larger one as do apex predators) but that seems a strange way to think if you like nature - oh that species isn't hte most improtant therefore I don't care what happens to it. It also isn't how ecology works, ecosystems are complex interrelationships between a huge number of species.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528138501000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'large declines in their numbers'}, {u'cause': u'a lack of phosphorous which they go from bird droppings', u'effect': u'the remaining pines are struggling in part'}, {u'cause': u'this', u'effect': u"significant drops in bird guano which has meant that the soil on the island is n't getting the necessary phosphorous every year to help the island 's keystone plant species"}], u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'116598614', u'id': u'116599580', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ignorethehype', u'text': u'This story gets recycled over and over. description: Climate change has caused a catastrophic drop in the numbers of terns, kittiwakes and puffins
og_fields.og:description: Climate change has caused a catastrophic drop in the numbers of terns, kittiwakes and puffins
og_fields.og:title: Eerie silence falls on Shetland cliffs that once echoed to seabirds’ cries
text:
Sumburgh Head lies at the southern tip of mainland Shetland. This dramatic 100-metre-high rocky spur, crowned with a lighthouse built by Robert Louis Stevenson’s grandfather, has a reputation for being one of the biggest and most accessible seabird colonies in Britain.
Thousands of puffins, guillemots, razorbills, kittiwakes and fulmars gather there every spring to breed, covering almost every square inch of rock or grass with teeming, screeching birds and their young.
Or at least they used to – for this year Sumburgh Head is a quiet and largely deserted place. Where seabirds once swooped and cried in their thousands, only a handful of birds wheel round the cliffs. The silence is uncanny – the result of a crash in seabird numbers that has been in progress for several years but which has now reached an unprecedented, catastrophic low.
One of the nation’s most important conservation centres has been denuded of its wildlife, a victim – according to scientists – of climate change, which has disrupted food chains in the North Sea and North Atlantic and left many seabirds without a source of sustenance. The result has been an apocalyptic drop in numbers of Arctic terns, kittiwakes and many other birds.
“In the past, Sumburgh Head was brimming with birds, and the air was thick with the smell of guano. The place was covered with colonies of puffins, kittiwakes, fulmars, and guillemots,” said Helen Moncrieff, manager of RSPB Scotland’s office in Shetland.
“There were thousands and thousands of birds and visitors were guaranteed a sight of puffins. Today they have to be very patient. At the same time, guillemots have halved in numbers. It is utterly tragic.”
This grim description is backed by figures that reveal the staggering decreases in seabird numbers in Shetland, the most northerly part of the British Isles. In 2000, there were more than 33,000 puffins on the island in early spring. That figure dropped to 570 last year and there are no signs of any recovery this year, although it is still early in the season.
Similarly, Shetland’s kittiwake population plummeted from over 55,000 in 1981 to 5,000 in 2011, and observers believe those numbers have declined even further in the past few years. Only the lack of a properly funded census has prevented ornithologists from putting precise numbers on the devastation that is occurring.
“I went to check our sites at Dalsetter and Troswick last week to compare numbers of Arctic terns with those we counted during Seabird 2000, the last national seabird census carried out across Britain and Ireland,” added Moncrieff. “I found there were around 110 Arctic terns there last week compared with around 9,000 that were counted in the same area in 2000. That is the kind of loss we have sustained here.”
This point is backed by Euan Dunn, principal policy officer for the RSPB. “These are apocalyptic numbers,” he told the Observer. “We are seeing something very dramatic happening, something that has never occurred in the history of ornithology up there.”
The causes of these devastating declines are many, according to scientists – though most agree that the disappearance of food sources is the main reason. Seabirds rely heavily on sand eels for food, and this supply was severely depleted in northern waters by fishing – though this was eventually halted, allowing stocks to recover. However, these have now been disrupted again by global warming, triggered by rising carbon dioxide emissions from factories, cars and power plants that burn fossil fuels. Temperatures in the North Sea and North Atlantic have risen significantly as a result.
“This warming seems to be affecting the availability of plankton at the time when sand eels produce their larvae,” said Dunn. “There is less plankton and the larvae grow less well and survive less well.”
Not every coastal area of the UK is affected to the same degree, as has been highlighted in a recent project carried out by the RSPB. Groups of puffins, one of the seabirds worst affected by the current crisis, were tagged at two different locations: Shetland and the Shiant Islands, in the Inner Hebrides, where numbers have remained relatively stable in recent years. In the latter, the birds were found to travel on very short journeys of a few kilometres before they returned to their young with plenty of plump fish.
However in Shetland, the picture was found to be starkly different. One of its puffins was found to have to fly more than 400km (248 miles) to find food. “That is more than 10 times further than we thought they were flying,” added Dunn. “Journeys like that are hugely energy consuming and leave the birds very weakened. Not only that, they bring back fish that are much less nutritious than the ones they caught in the good old days when Shetland had plenty of puffins.”
A similar story is provided by trackers fitted to guillemots and razorbills from nearby Fair Isle, which has also suffered serious seabird population losses. They too are having to travel hundreds of kilometres to find food. “It explains clearly why our colonies have foundered,” said Dunn.
In addition to the sand eel crisis that affects coastal areas of Scotland, there is the problem of plastic which builds up on beaches and is ingested by seabirds, with fulmars being particularly badly affected.
“We believe there is plastic in the stomachs of every Shetland fulmar,” said Moncrieff. “If you scaled up what you find in a fulmar’s stomach, it is the equivalent of having a lunch box full of plastic inside your own stomach. There would be no room left for proper food.”
The catastrophe that has struck Shetland’s seabird population has been revealed just as similar crises are being reported from other islands round Britain. Puffin numbers have dropped dramatically on the Farne Islands, it was reported last month, while on St Kilda, one of the most significant seabird colonies in the North Atlantic, there has been a 99% reduction in kittiwake nests since 1990. Two years ago, in all the island’s monitored sites, only one pair bred –and that single chick died.
Yet as these crises have unfolded, the government has declined to fund a new national census, along the lines of those organised in 1970, 1985 and 2000, even though it is supposed to instigate one every 15 years. “Fortunately, it has now agreed to proceed with one, which we hope should be completed by the end of next year,” said Dunn. “Then we should have a better overall picture of what is happening and why these striking declines are happening in particular places.”
For Shetland, the catastrophic decline in many of its key seabird populations is an issue of real concern. The islands are famed for their bleak beauty and have become an important eco-tourism destination. The loss of many of its seabird colonies does not help that cause – though it still has many special attractions: its prehistoric houses and iron age towers, called brochs; a large population of otters (more than 10% of Britain’s otters live here); and increasing numbers of visits by killer whales.
As Moncrieff said: “There are still good reasons to come here, but equally the crisis that has hit so many of our seabirds is not something that we can continue to ignore.”
• Turtle doves used to arrive in large numbers in April to breed in the British Isles but have now disappeared from large areas of the countryside for a variety of reasons: lack of seed from arable plants; the parasite that carries trichomonosis; and hunting during their migration through southern Europe. As a result, the turtle dove has become the UK’s fastest declining bird and is now considered at risk of global extinction.
• Wader populations are declining worldwide thanks to the loss and degradation of habitats, increased predation, and a changing climate. In the UK, this has produced dramatic declines in curlew populations over recent decades – the species has been proposed as the UK’s most important bird conservation priority.
• Nightingales and pied flycatchers have declined in large numbers since monitoring of these woodland species began in 1994, leading to their appearance on the red list of endangered bird species in the UK. In total, there are now 16 woodland birds on the red list.
• One of five upland bird species that were moved on to the red list recently, the dotterel has declined severely in numbers since the 1980s. Causes for the drop include changes in grazing practices and atmospheric pollution, as well as the effect of climate change, to which mountain-dwelling species are especially vulnerable.
Sources: the British Trust for Ornithology; the State of the UK’s Birds 2016.

BQENDYes knowing how intermittent something will be helps you to plan how much extra infrastructure and spending you need to compensate for it.
So if your household have to get into work every day and night and you know the train will only be on time 10.2% of the time (the average yearly capacity factor of solar in the UK) and won't work at night then how much extra do you plan to spend on travel.On top of your season ticket you can buy a bike - not ideal for all seasons but okay for short distances.Knowing how unreliable the trains are you can budget for taxis -they cost massively more (especially as you've paid for the train), tend to be slower and aren't good for the environment.

By Rachel Morison7 June 2018, 14:00 GMT+10 "Forecasters see wind output staying low for at least two weeks Wind generating 4.3% of U.K. electricity on Wednesday
Britain’s gone nine days with almost no wind generation, and forecasts show the calm conditions persisting for another two weeks.
The wind drought has pushed up day-ahead power prices to the highest level for the time of year for at least a decade. Apart from a surge expected around June 14, wind levels are forecast to stay low for the next fortnight, according to The Weather Company.
U.K. turbines can produce about as much power as 12 nuclear reactors when conditions are right. During the “Beast from the East” storm that hit Britain in March, they generated record levels of power and at times provided the biggest share of the nation’s electricity."
Actually that's nothing exceptional. In the past there have been three-week intervals with virtually nil wind, and two months with low winds. 
On a more general level we now have just under 20GW of wind nameplate capacity, which is two thirds of the typical summer daytime consumption, and may even equal the night consumption sometimes. Yet in spite of this massive deployment, wind output is more typically in the 5GW region. So, even to achieve an average performance equal to fossil fuels, we'd need to deploy four times as much wind kit. Somebody has to pay for all that equipment! 
Then, we have the battery car promoters trying to ban diesels so as to promote sales of their products. Their argument is that battery cars can be recharged from wind energy. -Wait a mo, though, wind energy is struggling to meet normal electricity demand, and you want to add the whole of the UK's transport energy demand to that? Sir, you are not just a dreamer. You are without the capacity to reason. 
Thing is, rarely do you see an honest report on wind or solar performance. All you see in here is cherry-picked praise for these technologies. The Great American Fracking Bubble
BQSTART
An Industry Built on Debt Roughly a decade after McClendon’s rise, the Wall Street Journal reported that “energy companies [since 2007] have spent $280 billion more than they generated from operations on shale investments, according to advisory firm Evercore ISI.” 
As a whole, the American fracking experiment has been a financial disaster for many of its investors, who have been plagued by the industry’s heavy borrowing, low returns, and bankruptcies, and the path to becoming profitable is lined with significant potential hurdles. Up to this point, the industry has been drilling the “sweet spots” in the country’s major shale formations, reaching the easiest and most valuable oil first.
But at the same time energy companies are borrowing more money to drill more wells, the sweet spots are drying up, creating a Catch-22 as more drilling drives more debt.
BQEND
Plus, of course, US frack gas is propped up by shale oil, but it will only take a small reduction in oil demand (from the rollout of EV's) to knock the crude price down slightly, and that will wipe out the industries with the highest abstraction costs first, putting US shale and Canadian oil sands right in the cross-hairs.

Main customer of Arizona coal plant goes green, ignoring Interior Department
BQSTART
The Trump administration has been waging a broad effort to keep aging coal and nuclear plants from retirement, arguing that their closure would constitute a threat to national energy security. 
On Friday, the board of the Central Arizona Project (CAP), a major electricity consumer that supplies water to a large swath of Arizona, voted to sign a 20-year agreement to buy power from a solar project and also agreed to a five-year power deal with utility Salt River Project for electricity from a variety of sources.
The vote came despite a plea from the head of Interior’s Bureau of Reclamation, who last Friday wrote to board members to say that a 1968 law gives Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke power to require the CAP to buy energy from the Navajo Generating Station, or NGS, a 2,250-MW coal-fired power plant that is scheduled to close in 2019.
BQEND
But far more important is that whilst cheap gas is pushing nuclear and coal off the grid, the even lower cost of RE can now push gas off the grid:
America Should Invest In Distributed Renewable Energy Instead Of Natural Gas Plants, Finds RMI Report
BQSTART
Half of all existing conventional electricity generating plants in the US will need to be replaced by 2030 as they reach the end of their useful life. The question is, what should they be replaced with? The Rocky Mountain Institute has studied this question and concluded that investing in distributed renewable energy makes the most economic sense. 
RMI says, “US electricity generators may be committing their customers and investors to as much as $1 trillion in future investment and fuel costs through 2030 as they rush to build new gas-fired power plants. Yet advances in renewable energy and distributed energy resources (DERs) offer lower rates and emissions-free energy while delivering all the grid reliability services that new power plants can.”
If the proposed natural gas facilities get built, they will eat up $480 billion in fuel costs and pump 5 billion tons of carbon dioxide into the air through 2030. By 2050, total emissions will amount to 16 billion tons. Renewables, which have no fuel costs and no carbon emissions, should be a no-brainer. That they are not is an indication of how dysfunctional US energy policy is at the present time.
BQEND
So, nuclear and coal can't compete against gas, and gas can't compete against RE. Great news.
Plus the US is expecting £11/MWh PV generation in the early 2020's:
The path to US$0.015/kWh solar power, and lower

BQEND
Lets start with intermittency- Southern Europe, the Southern States and a lot of the developing world has predictable intermittency- when it comes to solar, so storage just has to get people through the night or a few dull days.In other places like the Great Plains, the offshore resource particularly off Europe the wind is predictable- and supplying up to 30% in the UK, and that could and will be 50%.pretty well all studies have no problem with 50% or even 80% renewables- the last 20% is very tricky and something that will need to be dealt with after 2050.
Nuclear has its supply problems-- new nuclear can vary output reasonably fast to cope with the demand spike which can be twice as much as the off peak. Canada did a whole study on the subject- and eventually decided the best option was to change consumer habits so they evened out demand. But EVs could be the saviour.
In the UK with lower electricity consumption than the US the current off peak period if ran at capacity could supply 30% of transport without any new generation- that is 10 million vehicles. And a complete electrification of transport only increases demand by 40%. Switching from fossil fuels for heating to efficient heat pumps is just another 10% .
Nuclear could be a future with an electric economy.
By 2050 oil will certainly be in decline- perhaps sooner. why use 10 kWh of gas to move a car 10 miles or less when a similar EV will move 40 miles? Batteries don't have to have the same energy density as petrol or diesel- and when it comes to weight you can lose the engine, gear box, fuel and tank and 3/4 of the energy lost in heat.With 300 mile range cars now that can be charged in 20 min and just 10-20% heavier any improvement in battery density will just make cars cheaper. i.e. small city cars with 80 mile range.sometime after 2030 it will be difficult to find a ICv, and a problem finding a station to sell you gas. You can of course run a horse years after cars arrived but feeding them or looking after them especially in cities is expensive and specialist.
Trains, autos, heating, etc does not care where the electricity comes from - but the system will need to be robust and do more work than it has in the past. Of course the infrastructure of roads in the US was pretty rubbish and a huge investment in the interstate system was required. In the new industrial revolution grid infrastructure will also need upgrading, just as blacksmiths and livery stables had to change and build a new auto infrastructure.The challenge to replace fossil fuels is huge- and it would be huge if we chose nuclear or renewables. I mean truly, no one has ever seen fusion in the middle of a star, so it is impossible for it to exist.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528656825000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17680035', u'in_reply_to': u'116780835', u'id': u'116820708', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glennmr', u'text': u'There is a history in the US about electricity production that may be interesting. A long time ago in a land far far away, I was working for a large utility in the south of the US that fired gas essentially for all their MW. They had oil backup (#6 nasty oil) and zero coal plants. Back in the 70s, energy growth was enormous and electricity demand was increasing about 7% a year in a lot of markets including the one I was in. The oil companies at that time informed the utilities that they could not supply natural gas in sufficient quantities past the late 80s. (this was before LNG stuff and finding a bunch more natural gas off shore.) So, the word was out…build coal plants and nuclear. The utility I was working for even started coal conversion…replacing boilers on their gas fired plants. No utility would fire coal if natural gas is available because coal plants are much harder to maintain and just nasty overall. This is why coal took off in the US…and nuclear sort of--exploding costs were the real issue. When the oil shocks hit, the electricity growth went negative for a bit and then only increased slowly. No need for more plants and many nukes got cancelled..as did many coal plants. This was all before the TMI accident. The nuclear industry was on the way out for several years before TMI. Energy efficient A/C and many other home and office products have kept growth low.
The fossil fuel industry still holds sway over Washington with their lobbying…so, the Republicans may have given lip service to nuclear, but never really supported it in any fashion. Some local governments have put in support for nuke plants…and the natural gas industry has sued as a result. This is one symptom of the US energy plan…which is a plan to ensure there is never a plan and long-term means “next quarter.”
Now with fracking and LNG, natural gas is king again…but that won’t last very long as we are burning it way too fast…In a decade or two, when the “utter confusion” stage hits, it will be too interesting to see the associated panic.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528651155000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'coal plants are much harder to maintain and just nasty overall', u'effect': u'if natural gas is available'}], u'author_id': u'17680035', u'in_reply_to': u'116817629', u'id': u'116818324', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'Thanks for your answer. It's entirely feasible and of course the side effect is electricity production rather then electrolyser consumption but that would take decades to come to scale.
Batteries are easier.
That's not to say hydrogen and fuel cell won't be of great use commercially/ I think they will, but we will have to CCS the CO₂ from the steam reformation process and the Luddites hate CCS almost as much as they hate nuclear.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528637854000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'116762412', u'id': u'116812767', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'so Jules, given your tacit acknowledgement that:- JBL:"300 mile range cars now that can be charged in 20 min" -is nonsense, I'm still waiting to hear about the cars you say will charge at 150kw instead of the 225kw of your initial claim.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528637354000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'116736652', u'id': u'116812582', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'heinbloed', u'text': u'Atom Clown.

description: Dana Nuccitelli: The powerful few who benefit from the fossil fuel status quo are exerting their influence
headline: r
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: The powerful few who benefit from the fossil fuel status quo are exerting their influence
og_fields.og:title: The latest weak attacks on EVs and solar panels | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
Over the past two weeks, media attacks on solar panels and electric vehicles have been followed by Trump administration policies aimed at boosting their fossil fueled rivals.
The first salvo came via a Forbes article written by Michael Shellenberger, who’s running a doomed campaign for California governor and really loves nuclear power. Shellenberger’s critique focused on the problem of potential waste at the end of a solar panel lifespan when the modules must be disposed or recycled. It’s a somewhat ironic concern from a proponent of nuclear power, which has a rather bigger toxic waste problem.
About 80% of a solar panel module can be recycled, but some portions cannot, and create potentially hazardous waste due to the presence of metals like cadmium and lead. The Electric Power Research Institute notes that long-term storage of used panels until recycling technologies become available may be the best option for dealing with this waste stream. Ultimately, it’s an issue that will need to be addressed as solar panels become more widespread and reach the end of their 25-plus year lifespan, much like the issue of nuclear waste. But it’s an issue that we should be able to resolve with smart policies and technologies.
It’s also not a big near-term concern, unlike the urgent need to deploy low-carbon energy, or an immediate pollution problem like for example the environmental crises that result when oil rigs fail or coal barges sink into rivers.
#BREAKING VIDEO: Sinking barge spilling coal into the Monongahela River in PennsylvaniaVideo via WTAE-TV pic.twitter.com/zzeI0RZWeL
Shellenberger also raised concerns about the possibility “that cadmium can be washed out of solar modules by rainwater.” But that’s only a problem for broken panels, which are relatively rare except perhaps in the wake a natural disaster like a hurricane or earthquake. In a disaster area, leaching of metals from some broken solar panels is the least of a city’s problems.
In short, it’s valid to note that end-of-life solar panel recycling and disposal is an issue that we’ll have to address smartly, but unlike climate change, it’s not a big or urgent concern. Meanwhile, the Trump administration is planning to order grid operators to buy electricity from struggling coal power plants to extend their lives. This is the latest in the administration’s misguided campaign to save the dying coal industry, which can no longer compete in the free market against cheaper, cleaner alternatives. As a result, coal power plants have continued to shut down at a rapid rate. Those coal plants pose a much greater threat of pollution, including from heavy metals.
I eagerly await the administration’s regulations protecting pagers, fax machines, and Blockbuster. https://t.co/ykLJHT4OvK
In the New York Times, conservative opinion columnist Bret Stephens devoted an editorial last week to attacking Tesla specifically, and electric cars in general. There are valid reasons to criticize Tesla – the company regularly falls short of its ambitious production goals – but Stephens’ piece went far beyond what’s fair. For example, it called the Tesla Model 3 “a lemon” because Consumer Reports initially did not recommend the vehicle due primarily to issues with braking distance during its tests. Within about a week, Tesla issued a software update to correct the braking problem, and the Model 3 earned its Consumer Reports recommendation. Worse yet, Stephens declared that gasoline is the fuel of the future:
The terrible idea is that electric cars are the wave of the future, at least for the mass market. Gasoline has advantages in energy density, cost, infrastructure and transportability that electricity doesn’t and won’t for decades.
That’s equivalentt to saying in 1910 that horses have advantages over automobiles, and will continue to dominate the transportation market. The experts disagree. The International Energy Agency estimated that global electric vehicle ownership increased 54% from 2016 to 2017, to 3.1 million EVs, and projects that number will increase 40-fold to 125 million by 2030. Virtually every major automaker is developing electric cars. GM plans to launch 20 new all-electric models by 2023 and the company “believes in an all-electric future.” Nissan plans to launch 8 new all-electric models by 2020 and hopes to sell 1 million EVs per year by that date.
As for the infrastructure disadvantage, California, New York, and New Jersey are spending a combined $1.3bn on EV charging to address that problem. But more than 80% of EV charging happens at home. The Nissan Leaf and Chevrolet Bolt have 150- and 200-mile ranges, respectively, and the average American only drives 30 miles per day. An MIT study in 2016 found that EVs with a 74-mile range could meet 87% of American car owners’ needs with only overnight charging at home; Nissan and GM have doubled and nearly tripled that range. Infrastructure is no longer a big obstacle to EV adoption for many people.
Costs are difficult to compare; while electric cars receive federal and state rebates, fossil fuels receive tremendous subsidies, particularly in the form of deferred climate change costs. Recent research suggests that the ‘social cost of carbon’ is around $200 per ton, which equates to an effective subsidy of close to $2 per gallon of gasoline. Doing an apples-to-apples comparison by either accounting for current fuel prices and federal tax EV credits, or excluding tax credits but adding $2 per gallon to fuel costs, electric vehicles already have similar lifetime costs to comparable gasoline-powered sedans. And due to improving battery technology, the price per mile of EV range is falling rapidly.
The Trump administration is working on behalf of the fossil fuel industry to stall the transition to electric cars, advancing regulations that will freeze fuel efficiency requirements. However, California will be taking the Trump and Pruitt EPA to court in order to preserve the state’s ability to set its own vehicle pollution standards.
In a world where leaders in every country outside America accept the reality of dangerous human-caused climate change, these clean technologies are the future. Working to undermine their progress in the US will just allow competing countries like China to gain a bigger advantage in the growing green economy of the future.

description: Other new research shows diesel vehicles cause 88% of the £6bn annual damage to people’s health from car and van exhaust in the UK
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Other new research shows diesel vehicles cause 88% of the £6bn annual damage to people’s health from car and van exhaust in the UK
og_fields.og:title: 'Impossible-to-cheat' emissions tests show almost all new diesels still dirty
text:
Emissions tests that are impossible for carmakers to cheat show that almost all diesel car models launched in Europe since the “dieselgate” scandal remain highly polluting.
The test uses a beam of light to analyse the exhaust plume of a car as it passes and automatic number plate recognition to link the measurement to a specific model. More than 370,000 such measurements taken in the UK, France and other countries have been compiled into new rating system called The Real Urban Emissions Initiative (True) and made available to the public on Wednesday.
Volkswagen was exposed as cheating emissions tests in September 2015. But, without breaking the letter of the law, almost all car manufacturers were producing diesels that emitted far more in real-world driving conditions than in official lab-based tests. This was done by optimising vehicles to pass standardised tests, but the beam test is conducted as cars pass and so cannot be manipulated.
The True analysis shows that new diesel models released in 2016 were still on average five over times above the EU’s official baseline limit of 0.08mg of nitrogen oxides (NOx) per kilometre. The 2017 models were a little cleaner, but still nearly four times over. 
NOx pollution is at illegally high levels in numerous EU nations. It is estimated to cause 23,500 early deaths a year in the UK, where government plans to cut pollution have been repeatedly ruled so inadequate as to be illegal. Separate research published on Wednesday calculates that diesel cars and vans, which make up less than half the UK’s fleet, cause 88% of the health damage from light vehicles. 
The beam tests are continuing and will be able to single out highly polluting models in future. “I see this remote sensing mostly as a screening tool, to see which vehicle models behave suspiciously,” said Peter Mock, at the International Council on Clean Transportation which produced the True rating in partnership with the FIA Foundation and other groups. 
Those models highlighted as highly polluting could then be tested by putting a portable emissions measuring system (Pems) on a car, which is more accurate but also much more expensive. Diesel cars shown by the True data to emit far more NOx than the official baseline when on the road included two-litre Fiat Chrysler models – 18 times more – and 1.6-litre Renault Nissan models – 14 times more – though the cars passed legally required tests.
“If I was a customer, I would look at these figures at the moment and have to conclude I should not buy a diesel car,” Mock said, noting that the petrol versions are far cleaner. “Even Euro 6 [the most recent standard] diesel vehicles are not performing well at the moment so pretty much all of them should not have access to city centres.”
Greg Archer, at campaign group Transport & Environment, which is part of the True initiative, said: “The True rating exposes the legacy of dieselgate – tens of millions of dirty diesels that are still on the roads producing the toxic smog we daily breathe. It identifies the worst performing models and regulators must act to require carmakers to clean these up.”
The True rating is a “brilliant” screening tool and also good at monitoring pollution from cars as they get older and enter the used car market, said Nick Molden, chief executive of Emissions Analytics, which performs 300-400 Pems tests every year on new car models and publishes another rating system called the Equa index.
But Molden cautioned that the True rating system, which averages the same models across several years, will not show when the latest model has radically cut its pollution. He cites the example of a Mercedes model that improved significantly between 2014 and 2017: “It went from quite dirty to really quite clean.”
Since September 2017, new cars have had to pass a road-based test, but an EU compromise with the industry means emissions can still legally be double the baseline limit. Molden said car manufacturers are now very wary of being caught launching cars that fail emissions tests and some new diesel models are very clean, sometimes 50% below the baseline.
Mike Hawes, chief executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers & Traders, said: “Thanks to massive investment, each generation of vehicle is more advanced than the last, with significantly lower pollutant emissions. This is acknowledged by the [True] report, and consumers can be assured that new cars on sale today are the cleanest ever and fully compliant with EU emissions standards.”
The new analysis of the health impact of diesel in the UK was conducted by experts at the University of Oxford and University of Bath in advance of Clean Air day 2018 on 21 June. They used data on the number of vehicles and mileage, along with government estimates of the harm caused by pollution.
The researchers found the health damage from diesel vehicle emissions are about 20 times greater than from electric vehicles and five times more than petrol vehicles. Christian Brand, at the University of Oxford, said: “Cars and vans are responsible for 10,000 early deaths each year, and diesel vehicles are the main problem unfortunately.”

article_tags: [Farming, Environment, Australian politics, Drought, Australia news, Water, Climate change]
description: Farmers and National party voters say they are ‘increasingly frustrated’ at the lack of action on climate change
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: Farmers and National party voters say they are ‘increasingly frustrated’ at the lack of action on climate change
og_fields.og:title: Farmers challenge Nationals' claim drought unrelated to climate change
text:
Farmers have challenged National party claims that conditions in drought-stricken regions in eastern Australia should not be politicised by attributing them to climate change.
Farmer and former Nationals leader John Anderson said this week that while the drought was the worst he had experienced, it was not unprecedented.
He told the Financial Review farming records for his property, which had been in his family for more than a century, showed droughts of equal severity between 1902 and 1904 and again in 1940.
“I’m not a climate change denier but I would be very wary about using this as a political device,” he said. 
The deputy prime minister and Nationals leader, Michael McCormack, also said: “I’m a believer that the climate is always changing and it’s been changing since Moses was a boy.”
Verity Morgan-Schmidt is from a multigeneration farming family in Western Australia and is CEO of Farmers for Climate Action.
She said the comments were “a disservice to many of our farmers who are already facing the reality of climate change”.
“My family has been on properties out in Western Australia for over 100 years. We can say this has well and truly moved beyond natural cyclical patterns,” she said.
“The idea that we could be accused of playing politics by accepting reality is a bitter pill to swallow. The science is clear. Climate change is increasing the severity of extreme weather events that include drought.
“The vast majority of farmers and National party voters that we speak to are growing increasingly frustrated at the lack of action on climate change at a federal level.”
The south-east of Australia has experienced record high temperatures this year during an unseasonably dry and hot autumn, prompting fire bans and warnings from authorities.
In its latest winter outlook, the Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting warmer and drier than average conditions across large parts of the country.
Richie Merzian, the Australia Institute’s climate and energy program director, said: “There is a well-established link between climate change and the frequency and harshness of droughts in Australia.”
In its latest drought statement, the Bureau of Meteorology listed May 2018 as the third-driest May on record.
The Climate Council has identified an 11% decline in the growing-season rainfall (April–October) in south-east Australia since the mid-90s, the period including the millennium drought. 
It has highlighted “particularly strong drying trends” in south and southwestern Australia in the months of May and July and says it is likely climate change is making drought worse in both south-east and south-west Australia, some of the most productive farmland in the country.
“The bottom line is climate change is making weather patterns more extreme and unpredictable and that has serious consequences for Australia’s agriculture production,” the Climate Council’s research director and acting CEO, Martin Rice, said.
“In southern Australia we are seeing the influence of climate change and drought. We’re seeing less cool season rainfall and that’s having an impact on agriculture.
Rice said hotter than average conditions and heatwave conditions in northern parts of New South Wales were leading to drier conditions and there had been an “abject failure” in climate policy at a federal level. 
“Hot temperatures bring dry conditions and we can expect to see an increase in drought if we don’t reduce emissions,” he said.
“Farmers generally are on the frontline of climate change and they are experiencing worsening extreme weather events, particularly heat-related events and that has an impact on their business.” 
The prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, who is touring drought-affected regions, and the agriculture minister, David Littleproud, have acknowledged climate change is a factor.

How can denial exist when factual evidence is presented?https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_level_rise', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528453381000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2600028', u'in_reply_to': u'116711292', u'id': u'116737020', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'derekcolman', u'text': u'Naturally means the rise of sea level due to ice melting which has been going on for the last 15,000 years since the planet came out of the last glaciation. This is a process which will probably continue until the next glaciation takes hold. It is a process which was quite rapid initially but obviously slows down as it approaches equilibrium. Over the last few centuries it has occurred at a rate of 8 to 12 inches per century. It is difficult to be precise because of the difficulty of actually measuring it, as levels vary in different parts of the world. Even today here are areas where no rise has occurred in recent times and other areas where rise is considerably more than the average. Global warming then tops up the natural rise, for instance a rise of 10 inches might be 8 inches of natural rise plus 2 inches caused by global warming. It a wonderful, infinitely complicated, unpredictable thing called climate.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528512601000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100470058', u'in_reply_to': u'116696533', u'id': u'116765746', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Shouldn't a certain TT be coming on here now to attack you for overdoing the dark scenario? Oh well, I'll do his job for him. The outlet glaciers are without doubt losing ice and the land-based glaciers behind them accelerating, however these changes will come over time and are not abrupt. The glacier at Jakobshavn has been calving at its front since at least the turn of the 19th 20th century and worrying as this may be it is not a world wide problem. Other places you mentioned (particularly Antarctica) are more of a threat than ice loss from Greenland. 
What is becoming irreversible is the changes to weather patterns world wide. Increased meltwater from outlet glaciers seems to be affecting the ocean currents around Greenland, in particular the Labrador Current and the Gulf Stream. Shifting water currents work together with upper air currents and reinforce each other. This seems to be having knock-on effects in places as far inland as the Czech Republic. They are apparently suffering from a severe drought this year. This can only be explained by the combination of low precipitation and warm weather in the last winter and the current dry spring. How much such weather "events" are the result of shifts in upper air patterns, and ultimately, ice loss in the Arctic, is hard to determine. More and more climatologists are finding the "fingerprint" of global warming on local weather extremes.
We only know that the world's climate systems do not respect political borders. 
(Oh all right, I didn't do a good job as TT. Here you go: you are wrong, you are scaring off the very people we need to convince of the importance of the cryosphere. Strange and beautiful country.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528504474000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100470058', u'in_reply_to': u'116761604', u'id': u'116764853', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ronnewmexico', u'text': u'A fact but bares a bit of a addition.Local shore line issues may be affected by stream flow disruption. A thing like a particular reduction in flow of large streams (gulf stream perhaps) may result in a actual reduction in ocean level particular to that in a specific area. This depends in part on the geography of a specific area and the extend of increase or decrease of flow. Even at times the extend of interaction one flow with another.
While generally all oceans are rising we may be thinking a reduction in ocean level in one particular area says all is normal. But stream flow disruption can have effects which do produce a observed decrease in ocean level at shore at times., As well as a inordinate or beyond the norm increase in a local area.
The actual flows of deep water stream in the ocean are affected by things like salinity water temperature contrast and some other specifics. A increase and/or decrease may affect local weather and as well shore line increase or decrease. But these are local affects not speaking of a global trend.The deniers amongst us will almost certain point to this fact as a proof of lack of global warming. AS they point to a decrease in winter temperatures in areas like the Northeastern US as being that as well.Both can be a result of stream disruption and produce local affects which are not the norm.
This bares stating, as always those who deny will point to statistical data of a selective sorts pointing to this or that area, not seeing a increase in ocean level. True, but it is like pointing out a hundred or so new records to the down or colder side of temperatures globally as opposed to a thousand pointing to the upside.
So any article of this sort must include this specific.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528503537000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a thing like a particular reduction in flow of large streams', u'effect': u'a actual reduction in ocean level particular to that in a specific area'}], u'author_id': u'14139778', u'id': u'116764692', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ncdave', u'text': u'The claimed drastic accelerations in sea-level rise are obtained by splicing together data from different locations, which have different trends. In some cases they even splice together data from entirely different measurement methods, which (no surprise!) give different results. For example, here's a Hansen & Sato graph which splices mid-ocean satellite altimetry (starting in 1993), onto a graph of averaged coastal tide gauge measurements (which they cut off in 1993):
http://www.columbia.edu/~mhs119/SeaLevel/SL.1900-2018.png
If you don't splice together data from different locations and/or different measurement methods, the "acceleration" disappears. Here are a couple of particularly long, high quality, measurement records, from tectonically stable sites, with very little vertical land motion, and very typical trends, on opposite sides of the globe, showing sea-level juxtaposed with CO2 level:
http://sealevel.info/120-022_Wismar_and_1612340_Honolulu_vs_CO2_annot1.png
As you can see, the large increase in CO2 level caused no noticeable acceleration in sea-level rise. (BTW, if you don't know how to recognize "acceleration" (or its lack!) in a graph, this little primer should help.)
Every long, high-quality sea-level measurement record shows the same lack of acceleration since 1920s or before. Here are many more graphs (click on the thumbnails to see big versions & details about each site):
http://sealevel.info/MSL_global_thumbnails5.html
Sea level is rising in some places, and falling in others, because the global trend is so slow that in many places it is outpaced by vertical land motion. The global average rate of coastal sea-level rise from reliable measurements is only about 1½ mm/year (6 inches per century), with no significant acceleration in nine decades.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528447183000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the large increase in co2 level', u'effect': u'no noticeable acceleration in sea level rise'}], u'author_id': u'2496572', u'in_reply_to': u'116685411', u'id': u'116732477', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'reinhardpolley', u'text': u'Then do allow me to correct my error How laughable that you use cherry-picked tide-gauge data  from an unqualified denial blogger as "evidence", rather than real data compiled by real scientists and published in real scientific journals such as the PNAS...etc"FYI, I don't "pick studies which confirm prejudices", that's your MO, I pick studies that have undergone proper scrutiny and peer review by a reputable journal such as PNAS. That's why I'm not going to waste another second of my time even thinking about the unqualified non-science from either you or WattstheWeatherman. If you think you can debunk the real science performed by NAS , NASA etc stop polluting the Guardian comments section and write a paper and submit it and your "tools" to PNAS for publication..I won't hold my breath waiting.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528447095000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16020012', u'in_reply_to': u'116729620', u'id': u'116732422', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glennmr', u'text': u'First, there is insufficient data on hurricanes and other events to conclude causes from AGW. The data won’t be robust enough and red herrings posted are always meaningless. Maybe a hundred years from now when it won’t matter, the data will be there.
You are wrong on what Hansen projected in 1988 paper. The were no scenarios that projected 0.5c/decade surface air temp increases.
Scenario A assumed 1.5%/year increase in atmospheric CO2 concentration based on the keeling curve…not 1.5% increase in carbon emissions. 
Since the planet has warmed about 0.2 to 0.25C per decade, Hansen essentially nailed it within the error bars.And the graphs in this link are accurate:
http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/climate-model-projections-compared-to-observations 
The sea level rise has been on the high end of projections…as seen here: 
https://www.skepticalscience.com/sea-level-rise-predictions-intermediate.htm
And you arel not putting up what the forcing is causing the SATs to increase, ocean levels to increase, ocean temperatures to increase when the sun has been cooling for decades—the planet should not be warming at all since the modern max. the WMGHG forcing is +2.9W/m^2. So, unless you post up the natural forcing that is causing the warming, you are leaving out the science part.. Copying nonsense from anti-science blogs is still wrong. But don't the years 367,750 BC to 367,150 BC disprove your point?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528496469000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100470058', u'in_reply_to': u'116755847', u'id': u'116763229', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ncdave', u'text': u'glenmr asked, "which projections have failed"
Sharply rising temperatures, for one. Accelerated sea-level rise, for another. Increased extreme weather, for a third.
The raison d'être of the IPCC was the supposed threat of rapid, drastic, damaging, "greenhouse" warming. Hansen et al 1988 (published just before the IPCC was created) predicted that if GHG emissions rose 1.5%/year temperatures would rise 0.5°C/decade. (That was their "Scenario A.") Instead CO2 emissions rose nearly 2%/year, yet we only got about 1/4 as much warming as they predicted (at most 1/3, depending on whose numbers you use).
Sea-level vs. CO2 -- do you understand graphs?1. At two especially high-quality measurement sites, and2. Everywhere elseAs you can see, sea-level rise hasn't measurably accelerated in nine decades.
Extreme weather -- do you understand graphs?1. Hurricanes & tropical cyclones2. TornadoesAs you can see, hurricanes & tropical cyclones have no clear trend, and strong tornadoes have noticeably decreased.
The only really strong trend related to rising CO2 levels is agricultural productivity. It has nearly tripled since the 1960s, in part because of "CO2 fertilization."', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528446371000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'co2 fertilization', u'effect': u'it has nearly tripled since the 1960s'}], u'author_id': u'2496572', u'in_reply_to': u'116720397', u'id': u'116731966', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ncdave', u'text': u'GuyWarren, you are right to question the cherry-picked reporting about sea-level rise wherever it happens to be "slushing up," at the moment.
The academic literature is not immune, either. For example, do you remember the huge media splash about Sallenger's 2012 Nature paper, about a "hotspot" of accelerated sea-level rise along the U.S. Atlantic Coast, from Beaufort, NC north, especially at New York City?
It turns out that there was no sustained acceleration in rate of sea-level rise, only multidecadal fluctuations. The oceans are full of water, and they slowly SLOSH. So it's not surprising that if you pick short enough intervals and small enough regions you can find temporary localized increases and decreases. That's all Sallenger did.
Here's what sea-level has done at NYC since then:
http://sealevel.info/8518750_The_Battery_2010-2016.png
Some "hot spot," eh? ��
However, Guy, you are mistaken in your belief that "sea level rises were much faster 150 years ago before AGW." We have actual measurement records extending that far back (including New York City), and they do not show that. Some of them show a linear trend, and some show a very slight acceleration, but none that I am aware of show sea-level rise greatly decelerating.
The largest acceleration seen in a long, high quality measurement record is from Brest, France (PSMSL gauge #1), but it does not support the notion that CO2 drives sea-level rise.
Between 1850 and 1930 CO2 levels rose less than 8%. That was accompanied by a slight but measurable acceleration in sea-level rise, in some places. The acceleration was most apparent at Brest, where sea-level rose at 0 (zero) mm/yr in the 1800s, but 1.5 mm/yr (6"/century) since then.
Since 1930 CO2 levels have risen another 32%. That 4× greater increase in CO2 forcing was accompanied by no measurable acceleration in sea-level rise.
Arguments that fossil fuel use must be curbed to reduce sea-level rise are based on superstition, not science.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528444523000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2496572', u'in_reply_to': u'116690695', u'id': u'116731074', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'This thread may be blessed by the presence of a WUWT Doctor of Internet Science.

See also https://blog.hotwhopper.com/2016/04/dave-burton-wants-to-level-seas-at-wuwt.html', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528494341000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'116759832', u'id': u'116762786', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ncdave', u'text': u'glenmr asked, "the cause of sea level rise naturally is???"
It is affected by many factors, but we know with certainty that CO2 is not one of them, or at least that it is not an important one. We know that fact because, globally, sea-level is rising no faster now, with CO2 levels above 400 ppmv, than it was nine decades or more ago, with CO2 levels below 310 ppmv.
Here are a couple of particularly long, high quality, measurement records, from tectonically stable sites, with very little vertical land motion, and very typical trends, on opposite sides of the globe, showing sea-level juxtaposed with CO2 level:
http://sealevel.info/120-022_Wismar_and_1612340_Honolulu_vs_CO2_annot1.png
As you can see, the large increase in CO2 level caused no noticeable acceleration in sea-level rise. (BTW, if you don't know how to recognize "acceleration" (or its lack!) in a graph, this little primer should help.)
Every long, high-quality sea-level measurement record shows the same lack of acceleration since 1920s or before. Here are many more graphs (click on the thumbnails to see big versions & details about each site):
http://sealevel.info/MSL_global_thumbnails5.html
Sea level is rising in some places, and falling in others, because the global trend is so slow that in many places it is outpaced by vertical land motion. The global average rate of coastal sea-level rise from reliable measurements is only about 1½ mm/year (6 inches per century), with no significant acceleration in nine decades.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528442916000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2496572', u'in_reply_to': u'116709633', u'id': u'116730434', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our
