Have we reached peak denial?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528442150000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11150889', u'in_reply_to': u'116726265', u'id': u'116730160', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ncdave', u'text': u'Erik Frederiksen, the GRACE-based studies you're relying upon are not the only measurements from which ice mass estimates can be deduced. The truth is that the various studies cannot even agree about whether Antarctica is gaining or losing ice.
Based on CryoSat, McMillan (2014) found Antarctica is losing 79 to 241 Gt/yr of ice, though that was based on only 3 years of data.
Based on GRACE, Shepherd (2012) concluded that Antarctica ice mass change since 1992 has averaged -71 ±83 Gt/yr, which means they couldn't tell whether it's actually gaining or losing ice mass.
Based on ICESat and ERS, Zwally et al (2015) found that Antarctica is GAINING ice (albeit at a glacially show rate).
Here's an earlier (2012) video of NASA's Jay Zwally discussing ERS & ICESat measurements:
https://vimeo.com/46429608
What's more, 130 Gt of ice loss per year is completely negligible.
That amount of ice loss would cause only 1.4 inches of sea-level rise per CENTURY.
What's more, describing apparent fluctuations in ice mass flux as a constant acceleration ("44Gt/y2") is nonsense. The reality is that GHG forcings have been increasing substantially for 2/3 of a century, and at nearly the current rate for about forty years, but if all that CO2 and those other GHGs have had any effect on ice sheet mass flux the effect has been too tiny to detect in sea-level trends, because sea-level rise hasn't measurably accelerated in nine decades.
Sea-level is rising no faster now than it was when CO2 levels were 100 ppmv lower. Every long, high-quality sea-level measurement record shows same lack of acceleration since 1920s or before. Here are some graphs (click on the thumbnails to see big versions & details about each site):
http://sealevel.info/MSL_global_thumbnails5.html
Here are a couple of particularly long, high quality, measurement records, from tectonically stable sites, with very little vertical land motion, and very typical trends, on opposite sides of the globe, showing sea-level juxtaposed with CO2 level:
http://sealevel.info/120-022_Wismar_and_1612340_Honolulu_vs_CO2_annot1.png
As you can see, the large increase in CO2 level caused no noticeable acceleration in sea-level rise. (BTW, if you don't know how to recognize "acceleration" (or its lack!) in a graph, this little primer should help.)
What's more, GRACE (may it Rest In Peace) didn't even actually measure ice. It measured only gravity. When magma shifts as the Earth's crust rises or sinks, perhaps due to changes in the loads upon it, if affects the Earth's gravity field just like ice accumulating or diminishing does. GRACE can't tell the difference. 
So the GRACE-based studies must adjust their gravity measurements to account for GIA. Unfortunately, GIA/PGR is not reliably measurable, especially beneath ice sheets. So they use model-derived estimates of what they think GIA probably should be.
Of course, the altimetry-based studies are also affected by GIA, but much less so than GRACE, because rock is nearly 3x as dense as ice. So vertical land motion affects gravity readings much more than it affects altimetry readings, and errors estimating GIA corrupt GRACE-based studies 3x as much as they corrupt altimetry-based studies. (OTOH, the altimeters also have challenges due to varying snow and ice densities, which don't affect GRACE.)
And, guess what? It is my understanding that GRACE did not actually measure a declining Antarctic gravity field, from diminishing ice mass. It actually measured a (slightly) increasing gravity field, so all of the ice mass loss "measured" by GRACE was actually due to the calculated GIA adjustments. ("It's models all the way down.")', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528441687000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that amount of ice loss', u'effect': u'only 1.4 inches of sea level rise'}, {u'cause': u"sea level rise has n't measurably accelerated in nine decades", u'effect': u'if all that co2 and those other ghgs have had any effect on ice sheet mass flux the effect has been too tiny to detect in sea level trends'}, {u'cause': u'changes in the loads upon it', u'effect': u"when magma shifts as the earth 's crust rises or sinks"}, {u'cause': u'rock is nearly 3x as dense as ice', u'effect': u'of course the altimetry based studies are also affected by gia but much less so than grace'}, {u'cause': u"varying snow and ice densities which do n't affect grace", u'effect': u'challenges'}, {u'cause': u'the calculated gia adjustments', u'effect': u'all of the ice mass loss measured was actually'}], u'author_id': u'2496572', u'in_reply_to': u'116728619', u'id': u'116730029', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Anthony's our resident self contradictory dopey denier.

All the best.', u'recommendation_count': u'17', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528489985000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"you should n't add together the results of all the globe 's tidal gauges and satellites", u'effect': u'that there is a fall in gmslr'}], u'author_id': u'3917113', u'in_reply_to': u'116701283', u'id': u'116761696', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ncdave', u'text': u'reinhardpolley, those 159 sea-level (SL) graphs are from tide-gauges (mostly GLOSS-LTT). They aren't "satellite data," and they're not "cherry-picked."
They aren't from an "unqualified denial blogger," either. The graphs are from NOAA & PSMSL data, using tools on my sealevel.info site. The tools & data are all free and publicly available, for anyone to use.
As for Nerem et al, 2018, it sounds like you haven't read it. They claimed to have found "acceleration" in the satellite altimetry SL data. But the "acceleration" wasn't an increase in the rate of sea-level rise (SLR). Instead, it was created by slowing the rate of SLR "measured" by Topex-Poseidon in the distant past (pre-2003), thereby creating appearance of acceleration when early Topex data is compared to newer data (though the new Jason-3 measurements show little SLR, so far).
(That drastic revision of Topex measurements also lowered the average rate from the previously reported 3.4 mm/yr to 3.1 mm/yr.) 
What such revisions prove is how malleable and unreliable satellite altimetry "measurements" of SL are, compared to coastal data. Trustworthy measurements don't require revision and correction long after they've been collected!
Satellite altimetry data has many problems. Most obviously, satellites measure SL in the wrong place. They can't measure SL at the coasts, where it matters.
Also, satellite measurement records are very short. Their longest single-instrument record is only about a decade. Some coastal measurement records are over 1.5 centuries long!
One of the major groups working with satellite altimetry is at the University of Colorado. Look how changes in how they process and adjust the data increased the rate of SLR they report (h/t Steve Case):
http://sealevel.info/U_CO_SLR_rel2_vs_rel1p2_SteveCase.png
That's 2 dramatically different interpretations of the same measurement data by the same U.S. group from the same satellite radar altimeters! If it doesn't smell fishy to you, you need to have your nose examined.
Here's an even more dramatic example, from Europe. Envisat measured sea-level by satellite altimetry for ten years. Here are 2 different interpretations of the same measurement data by the same European group from the same satellite:
http://sealevel.info/2061wtl.jpg
The small graph is the original version, showing 0.76 mm/yr (and it would have been even less if they hadn't omitted the 1st 18 months of data).
The large one is the "corrected" version, showing 2.33 mm/yr SLR.
After 10 years of collecting and reporting data they discovered a problem, the correction of which approximately tripled "measured" rate of SLR!
So why is satellite altimetry data so poor?
There are many issues, but a major one is difficulty determining exactly where the satellites are, and how their orbits change, with sufficient accuracy. Unlike tide gauges, satellites aren't referenced to geodetic markers.
In 2011 NASA proposed a new satellite mission called the Geodetic Reference Antenna in SPace (GRASP), to address that problem. The proposal and implications for measuring sea-level were discussed here. The Europeans are apparently considering a similar mission (E-GRASP). But none of those proposed missions have flown.
Here is a discussion of the challenges of measuring sea-level via satellite altimetry:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1gmW9GEUYvA#t=17m37s
So, given the high quality and long duration of coastal measurements, and the low quality and short duration of the satellite measurements, why would anyone ignore the former in favor of the latter? That's not just cherry-picking, it's picking the rotten, wormy cherries!
When people do that it's a sign of bias: picking studies which confirm their prejudices, and ignoring contrary evidence. You see the same sort of behavior when people cite GRACE studies and ignore ICESat & ERS, w/r/t Antarctica ice mass balance.
That sort of behavior is useful -- for identifying scientific work you shouldn't trust.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528440025000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2496572', u'in_reply_to': u'116727395', u'id': u'116729620', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'I'd like citations to papers that make those predictions, if you have them.
We need to be careful about apocalyptic predictions.
A paper worth looking at is -
"A human-induced hothouse climate?" - Kidder & Worsley, 2011
Here's a key quote from the Conclusions:
"The likely cool greenhouse in which about half of Antarctica is still ice-covered means devastation from the tens of meters sea level is likely to rise (e.g., Ward, 2010), and poleward shifting of warm climate belts."
So the appropriate term for what's likely to happen is a 'cool greenhouse', which sounds harmless, but is not.
It's a very interesting paper.
How quickly?
Another quote:
"a cool greenhouse seems imminent within perhaps a century or two."
However, although those conditions could set in within that time, the process of melting half of the ice on Antarctica would take around 1000 years.
Meanwhile the
"poleward shifting of warm climate belts."
means that the equatorial regions will become increasingly inhospitable - but over time, not in a couple of years.
A possible comparison is the PETM, around 56 million years
The current rate of rise in CO2 is faster than during the Palaeocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum.
The fossil record in rocks formed around the equator during the PETM is really poor, and that's an indication that life was extremely stressed.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528489937000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'116738177', u'id': u'116761673', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'If it was subsidence and development - exactly how does that cause sea-level to go up on the planet as a total? 
For Norwegians this is easy - because we grow up being explained about the difference between eustatic and isostatic effects. 
The isostatic effect simply can not be used by Norwegians as an argument because we live where we live and got it explained when we are ten years old - and we make sure kids understand basic science so we can understand geology - and find oil (if you like) 
Anyone in Norway living on the coast less than 100 meters above the sea-level will conclude that ocean sea-level must have fallen since the last ice-age. 
Then we learnt that all this ice that covered us obviously melted into the ocean. Making us ponder if the volume of the ocean changed much. Realizing that it does not make not much sense from pure logic. So we learn that the mantel our very old continual plate float on acts like a rubber duck with weight on top - (or a fishing boat laden with fish sitting low in the water and that the boat itself does not care much if the tub is low or high)
And like this, me, in the 70s starting school started to learn logic. Figuring out isostacy and eustacy components. 
Not to learn about AGW - but to learn logic. 
2 decades later I was at University - learning about bulging. Yes - the volume do change when the rubber duck of an ice-sheet experience mass shifting below.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528489764000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'sea level to go up on the planet as a total'}, {u'cause': u'we grow up being explained about the difference between eustatic and isostatic effects', u'effect': u'for norwegians this is easy'}, {u'cause': u'we live where we live and got it explained when we are ten years old', u'effect': u'the isostatic effect simply can not be used by norwegians as an argument and we make sure kids understand basic science so we can understand geology'}], u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'116727611', u'id': u'116761604', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Sea level rises for a reason. Deniers use the word "natural" instead of writing either "magic" or, and what they really mean "anything but CO2".', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528438835000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'116727983', u'id': u'116729424', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'I could not agree more. That we came up with the name of our own planet (Earth) is based on terrible human ignorance. This planet should be called "water". 
Not just because most of the Earth surface is covered in water. But because our planet happily exchange water through its solid, gaseous and liquid state at once. Continously exchanging these states. 
We live on "planet water" to the extent that fucking with CO2 (not a very strong climate gass) makes "planet water" to double the sensitivity just by the little water we have inside the atmosphere. And after that we notice that water in white form react too - and lower the albedo. 
Many people think that water (such as the Gulfstream - to use a popular word for the concept) operate to heat North Western Europe. This is of course wrong - it exist to cool down Equator. People are always talking about fears of the Gulfstream shutting down and making us cold. Here is something to ponder - if the water cooling system of the planet breaks down and the tropics contain all the heat down where it is collected facing the heat source (the sun) - that is a problem too - called overheating.

Don't be intentionally obtuse.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528436850000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'116711679', u'id': u'116729119', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ncdave', u'text': u'DennisHorne, I realize that the physics is not intuitive for someone who hasn't studied it. But ask any physicist: gravity balances mass, not volume. That's why displacement is measured in units of mass, not volume, and why a floating iceberg protrudes above the surrounding ocean.
http://burtonsys.com/climate/iceberg_1521870c_annotated.jpg
So if, for example, there's a warm area in the middle of the Indian Ocean, it will cause the water there to "bulge up" in place, affecting satellite altimetry measurements of sea-level. But the water in that "bump" doesn't "run downhill" and affect sea-level elsewhere.
Well, more precisely, the water at the surface which "runs downhill" is exactly balanced by water at depth which flows in the opposite direction, to keep the masses equal. So there's no net lateral flow, and no effect on sea-level at distant shores. Only where the water temperature actually rises is its depth affected.
Such "thermosteric sea-level rise" affects satellite altimeters, because they measure sea-level in the open ocean. But it doesn't affect sea-level far away, at the coasts, where sea-level actually matters, and where tide gauges measure it.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528436072000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u'the water there'}, {u'cause': u'they measure sea level', u'effect': u'such thermosteric sea level rise affects satellite altimeters'}], u'author_id': u'2496572', u'in_reply_to': u'116727272', u'id': u'116728992', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'funkymentalist', u'text': u'BQSTART

It takes time for temperature and sea level to equilibrate with CO2 levels and we could blow much further off that graph.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528476239000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'116753763', u'id': u'116755847', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'We’ve waited so long now to act that there are parts of the system that may already be out of our hands. Some of those parts are related to the ocean. Because we know that we’ve already put a lot of heat content into the ocean. 
In the case of the Antarctic Ice Sheet, regarding the marine-based ice which is very sensitive to ocean temperatures—West Antarctica 3.3m, East Antarctica 19m—we are likely to end up being committed to some response of the ice sheet to the heat that has already gone into the ocean. And Greenland has around 3m of sea level rise equivalent of marine-based ice as well.
This marine-based ice has its feet in a warming ocean and ocean temperature likely controls Antarctic Ice Sheet mass, according to the glaciologist Richard Alley (57m sea level rise equivalent of ice).
It's -50 degrees C on parts of Antarctica, warm it up to -45 and who cares? But it is at the melting point at the coast where the floating and thinning ice shelves provide less and less friction constraining ice sheet flow.
An increase of just 1 degree C destroyed the ice shelf constraining the flow of the Jakobshavn Isbræ Glacier on Greenland and such an increase is a big insult to an ice shelf almost anywhere on the planet.
The Antarctic Peninsula has lost 8-10 ice shelves over the last 25-30 years. When the Larsen B ice shelf broke up there over a 5 week period in 2002 the glaciers behind sped up by a factor of 6 to 8 and are still flowing at that accelerated rate today because the cork was removed.
If we sped up all of Antarctica’s glaciers by a factor of 6.5 we’d have 4m per century sea level rise, roughly what occurred for four centuries 14,600 years ago.
This is the reality we’ve created for ourselves; a shoreline which will keep moving inland for millennia.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528435605000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the cork was removed', u'effect': u'are still flowing at that accelerated rate today'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'116728922', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"Yes, the Earth has slowly warmed for some time."
For the six thousand years leading up to the Industrial Revolution the pattern was slow cooling at an average rate of about 0.2 degrees C per millennium. There were ups and downs due to changes in ocean currents and solar output, but at most those changes were around 0.1 degree C per century and after five or six hundred years the average global temps returned to the cooling trend. (Graph of the last 20,000 years of global temperature) 
In the last hundred years we have seen global temperatures climb just over a full degree C with the majority of that increase in the last forty years. Solar out put has actually been declining slightly during those last forty years. 
"Sea levels have risen slowly for quite a while also"
Looking at this graph of post glacial sea level rise we can see that sea levels have been remarkably stable for the last 6000 years, which is why we still have London although it was founded 2000 years ago.
But the most important line in the world, the shoreline, is starting to change noticeably for the first time in recorded human history.
In 2014 two independent teams of scientists reported that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is likely retreating irreversibly. 1
That’s 3.3m of sea level rise equivalent of ice (over 4m in the North which has a more heavily populated coast).
The rate of acceleration of ice sheet mass loss is around 44Gt/y2 now. If it continued at that rate we’d get 78cm from that source by 2100. Throw in mountain glaciers and thermal expansion, 20-30cm, and you get around a meter.
But with a warming world will that rate remain the same? Glaciologists are worried that it could increase substantially when the West Antarctic starts to let go.
1. Widespread, rapid grounding line retreat of Pine Island, Thwaites, Smith, and Kohler glaciers, West Antarctica, from 1992 to 2011http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014GL060140/abstract

“Several areas of earth science require knowledge of the fluctuations in sea level and ice volume through glacial cycles. From ∼1,000 observations of sea level, allowing for isostatic and tectonic contributions, we have quantified the rise and fall in global ocean and ice volumes for the past 35,000 years. Of particular note is that during the ∼6,000 y up to the start of the recent rise ∼100−150 y ago, there is no evidence for global oscillations in sea level on time scales exceeding ∼200 y duration or 15−20 cm amplitude.”

Some sources quote much higher rates, sometimes as high as 3.4 mm/yr (13 inches per century), based on satellite altimetry measurements of sea-level. But using satellite altimetry to estimate global average sea-level change, rather than using coastal sea-level measurements from tide gauges, is a mistake. 
Most fundamentally, click for larger version satellite altimeters measure the wrong thing. Their measurements are distorted by "sea-level rise" caused by thermal expansion when the upper layer of the ocean warms. But that is a strictly local effect, which doesn't affect the quantity of water in the oceans, and doesn't affect sea-level elsewhere (e.g., at the coasts).
BQEND
Schoolboy howler.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528416331000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'thermal expansion', u'effect': u'sea level rise when the upper layer of the ocean warms'}], u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'116726433', u'id': u'116727272', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ncdave', u'text': u'Louisiana's inundation problems are anthropogenic, but they aren't climate-related.
Louisiana's high local rates of sea-level rise are due to subsidence, not global sea-level rise. It is mostly a consequence of taming the Mighty Mississippi.
For many millennia Old Man River had been dumping silt into the Delta, mostly during floods, and the Earth's crust is sinking under the burden of that silt. Now, thanks to the flood control dams, the river no longer deposits much silt in the Delta, but the Earth is continuing to sink. The result is very high rates of local sea-level rise. It is anthropogenic, but it isn't climate-related, and CO2 has nothing at all to do with it, and curbing CO2 emissions would do Louisiana no good at all..
Sea level is rising in some places, and falling in others, because the global trend is so slow that in many places it is outpaced by vertical land motion. The global average rate of coastal sea-level rise from reliable measurements is only about 1½ mm/year (6"/century), with no significant acceleration in nine decades.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528411875000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'subsidence not global sea level rise', u'effect': u"louisiana 's high local rates of sea level rise are"}, {u'cause': u'the global trend is so slow that in many places it is outpaced by vertical land motion', u'effect': u'falling in others'}], u'author_id': u'2496572', u'in_reply_to': u'116698613', u'id': u'116726433', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ncdave', u'text': u'In the United States, the places where flooding is increasing in frequency are mostly where subsidence is causing local sea-level rise unrelated to the global trend, and where development is increasing impervious surface coverage and storm runoff, and in some cases where raised roadbeds create "dikes" that impede stormwater drainage.
For instance, Galveston Island is mostly built upon silt, dredged and pumped from Galveston Harbor, and retained by its famous seawall -- and that fill dirt is still sinking, a century after it was pumped onto the island. The story of Galveston and its seawall is fascinating, but anyone who cites Galveston's flooding as an example of the consequences of climate change doesn't know what he's talking about:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6DexSKxY2Nc
"Serious global climate change concerns" have nothing to do with it. That's a red herring. Sea-level is rising no faster now than it was nine decades ago, when CO2 levels were 100 ppmv lower, and flood-triggering storms are not detectably correlated with rising CO2 levels, either.
All that CO2 has not detectably affected sea-level trends. Every long, high-quality sea-level measurement record shows same lack of acceleration since 1920s or before:

description: Shoreline communities may be inundated in the next two years as ocean levels rise amid serious climate change concerns
og_fields.og:description: Shoreline communities may be inundated in the next two years as ocean levels rise amid serious climate change concerns
og_fields.og:title: Flooding from high tides has doubled in the US in just 30 years
text:
The frequency of coastal flooding from high tides has doubled in the US in just 30 years, with communities near shorelines warned that the next two years are set to be punctuated by particularly severe inundations, as ocean levels continue to rise amid serious global climate change concerns.
Last year there was an average of six flooding days per area across 98 coastal areas monitored by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (Noaa) – an all-time record. More than a quarter of these locations tied or broke their records for high tide flood days, the federal agency states in a new report.
Known as “sunny day flooding”, these events swamp streets and homes with water simply from the incoming tide, without the aid of a storm. Noaa said that in 2017 areas across the US north-east and Gulf of Mexico were worst hit, with Boston, Massachusetts, and Atlantic City, New Jersey, both experiencing 22 days of flooding, while Galveston, in Texas, was soaked on 18 different days.
Noaa warned that cyclical climatic conditions during 2018 and 2019 “may result in higher than expected flood frequencies” in around half of the coastal sites it measures. 
The longer-term trend is even more certain, Noaa said, with melting glaciers, thermal expansion of sea water and altered ocean currents pushing the sea level steadily higher and causing further floods. 
“Breaking of annual flood records is to be expected next year and for decades to come as sea levels rise, and likely at an accelerated rate,” the report states. “Though year-to-year and regional variability exists, the underlying trend is quite clear: due to sea level rise, the national average frequency of high tide flooding is double what it was 30 years ago.”
The Noaa report is “comprehensive” and “clearly illustrates the increasing problems along our coastlines”, said Ben Horton, a sea level rise expert at Rutgers University. “There is flooding on all our coastlines, places where people live and work. There needs to be a national response to that.” 
Last year was marked by three high-profile hurricanes that pummelled the US, triggering flooding that resulted in dozens of deaths and billions of dollars in damage. Scientists have found that warming temperatures, driven by human activity, is making hurricanes stronger, but it is also exacerbating more chronic nuisance flooding events by pushing up the level of the ocean.
“There’s a clear upwards trend of this type of flooding,” said Andrea Dutton, a geologist at the University of Florida. “Extreme events like hurricanes may be the breaking point but this sort of frequent flooding is the taste of what is coming in the future on a permanent basis. We need to rethink our relationship with the coastline because it’s going to be retreating for the foreseeable future.”
Dutton said that south Florida, where weather forecasts in some places now come with tidal warnings, and fish are a regular sight on flooded roads, is particularly vulnerable. The low-lying region sits on porous limestone, which pushes up floodwater from underground, and many communities are unable to easily retreat because they back on to the Everglades wetlands.
“They used to get just one day a year of tidal flooding, now it’s two months of it in the fall,” she said. “Engineering can help delay things but ultimately the oceans will win. We are going to have to live with the water.”
Globally, the seas have risen by an average of nearly three inches since 1992. Parts of the US coastline are unusually prone, with Noaa forecasting last year that the oceans could swell by more than eight feet by 2100. 
Despite the risk posed to the US by sea level rise and flooding events, there is no national plan to deal with the issue, with much of the adaption work left to states and counties. The Trump administration has rescinded previous rules to build federally funded infrastructure with climate change in mind and has sought to reverse various measures aimed at taming global warming.
“We need to take this report as a warning to prepare ourselves, or we will just sit around and wait for disaster to happen,” Dutton said.

description: Agriculture minister says climate is changing and Australia must ‘use the best science available’
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: Agriculture minister says climate is changing and Australia must ‘use the best science available’
og_fields.og:title: Move to renewables a 'good thing', Nationals' David Littleproud says
text:
The agriculture minister, David Littleproud, says the climate is changing and the transition in the energy market – with renewables displacing traditional power generation sources – is “exciting, not only for the environment but for the hip pocket”.
In an interview with Guardian Australia, the Queensland National said the climate had been changing “since we first tilled the soil in Australia” and he does not care whether the change is due to human activity or not.
While some colleagues in the National party have long queried whether humans are contributing to global warming, and have been openly hostile to the advance of renewable energy, Littleproud said: “I’m not losing any sleep on that, whether you want to prove it is manmade or not – I want to be pragmatic.
• Sign up to receive the top stories in Australia every day at noon
“The climate has been changing since we first tilled the soil in Australia and the reality is farmers have been adapting to it,” the agriculture minister said. “Farmers are always at the cutting edge of science and technology, and they’ve been adapting since we first tilled the soil here.
“I believe the climate is changing. Whether it is manmade or not, I don’t really care. The reality is we are seeing disruption, particularly with renewables, and we are going to see cleaner air. I try not to live in cities, you do feel the effects ... so it’s a good thing that renewables are coming on.
“In fact, in my own electorate [of Maranoa in south-west Queensland] I’ve got all of the above. I’m about to have one of the largest solar farms in the southern hemisphere, one of the biggest wind farms in the southern hemisphere. I’ve got geothermal and I’ve got four coal-fired power stations. Two of those are super critical.
“The disruption that’s happening with the technology, moving towards renewable energy, particularly in storage for base load, is exciting. I think it is a good thing.”
While some government colleagues have championed prolonging the life of coal-fired power plants, Littleproud said economics rather than a culture war would ultimately determine Australia’s future energy mix. “Economics will win out in the end and if base load power can be stored in particular, that’s an exciting thing for the environment and everyone’s hip pocket.”
Littleproud has been on the road for much of the week with the prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, visiting drought-affected regions of New South Wales and Queensland.
The south-east of Australia this year has experienced record high temperatures during an unseasonably dry and hot autumn, prompting fire bans and warnings from authorities.
In its latest winter outlook, the Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting warmer and drier-than-average conditions across large parts of the country. It suggests winter rainfall is likely to be below average for NSW, South Australia, northern Victoria and western parts of Western Australia.
Turnbull this week said there was “no doubt that our climate is getting warmer”. He said the farming community needed to concentrate on becoming more resilient and focus on adaptation to a climate that was getting warmer and drier.
Littleproud said there was a place for both mitigation strategies to try and reduce the most damaging impacts of climate change, and also for adaptation. 
“No matter whether you mitigate or adapt, the climate is going to change and we’ve got to move with it,” he said. “You have to use the best science available at the time – you mitigate as best you can ... listen to the scientific evidence, because this should be predicated on science not emotion. 
“If there are mitigation efforts to lessen the impact, then we should explore those, but we have to continue to adapt as we have since we first inhabited Australia.”
He said he was currently working with state counterparts in the agriculture portfolio to develop “a national strategy around climate change adaptation”, which would include better collaboration across state borders, more research and development, including developing more drought-resistant grains and fibres, and looking at the genetics of livestock, and “understanding the weather better”.
Asked whether some Australian farmers were hanging on in areas made unviable for agricultural production because of the impact of climate change, Littleproud said: “I think ultimately the market and economics determine that.
“I honestly believe, having been a bank manager that sat around farmers’ kitchen tables, the greatest custodians of the land are farmers because their profit and loss is intrinsically tied to the health of their land. They don’t make a quid unless their environment and their farming is at its best.”
He said farmers in drier areas were deploying active strategies, like reducing their stocking densities, and some farmers he had met in regional Queensland this week were also engaged with traditional owners about land management. 
“They’ve learned how to manage that land, in some ways learning from how Indigenous Australians manage the land and techniques they’ve used,” he said.
Asked whether he accepted that agriculture and transport industries had to reduce their emissions to ensure Australia met its commitments under the Paris agreement, Littleproud said emissions reduction had to be “responsible”.
I think we are already reducing emissions
The latest official emissions data shows pollution increased by 1.5% in the year to December 2017. Australia’s emissions levels are now higher than they were in 2012 and have climbed by 3.6% since the carbon price was repealed in 2014.
Emissions are increasing in most sectors of the economy – in waste, agriculture and transport. Only one sector of the economy has recorded a decrease – the electricity sector – because ageing coal-fired power plants have exited the system, and new renewables projects are coming on stream.
“We’ve still got to be able to reduce the bills,” Littleproud said. “We’ve got to make sure the transition is done with people being able to turn their heaters on, and farmers turning their pumps on.
“I think we are already reducing emissions. We’ve made a commitment under the Paris agreement and we are moving towards that in a sensible and methodical way.
“As disruption happens in the technology space, [emissions reduction] will increase. In my own electorate, people are self-sustaining through solar. The reality is that type of disruption is happening and that is an exciting thing not only for the environment, but for the hip pocket.”

the UK government's determination to go against the grain

The UK govt is going with the grain, not against the grain. Contrary to the thrust of this misleading article, most developed & developing countries are planning to use nuclear power. The anti-nuclear countries are the tiny, "lonely club".
BQSTART
- *For 40 years of electricity generation (50 at the very most)
BQEND
All the new reactors have a design life of 60 years and it is common for this to be extended by 20 years. Reactors in the US have been extended to 80 years and may well go to 100.
BQSTART
why do we need to go to the trouble of creating and controlling a nuclear fission reaction just to heat water?
BQEND
Because it is often the cheapest way to heat the water (p4-5); and it is definitely the cleanest way (look at the data).
The fact is that in a decarbonisation solution, nuclear power results in lower environmental impacts compared to a solution using renewables alone:
* Nuclear power in low-carbon scenarios decreases costs and environmental impacts.
Note the analysis shows that nuclear is low carbon; but furthermore it shows it has lower environmental impacts than solar and wind for other aspects such as marine ecotoxicity and ozone layer depletion. It is simply the best environmental solution in a low-carbon scenario.
The whole point of about storing the waste is that is what makes nuclear power cleaner than other options. Only the nuclear industry stores its waste, with no intention that it will ever pollute the environment. Only the nuclear industry can do this, because only nuclear power has such a small waste stream. Other industries, including solar, discharge more waste and cause more harm. Characterising waste storage as a "problem" is churlish. It is the solution.
BQSTART
Nevertheless don't get me wrong ; overall I can accept the arguments for UK constructing a couple of new nuclear power stations to take us through a period of transition,
BQEND
That would be crazy. The first couple of plants will be the most expensive. The route to generating cheap nuclear power is via serial building of many reactors using identical designs. That is how France and South Korea achieved their low costs, and that is how China is doing it now.

The real question is when will Hinkley actually be running?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528712475000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'116806956', u'id': u'116837653', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TheSnickeringHound', u'text': u'Wow, an amazing little collective of pro-nuclear commenters here! Well, despite the UK government's determination to go against the grain and sign us up for another 150-odd years* of an electricity generation source that was devised in the mid 20th century, and everything that goes with it, I'm afraid you folks remain in the minority, albeit a noisy one. Besides, with the government's intransigence on this issue, you've got nothing to worry about! So no real need to do the rounds on fora such as these and try and shout the likes of me down, backed up by some lovely complex-looking statistics. 
Even more reason not to bother when you consider the following points:- *For 40 years of electricity generation (50 at the very most) a nuclear power station now takes a minimum of 10 years to construct and bring online, best case scenario (let's not even go there with Olkiluoto and Flamanville), then another roughly 100 years to completely decommission.- It should always be remembered that Nuclear power is basically just about heating some water to generate steam which then turns some turbines ; why do we need to go to the trouble of creating and controlling a nuclear fission reaction just to heat water? Given the by-products this generates, and the amount of investment and time required to construct vessels capable of containing the reaction, and the amount of earthwork required for a power station site, this seems like an awful lot of trouble.- Nuclear power plant contruction equals guaranteed cost overruns and delays. It seems that Hinkley Point has been smart about announcing these as early as possible to head off later controversy, but I'll be surprised if there isn't at least a significant delay announced in the next few years. I think they're currently announcing 2027 for the start of electricity generation. - Ditto for site decommissioning - cost overruns and underestimation of the time required are guaranteed.- There is still no confirmed long term solution in sight for the storage of the radioactive waste generated. This only serves to underline one of the major problems surrounding nuclear energy - the whole concept has been underlined by a headlong rush to get it up and running as soon as possible, without worrying about the future. It basically embodies our species' inability to look beyond our own little, finite lives (which to an extent I can of course sympathise with ;-) ) and, less forgiveably, think about the consequences for our future generations.- I'd also love to see some real studies conducted on the real, overall carbon footprint of nuclear power, including the amount of CO2 generated by the contruction of a site (right down to how much CO2 was produced in the manufacture of the materials required for the site contruction, in the site supply chain etc etc), and the the dismantling and decommissing processes, and on the amount of electricity a nuclear site consumes annually. Perhaps this has already been done, in which case I suspect you might take the opportunity to correct me...
Nevertheless don't get me wrong ; overall I can accept the arguments for UK constructing a couple of new nuclear power stations to take us through a period of transition, especially given our over reliance on gas for electricity generation, but the current number planned is too high and investment, subsidies etc should be redirected towards expanding and improving on all forms of renewable energy.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528712461000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11530026', u'id': u'116837644', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Joff', u'text': u'Nuclear spent fuel is really not a significant technical problem, despite the years of anti-nuclear attempts to make it so. 
It poses a "problem" roughly comparable to a broken bicycle at the bottom of a large garden. It might be dangerous for someone careless to play around it, but otherwise it's not going to harm anyone and over a longer timeframe it will cease to be a problem anyway, but it's probably better that it gets cleared up eventually. Maybe some parts of it can be reused, if anyone is so inclined.
Spent fuel casks are more permanent and far harder to break than most modern buildings. The chances are they could contain the waste safely for the entirety of its significantly hazardous period, but recasking and burial of the material at some point in the future would be other straightforward options.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528644297000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1339001', u'id': u'116815348', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'BQSTART

You are astutely avoiding quantifying how much storage that would get you.
Storage via batteries produces electricity at around $200/MWh-$300/MWh. It would need to be subsidised at around $120/MWh to $220/MWh to bring it down to market price. Whereas you have demonstrated Wylfa's subsidy is a fraction of that.
So you might begin to have a point if we only needed to store 10% of the electricity, and could reliably cycle it, fully, every day. But that is not the case if you want a complete solution. It is only viable for a small part of the solution (the expensive peaking part).
The point is that wylfa is good at providing continuous baseload. Storage is good at providing sporadic peaks, but is really very, very expensive for providing continuous baseload. They simply don't compete in the same space. We need both.
Storage will replace gas peakers, not nuclear baseload in the UK.

BQENDGermany's (fake) Energiewende is a mirage, it doesn't even work when supported by its neighbours.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528641140000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2427556', u'in_reply_to': u'116809616', u'id': u'116814050', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ColinG', u'text': u'Those US projects do not really provide a relevant cost comparison.
Firstly, wind and solar in the US are cheaper than the UK.
Secondly, they are very generously subsidised as well as being cheaper, so the contract prices are artificially low.
Thirdly, the amount of storage in those projects is relatively small - not enough to provide year-round baseload. They would need much more storage (and hence much more cost) to provide year-round baseload in the UK.
Fourthly, the UK has much higher seasonal variation between summer and winter, so it would need 5-10 times as much storage to cover the winter. And also the UK's wind production varies by 50% from year to year - so that would need long-term storage of months/years rather than hours to provide consistent baseload.
If you pick apart the details, and look simply at the unsubsidised cost of battery storage, it turns out that the electricity via batteries costs $200-$300/MWh. Compared to around $100/MWh for Wylfa's nuclear price. And those storage prices assume the storage in neatly cycled, fully, every day or so. But UK solar/wind production is not nearly that consistent.
In order to get continuous baseload, even if we assume an ideal site at the equator where the solar output is exactly the same every day, two-thirds of the electricity would need to go through batteries, and one-third direct. So even that would have a hard time competing with Wylfa (which is a relatively expensive first-of-a-generation nuclear project).
Once you factor-in the seasonal and annual variation from solar & wind, it would need a order of magnitude more storage.
So unless storage gets 10 times cheaper; and nuclear fails to get any cheaper than the most expensive first-of-generation plants; storage will never compete for baseload in the UK. It will be used for peaker-replacement on top of nuclear baseload. That is why there is backing for nuclear, even when renewables (without storage) can be cheaper. There is no prospect of large-scale storage being sufficiently cheap to compete for baseload in the UK.
Look at it another way: even very sunny countries like the UAE and Saudi are deploying large nuclear plants for baseload, alongside solar. And the UAE has some of the cheapest solar contracts in the world. Even they are not expecting solar to provide all the output (not in the next 60 years or so anyway).', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528705676000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2578657', u'in_reply_to': u'116822207', u'id': u'116832577', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glennmr', u'text': u'Sorry, but you are just reading the headlines and are biased toward renewables...there is always a backstory that doesn't hit the headlines in the far east and assigning western style attitudes never really works.
China is not going to abandon their nuclear. They put 8 plants on line in the last few years. That is why there are only about 20 under construction now. China will start more in the near future and still has plans for a lot more...including breeders reactors to close the fuel cycle. 
http://www.world-nuclear.org/information-library/country-profiles/countries-a-f/china-nuclear-power.aspx
As far as reducing hydro, they don't have any place else to dam up essentially. 
China has large coal reserves in the western part of the country and will not abandon those reserves...it is why coal plants are mainly built in that region. The nuclear plants are being put on the east coast due to limited fossil reserves and the difficulty to transport energy. 
Renewables are going to be a long term project there as well with one of the main goals is to dominate the energy production market (and that includes nuclear), but China will not abandon coal and other fossil fuels if it does not line up with their plans...climate change will likely be the last thing on the list overall.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528640432000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'limited fossil reserves and the difficulty to transport energy', u'effect': u'the nuclear plants are being put on the east coast'}], u'author_id': u'17680035', u'in_reply_to': u'116792886', u'id': u'116813769', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesValencia', u'text': u'I put up some reference to have a look at. The anti-nuclear fanatics complain about how long they claim nuclear takes to build and then demand reliance on schemes that have never been implemented anywhere at the needed scale in the real world and are fraught with uncertainties over both feasibility and cost.And that's the kindest interpretation that could be put upon it.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528703366000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'116829867', u'id': u'116831246', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Albert Rogers', u'text': u'So-called "nuclear waste" is slightly used nuclear fuel, that the 50 year old water moderated nuclear technology that was Alvin Weinberg's first invention cannot continue using, and so we call it "spent". The nuclear energy still in it is 19 times what has been used.Weinberg recognised this and two other weaknesses, which are slight compared with ANY other energy source, and do not include a usefulness for bomb-making.The only civilian reactor that has killed anybody, at Chernobyl, was the far riskier RBMK design, and it was disgracefully handled, not by the operators, but by their upper management.The Molten Salt Reactor Experiment, designed and managed by Weinberg at ORNL, successfully addressed all three weaknesses, which are:1/ Ceramic solid fuel pellets;2/ The need for a coolant (water) at 150 times atmospheric pressure;3/ The fact that the fissile inventory is reduced as it is consumed.Wait a minute, Albert, how can (3) not be inevitable? Simple, you synthesise as much fissile as you consume,. The more obvious way is to create U-233 by neutron capture activating thorium 232. It is the ultimate in Renewable Technologies.
One more thing: If the reactor for any reason gets too hot, the fact that the fuel is in and part of a molten salt that solidifies at far higher temperatures than "boiling water", means that a solid plug of it at the lowest point of the circuit is kept so with a fan powered the same way as the fuel circulation pump. If that power fails, the pug melts and dumps the entire fuel-salt contents of the reactor, safely into a basin where it solidifies -- the diametrical opposite of a "meltdown" caused by the evaporation of a water coolant.But this technology was sufficiently difficult even to adapt to bomb making that when Richard Nixon cut the funding for the Atomic Energy Commission, further development was abandoned.There are at least half a dozen companies now developing versions of molten salt reactor (MSR) design, at least one of which calls itself the People's Republic of China -- in its own language.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528640340000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the evaporation of a water coolant', u'effect': u'the diametrical opposite of a meltdown'}], u'author_id': u'16013454', u'id': u'116813728', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rootmeansquare', u'text': u'" And with the huge offshore wind potential of UK there is absolutely no issue to provide enough electricity for a 100% RE scenario. Reality is sometimes a bitch, clown."Which planet are you currently on? 19,000MW of wind turbine capacity are currently producing just 600MW and have been running at that level or less for the last 10 days.http://www.gridwatch.templar.co.uk/Non combustion renewables are generating 3.5% of demand right now - how on earth do you expect to get to 100%.?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528579953000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100100977', u'in_reply_to': u'116775883', u'id': u'116791909', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mazter', u'text': u'Interesting, but of course missing the point. When the anti-RE guys criticse an all RE option (the cheaper option), they claim insane amounts of storage, sometimes 3 weeks of storage due to 3 weeks of no wind.
But as your figures show, wind is low but it isn't at zero, and of course demand at this time of year is lower than in the winter when wind is more consistent, plus hydro, PV, bio-energy haven't been at zero.
Plus, of course, you are ignoring the back up of bio-gas, which could be produced by green efforts, such as the Ecotricity grass mills, or as a form of concentrated storage from P2G (power to gas), which despite it's low efficiency, is still economically viable (even in the winter) in a 100% RE model, as detailed here:
Can we get 100 percent of our energy from renewable sources?
BQSTART
"While several of the issues raised by the Heard paper are important, you have to realise that there are technical solutions to all the points they raised using today's technology," says the lead author Dr. Tom Brown of the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology. 
"Furthermore, these solutions are absolutely affordable, especially given the sinking costs of wind and solar power," says Professor Christian Breyer of Lappeenranta University of Technology, who co-authored the response.
Brown cites the worst-case solution of hydrogen or synthetic gas produced with renewable electricity for times when imports, hydroelectricity, batteries, and other storage solutions fail to bridge the gap during low wind and solar periods during the winter. For maintaining stability, there is a series of technical solutions, from rotating grid stabilisers to newer electronics-based solutions. The scientists have collected examples of best practice by grid operators from across the world, from Denmark to Tasmania.
"There are some persistent myths that 100 percent renewable systems are not possible," says Professor Brian Vad Mathiesen of Aalborg University, who is a co-author of the response. Our contribution deals with these myths one-by-one, using all the latest research. Now let's get back to the business of modelling low-cost scenarios to eliminate fossil fuels from our energy system, so we can tackle the climate and health challenges they pose," says Breyer.
BQEND
And please don't get upset about the cost of building out storage, as it will be done slowly and steadily alongside the expansion of RE. The monies could be made available by simply changing government policy. Look at this Guardian article, that displays £5bn of government investment to get the nuclear CfD down to £77/MWh.
Well, if we have on-shore wind instead at £50/MWh, (or PV at a similar price) how much monies would that give us for storage investment, just against this one nuclear plant. Well, assuming a future wholesale price of £45-£55/MWh (please see page 39), then the wind subsidy is £0-5/MWh, and the Wylfa subsidy £22-£32/MWh.
Annually, that's wind at £0 to £131m, and Wylfa at £578m to £841m.
So £447m to £710m annually to invest in storage (£16bn - £25bn over 35yrs), plus that £5bn at the start, not bad, not bad at all.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528700071000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'3 weeks of no wind', u'effect': u'sometimes 3 weeks of storage'}], u'author_id': u'11150889', u'in_reply_to': u'116826298', u'id': u'116829867', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quokkaZ', u'text': u'WNA sheds some light on this:
Nuclear Power in China

This phobia-scale fear of a humongous radioactive cloud 'wiping out' lives and lifestyles of families, friends and communities in the blink of an eye will be no more - NuScales 720 MW nuclear power plant [npp] has its Emergency Planning Zone [EPZ] at the boundary fence of its 0.16 sq km site, compared to the 200 sq km EPZ for a 'big nuclear' power plant.
A single 720 MW npp, comprising of 12 x 60 MW SMRs will have a capacity factor of 98%, a design life of 60 years and a capital cost of £2,136 million; every year, it will generate 5,181,056 MWh of 24/7 electricity. By contrast, 320 MW Swanseas TL will have a capacity factor of 19.6%, a lifespan of 120 years and a capital cost of £1,300 million; every year, it will generate 550,000 MWh of intermittent electricity.
It would take nearly 11 such tidal lagoons, at a capital cost of £14,300 million and occupying an area of 120 sq km, to generate as much intermittent electricity as the 24/7 electricity generated by a single 720 MW npp. The npp would have to be built a 2nd time, on the same site, using much of the same infrastructure to generate for 120 years - but this would only have a capital cost of £4,272 million - just 30% of the capital cost of intermittent tidal lagoon technology.
Paying 3.3X more for a technology that delivers a pathetic, intermittent product, that will forever require fossil-fuelled back up is insane. The millions of tons of quarried rock; the environmental desecration; the near-shore ecosystem destruction; the species wipe-out. BQSTART
Does France rely on German coal or does Germany rely on French nuclear?
BQEND
You present a false dichotomy, It goes both ways, the grids are interdependent.
In general France exports at night when it has a surplus due to overgeneration.
It relies upon the greater flexibility of its fossil powered neighbours to absorb this excess.
However, during the day France cannot necessarily guarantee to meet its own peak demand and imports from its neighbours to cover the shortfall.
This is especially so when several French nuclear plants have a safety shutdown.
The nuclear "miracle" is a mirage, it can't work in isolation.

description: Pumping £5bn into a new plant in north Wales as a way to fight climate change is a solution at odds with the rest of the world, says environment writer Fred Pearce
og_fields.og:description: Pumping £5bn into a new plant in north Wales as a way to fight climate change is a solution at odds with the rest of the world, says environment writer Fred Pearce
og_fields.og:title: Britain’s nuclear U-turn puts us in a very lonely club | Fred Pearce
text:
For once, ministers have put their money where their mouth is – into taking another stab at nuclear power. This week the business secretary, Greg Clark, announced plans to pump £5bn into a new nuclear power station at Wylfa in north Wales. It was a reversal of a longstanding Conservative policy not to underwrite nuclear construction. So why the sudden enthusiasm? And what does Clark know that the rest of the world does not?
For almost everywhere else, governments and corporations are pulling the plug on nuclear. Even in a world fearful of climate change, in which nations have promised to wean themselves off fossil fuels by the mid-century, almost no one wants to touch nuclear.
Germany will be nuclear-free by 2022. France – once Europe’s great nuclear advocates – is backtracking. President Macron is committed to cutting nuclear’s contribution to grid power from the 75% to 50%. Seven years after the Fukushima accident, all but a handful of Japan’s 54 nuclear power plants remain closed.
US utilities are shutting reactors fast too, even those with years of their operating licences yet to run. In America’s deregulated energy markets, nuclear cannot compete. Last week President Trump called for the utilities to suspend closures, citing national energy security. He may resort to the law to get his way, but even Trump is not demanding new reactors.
Meanwhile, the state-sponsored nuclear enthusiasm of China, recently the world’s premier builder, has dimmed. Beijing has issued no new construction approvals for over two years. Only Russia keeps up the momentum – which puts Britain in an embarrassing club.
Britain hasn’t completed a new nuclear power station for 23 years. The government’s professed reason for its newfound enthusiasm is fighting climate change, and in particular the need to find replacements on the grid for the remaining coal-fired power plants that it has pledged to shut by 2025. But while the cause is correct, the solution is increasingly at odds with the rest of the world.
Yes, nuclear is a proven large-scale source of low-carbon electricity. But renewable sources like solar and wind are both now cheaper, and are becoming cheaper still, while nuclear costs only rise.
Some who call themselves “eco-modernists” argue that nuclear and renewables would make a great mix: nuclear could fill in when the sun goes down and the winds drop. But there is a problem. Any effective stand-in for fickle renewables needs to be available at the flick of a switch. Hydropower or natural gas can do the job, but not nuclear. Its forte is to deliver constant baseload power.
If nuclear ticked enough other boxes, it might still have a role to play in keeping the lights on. But it has always been a bad neighbour and troublesome citizen. Some of our fears about radiation may be exaggerated, but they are real fears nonetheless. And nuclear power’s links to nuclear weapons are not just about shared technology – at least not while Britain remains home to the world’s largest stockpile of plutonium.
We are sitting on 130 tonnes of a human-made element that lies at the heart of most nuclear weapons. The stockpile is at a warehouse at Sellafield in Cumbria, in defiance of warnings from scientists at the Royal Society a decade ago that in its present form it poses a major security risk, whether diverted for weapons or breached by terrorists.
The plutonium was manufactured over decades from used power-station reactor fuel. Britain wanted to be at the forefront of a new global industry using plutonium to fuel new designs of reactors. But production continues even though there is no sign of a world market for plutonium. And neither the new Hinkley Point reactor under construction in Somerset, nor the proposed plant at Wylfa, will burn the stuff.
The government seems determined to pursue a nuclear dream, even though it has palpably failed to come to terms with the toxic legacy of the country’s nuclear past.
Next to the site of the planned Wylfa plant sits the shell of an old nuclear power station. It was shut in 2015, but is not scheduled for demolition for almost another century, in 2105. It is one of 11 former plants that sit abandoned around our coastlines, from Dungeness in Kent to Trawsfynydd in Snowdonia, and Sizewell in Suffolk to Hunterston in south-west Scotland.
They are currently being put into what the industry terms “care and maintenance” – mothballed while their radioactivity decays, and until the government’s Nuclear Decommissioning Authority can find somewhere to put their remains.
On present form, that day may never come. Britain is today no nearer agreeing a final resting place for its most dangerous and long-lasting radioactive wastes than it was back in 1976, when the royal commission on environmental pollution said we should build no more nuclear power plants until that problem was resolved. Absurdly, the most recent plan has been to bury the waste in tunnels to be dug beneath the Lake District national park.
Nuclear power today is a largely friendless industry: uneconomic without heavy government support, uninsurable, stuck with a military heritage from hell, overtaken by cleaner competitors, beset by waste problems that no one has resolved, and always vulnerable to public panic after the Chernobyl or Fukushima accidents.
Some believe it may have a future when the waste problems are resolved and if radical new reactor designs emerge. That may be so. But the truth is that in the 60 years since the bomb-makers first promised us “atoms for peace”, nuclear power has gone from a sunrise to a sunset industry. Only the British government seems not to realise it.
• Fred Pearce is the author of Fallout: A Journey Through the Nuclear Age, From the Atom Bomb to Radioactive Waste 
… we can’t turn away from climate change. For The Guardian, reporting on the environment is a  priority.  We give climate, nature and pollution stories the prominence they deserve, stories which often go unreported by others in the mainstream media. At this critical time for our species and our planet, we are determined to inform readers about threats, consequences and solutions based on scientific facts, not political prejudice or business interests. But we need your support to grow our coverage, to travel to the remote frontlines of change and to cover vital conferences that affect us all.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

description: Pontiff says clean energy is needed as climate change risks destroying humanity
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Pontiff says clean energy is needed as climate change risks destroying humanity
og_fields.og:title: Pope Francis tells oil bosses world must reduce fossil fuel use
text:
Pope Francis has told oil company chiefs that the world must switch to clean energy because climate change risks destroying humanity.
“Civilisation requires energy, but energy use must not destroy civilisation,” he said at the end of a two-day conference at the Vatican.
The pontiff said climate change was a challenge of epochal proportions, and that the world needed to come up with an energy mix that combatted pollution, eliminated poverty and promoted social justice.
The unprecedented conference, held behind closed doors at the Pontifical Academy of Sciences, brought together oil executives, investors and Vatican experts. Like the pope, they back scientific opinion that climate change is caused by human activity and that global warming must be curbed.
“We know that the challenges facing us are interconnected. If we are to eliminate poverty and hunger ... the more than 1 billion people without electricity today need to gain access to it,” Francis told them.
“But that energy should also be clean, by a reduction in the systematic use of fossil fuels. Our desire to ensure energy for all must not lead to the undesired effect of a spiral of extreme climate changes due to a catastrophic rise in global temperatures, harsher environments and increased levels of poverty,” he said. 
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

From what I've read above I understand that your definition of a "lukewarmer" is different from that of everybody else in that it doesn't include the usual definition of those who cherrypick the lowest range of estimated equilibrium climate sensitivities but does include those who consider there is no evidence that tropical cyclones are getting more intense, that famines are not increasing and that human struggles are not attributable to anthropogenic global warming.
However, Webster et al (2005) in the abstract of "Changes in Tropical Cyclone Number, Duration, and Intensity in a warming environment" Science Volume 309 Issue 5742 pp 1844-1846 report as follows.
"We examined the number of tropical cyclones as well as tropical cyclone days as well as tropical cyclone intensity over the past 35 years, in an environment of increasing sea surface temperature. A large increase was seen in the number and proportion of hurricanes reaching categories 4 and 5. The largest increase occurred in the North Pacific, Indian and Southwest Pacific Oceans, and the smallest percentage increase occurred in the North Atlantic Ocean. These increases have taken place while the number of cyclones and cyclone days has decreased in all basins except the North Atlantic during the past decade."
Climate scientists don't talk about famines increasing but they do talk about global warming increasing the rate of onset of drought, increasing the frequency of severe El Nino events which cause widespread drought, and moving west coast rainfall patterns poleward which also causes drought. In the absence of good governance droughts can lead to famine but countries with subsistence farmers at risk of famine have improved their governance in recent decades.
While all human struggles are not due to global warming, drought affected subsistence farmers are struggling and even more so in regions without good governance. Even in regions with good governance farmers can struggle financially with their farming business in times of drought and an increase in the rate of onset of drought and the frequency of severe droughts can lead to a farming operation becoming a struggle. In farming regions affected economically by such an increase in droughts people move out and seek work in the cities. BQENDYep, thanks for finally coming round to my way of thinking.
And what is best overall, a supply and demand pattern that best match each other.
So do you want to export leccy at minimal value in the summer, or avoid expensive leccy import in the winter.
Therefore choosing a steep pitch (when possible) gives a better year round match of supply and demand, than a shallower pitch.
Is such a decision wise at a cost of 1-1.5% of annual generation, I certainly believe so, and obviously so do the off-gridders.
And also of importance, it would reduce peak generation in the summer months which would help to allow more PV capacity to be rolled out and reduce DNO issues. So part of the 'big picture'.
But back to the crucial question, does an annual reduction of 1-1.5% of generation make such a set up unsuitable for the UK ........... only in your world, only in your world.
Anyways, nice to know the matter is now settled and you have revised your original and false claim. 0° (or as near as drainage will allow) works surprisingly well all year round because of the UK preponderance of overcast days.
A West biased azimuth on a 30-40° inclination also has benefits
We are talking about what is best overall - for your location (or your choice of Oxford) PVGIS (original database) says the optimum is 35° and on the latest db says 39°
Like nearly all domestic solar pv (and commercial farms) your system exports to the mains supply reducing demand on the grid at times of the day.
If you limit your production by de-optimising your supply then that is lost overall efficiency.There is no need to cut summer solar output because summer output does not exceed summer demand - it definitely does not do so as a matter of routine.

BQENDOkay, so give a time of year when solar export (demand reduction) on the grid is not used and therefore "wasted"

BQEND
BQENDIndeed - even in Northern Norway (20° North of your location) the steepest year round angle PVGIS recommends is 41°
Not 45°, not 50° and not 60°.
