description: Dana Nuccitelli: The WSJ disguises climate misinformation as “opinion”
headline: O
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: The WSJ disguises climate misinformation as “opinion”
og_fields.og:title: The Wall Street Journal keeps peddling Big Oil propaganda | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
The Wall Street Journal (WSJ) Opinion page has long had a conservative skew, and unfortunately that has extended to politicizing climate change with biased and factually inaccurate editorials.
Over the past several weeks, the WSJ’s attacks on climate science have gone into overdrive. On May 15th, the Opinion page published a self-contradictory editorial from the lifelong contrarian and fossil fuel-funded Fred Singer that so badly rejected basic physics, it prompted one researcher to remark, “If this were an essay in one of my undergraduate classes, he would fail.”
The WSJ did publish a letter to the editor (LTE) from real climate scientists Andrea Dutton and Michael Mann rebutting Singer’s editorial. However, it gave the last word to science deniers in an LTE response rejecting the well-established facts that sea level rise is accelerating and Antarctic is loss is contributing to it.
A few days later, the WSJ opinion page was at it again, publishing an editorial by Stephen F. Hayward, who describes himself as having “spent most of my adult life in conservative think tanks in Washington, D.C.,” and it shows. Hayward has a long history as a climate naysayer, spanning over a decade back to his days with the fossil fuel-funded American Enterprise Institute.
Hayward’s arguments of course deserve to be judged on their own merits. I devoted my first-ever Tweetstorm to doing just that:
Ok, let's do a Whack-a-Mole Twitter thread debunking all the nonsense in @stevenfhayward's @WSJ editorial (1/n)
Hayward falls into the category some describe as “Lukewarmers.” This group consists of people who think that – contrary to the body of available evidence – global warming will be slow and we don’t have to worry much about it. I prefer the term “Luckwarmer,” since they’re betting that Earth’s climate sensitivity is at the very low end or lower than the range of values supported by scientific evidence. In that sense, they’re gambling we’ll be very lucky that the climate dice will come up snake eyes.
Throughout his career, Hayward has spilled a lot of ink trolling those who are concerned about climate change. In this latest opinion piece, he argues that “climate change has run its course” because nobody is doing anything serious to solve it, and nobody cares about climate change anymore. 
Hayward’s evidence to support this thesis is flimsy, to put it charitably. For example, when pressed on the fact that every country save America has agreed to implement policies to curb climate change, Hayward cited Japan as a counter-example that’s building more coal power plants since the Fukushima nuclear plant disaster. Indeed, Japan’s climate policies are highly insufficient to meet the Paris goals. But Japan has nevertheless signed onto the Paris agreement, whose framework allows signatory countries to periodically strengthen their policies and commitments and thus eventually meet the targets. And Japan’s per person carbon pollution is already about 40% lower than America’s.
Hayward also cites polling data that shows Americans consider climate change a low priority, but neglects to mention that the vast majority (including Trump voters) support climate policies like taxing and/or regulating carbon pollution. He compares the issue to a car alarm whose blaring noise everybody soon tunes out. However, unlike a triggered car alarm, climate change poses ever-increasing risks. It won’t just go away if we ignore it. It’s much more like a fire alarm sounding off in a building whose occupants have been locked in.
Worst of all, Hayward claims that “the left politicized the issue,” which is beyond absurd. Those on the American ‘left’ generally accept the consensus of 97% of climate science experts and have proposed bipartisan solutions to this existential problem that, with a few exceptions, have been almost universally rejected by those on the American right for purely political reasons.
The WSJ is of course far from the only media outlet guilty of peddling fossil fuel industry propaganda. Last Friday, The Hill published a very similar editorial by Fred Singer, whose second sentence included two very easily fact-checked falsehoods: “sea level has been rising at a steady rate, between 1 and 2 millimeters per year.” In reality, sea level rise has been accelerating, now up to about 3.3 millimeters per year.
Some people are of the opinion that the Earth is flat, but the WSJ and The Hill probably wouldn’t publish Flat Earthers’ editorials. Of course, the Flat Earth Society doesn’t have the financial and political clout of the fossil fuel industry.
… we have a small favour to ask. More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

DRINK!', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528881090000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17443130', u'in_reply_to': u'116873536', u'id': u'116929545', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quokkaZ', u'text': u'BQSTART
I have some doubts about "rewilding" by injecting selected organisms into an environment as distinct from just abandoning land and allowing natural processes of regeneration to take place
BQEND
The more I hear of "rewilding", or at least some of the notions being spread both in Guardian comments and a couple of silly articles, the less I'm coming to like it. Any "rewilding" should be informed by conservation science not the current fad for just letting a bunch of weeds pop up.
Mining companies in Australia would love this notion of "rewilding" - fill in the holes, level the site and then bye. Thankfully their legal obligations extend further to rehabilitation - planting the site with locally native species with a suitable mix to provide some resemblance to what was there before. Do that and in a relatively short time the vertebrate and invertebrate animal life will follow.
Conservation is where it is at.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528974759000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'116975454', u'id': u'116983637', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paul Cowan', u'text': u'This is nonsense. We can't "rewild" half the planet and still provide sufficient food for the burgeoning population, particularly at a time when climate change is going to have a severe impact on food production. Consumption needs to fall dramatically to prevent ever more serious impacts from rising CO2, including rising sea levels, destruction of the base of the food chain in the oceans, shifting climate bands and unreliable weather patterns affecting harvests, including potential desertification of major grain producing regions. Presenting the problem as something that can be cured with a free cash hand-out and a programme of tree-planting is extremely misleading.What is needed, in addition to continuing efforts to shift to low-energy technologies and renewable sources of power, is a rejection of expectations of constantly rising living standards in the wealthy West, and willingness to embrace a far more austere lifestyle, and abandonment of the ambition to achieve Western levels of material prosperity in the third world. Unfortunately, humanity is innately selfish so that won't happen - everybody will continue to demand more, however well-off they are. There's no apparent solution to the problem, except one that reality imposes when we find that we are no longer able to tame nature.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528880564000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13533153', u'id': u'116929056', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'janey smit', u'text': u'the resistance lies firts and foremost with those who profit. austerity in this case is objected to because f the huge wealth gap.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528972553000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'f the huge wealth gap', u'effect': u'to'}], u'author_id': u'18507475', u'in_reply_to': u'116975454', u'id': u'116981742', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'I find it difficult to see that the planet could support 2% of our population. I wonder if the psychological impact of being a survivor of self-induced collapse will leave humanity with a very negative view of itself (which is fair subjectively, but objectively it looks like we are doing what our biology impels us to do). In my opinion intelligent life is the mechanism for inter-planetary spread of life. Which means that if humans eek out an existence and avoid extinction, we will nevertheless failed in what our role should have been.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528880520000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17327071', u'in_reply_to': u'116909227', u'id': u'116929010', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paul Cowan', u'text': u'I have some doubts about "rewilding" by injecting selected organisms into an environment as distinct from just abandoning land and allowing natural processes of regeneration to take place. That just comes from a gut feeling that ever-more human interference isn't likely to produce the most sustainable solutions.The main thing, though, is that persuading people to accept simpler, cheaper lifestyles is likely to face massive resistance: look at the screams of horror about a slight reduction to economic growth that economists predict from Brexit, or the outrage over "austerity" (which hasn't really been terribly austere) and ask yourself how people will respond to the prospect of the sort of cut in consumption that is probably necessary to hold down CO2 levels.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528965488000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13533153', u'in_reply_to': u'116949019', u'id': u'116975454', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Cloud9Cuckoo', u'text': u'UBI is great - but not for this. You need to stop GDP-growth, yes? But what the promise of GDP-growth currently substitutes for is redistribution of wealth. We don’t need to take resources away from the rich, as the poor will be rescued by GDP-growth.
Indeed any argument against growth is usually met by - ‘But what about the poor?’ 
UBI won’t, on its own, redistribute wealth. That can only be done by serious progressive taxation.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528879580000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4510472', u'id': u'116928159', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quokkaZ', u'text': u'BQSTART

The EUs total primary energy supply was slightly lower in 2015 than in 1990 but GDP approximately doubled over that period.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528960223000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'116971268', u'id': u'116971913', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'HalfTheSky', u'text': u'Yet another population-denialist article. "Birth rates" may be declining, but not as fast as numbers of mothers increase: births are actually increasing, and we are not at all "on track to stabilise", let alone on a track that would stabilise before causing environmental mayhem. No climate modelling unit in the world has been able to make <2oC warming feasible under the population path we are actually on (the IPCC's SSP3). The chance of net rewilding in the face of this population growth is between Buckley's and none. And yet there is so much that could be done to reduce population growth, if only people didn't deny it and pretend that there are other simple solutions.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528879490000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'environmental mayhem'}], u'author_id': u'15200929', u'id': u'116928080', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Globalman', u'text': u'Energy is in everything we do, from the basics of the food we eat to holidays, In fact money is energy, that is what we buy with it, money enables energy to be spent to make all what we consume,The more money spent the more energy used.

The same goes for Industrial Farming. If we want to stop destroying habitat then as consumers we should reject all products that contain palm oil, and any products that contain wood from endangered forests.We should pray mightily for the success of fusion technology experiments. Nothing will succeed in changing the World like a limitless supply of cheap power.There is still a lot we can do as individuals to make a difference,such as reduce our meat and dairy consumption and make ethical choices when we are buying products.We can dictate the direction of market forces if we choose, and even if it means harping on about the same old things, as I've just done, it's a simple message that everyone needs to listen to and understand.We do have power to shape the world, but it means denying ourselves some of the things we love, or at least limiting their consumption. This is a painful but necessary transition if we care about survival, and survival is what Life is all about, for every species of living thing. Disposible razors and or cartridges are about $100 / year x 10 yrs? 20 yrs? 50 yrs? 
Reuseable cloth diapers ( one child ): 100 cotton diapers ( 3 sizes included ) + covers. One time purchase of $250-$300. We're into year 2 with no issues . Disposibles $40-$50/ month x 1 yr? 2 yr? 3yr? Could be $1400 - $1800 at the 3 year mark. Its called RENT.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528843760000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17017662', u'id': u'116919211', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Phil246', u'text': u'Are you suggesting that we eliminate those who use most resources.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528898969000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100482184', u'in_reply_to': u'116939417', u'id': u'116946855', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sonicuniverse', u'text': u'Imagine tomorrow some incredible new gadget is created that you abolutely can't live without. The specs are flawless. It's perfect. 
You can't wait to get one. In fact you line up in front of the store overnight with others to be the first to get it. Your life will be so much better...
Except today you don't have it and today you're fine. Today you're absolutely fine.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528843291000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16606390', u'id': u'116919062', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'guest90', u'text': u'Just to underline this - a few points on the emissions mitigation strategy France has recently announced: 
BQSTART
"-Creation of a decarbonized industrial sector, with an objective of 10% decarbonized hydrogen by 2023, and 40% by 2028 -Development for zero emission solutions for road, rail, river, etc., transport with the deployment on the horizon for 2023 of 5,000 light utility vehicles, 200 heavy vehicles (bus, trucks, trains (TER), boats) and 100 hydrogen stations to refuel vehicles with locally produced hydrogen. -Increase in integration and storage capacities for renewable energies. 
"Decarbonized hydrogen is the energy transition accelerator." It was in using these words that Pascal Mauberger, by invitation from Nicolas Hulot, began his talk. He then continued, "the hydrogen revolution has begun." 
-Industry: augmented electrolyzers for a new low carbon era in the sectors of chemicals, refinery, steel. -Mobility: stations having the capacity to fuel a variety of hydrogen vehicles, from utility to buses and trucks, including cars and hydrogen trains.-Energy: long term storage solutions for very large volumes. Reinforcing the competitiveness of water electrolysis is essential for the deployment plan of decarbonized hydrogen
Water electrolysis technology, producing on-site and on demand from renewable resources, clearly appears to be the cornerstone for the large-scale deployment of decarbonized hydrogen for industry, mobility and energy."
BQEND
Germany are calling for between 4GW and
15GW of electrolysis by 2030, and 100GW by 2050. Industry is going to soon start shifting up a gear from the many 1-20MW pilot projects into large-scale commercial operations soon. Even the Norwegian government issued a formal statement on hydrogen; within the understanding that hydrogen
is the energy transition.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528893988000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17280722', u'id': u'116942363', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Eric Marshall', u'text': u'The Plasticine. Genius.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528842104000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100480750', u'in_reply_to': u'116904351', u'id': u'116918652', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'janey smit', u'text': u'it's funny how it's always about food but not industry making gadgets to throw away and all that comes with it. food we do need and there are better and worse ways of producing it but let's rewild 1. defunct industrial estates, and 2, make others defunct by producing stuff that lasts, but oh, the economy/profits for the rich, cause it's not really for jobs that this is done, especially with outsourcing and robots, it's for corporate profits. no chance of improvement with that system.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528892303000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18507475', u'in_reply_to': u'116929056', u'id': u'116940740', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Borjigin', u'text': u'The world is moving rapidly toward true money - gold and silver backed currencies.

Does that matter ? Hell yes, when we are moving into a period of high inflation.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528842010000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12101753', u'in_reply_to': u'116917593', u'id': u'116918621', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'janey smit', u'text': u'it already is for the poor! it's the well off that need to learn. other than that it's the capitalist system of ever increasing consumption to keep the economy going. and of course any military,even at ''peace'' has a huge foot print.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528892037000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18507475', u'in_reply_to': u'116930947', u'id': u'116940481', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'martinstott', u'text': u'Universal Basic Infrastructure; childcare, eldercare, education, health, climate change mitigation, public transport and much else - public goods that people who need them most would use most, is a far better idea than UBI. No one agrees with anyone else they haven't already agreed with before a hundred times. Why can't the guardian open interesting subjects up for comment?
Like why wind turbines are killing 80,000 bats a year, surely that's not down to population is it? Or why our pets have to justify their existence on this planet but humans have no need justify their extravagant families, hmm Tis hard to move away from the population problem the liberals try so hard to ignore.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528828058000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'id': u'116912476', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Borjigin', u'text': u'Standard economics died in 2008.
We, the world have been on a diet of debt creation with no growth since that date.The financial system is changing in front of your eyes and not for the good.
Our immediate problems are rising interest rates, rising inflation, collapsing banks, collapsing bond market and sovereign debt defaults. 
UBI will be long forgotton when all of this accelerates.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528841441000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12101753', u'in_reply_to': u'116917593', u'id': u'116918434', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'guest90', u'text': u'UBI I think is a good idea in certain areas, and with certain people - it allows a little more trial and error in the jobs market that could really be useful.
However I will focus on the major problem- 
We have one problem and as the authors point out, it is not population although this is a contributary factor. It is fossil fuels. I will also point out that at this point it will not do much good to argue too much about population unless you are trying to provoke a war (fairly unpleasant idea); and even that would not get us anywhere - all ideas of trying to stick to difficult emission mitigation strategies would be well and truly out the window. Every nation on Earth would ramp up fossil fuel production and consumption, and budgets on environmentally friendly policies would evaporate instantly. 
Realistically, we should use the global pool of talent and productivity we have available to speed up deployment and realisation of the technologies that have any hope of getting us out of this mess. This is what is already happening; the only problem with the kind of renewable energy investment that is really needed is that we already have so much infrastructure based around oil, gas and coal. It cannot be overstated that the energy landscape is in the midst of profound change.
However there is one piece of the puzzle that has still not been fully grasped by many. We need something that fills all the gaps oil, gas and coal leave behind: dispatchable power, months of winter heating, many hours of driving or traversing the skies and oceans, and very large quantities of high temperature heat for all the materials we require to make things. 
This energy needs to be produced by cheap renewable power and easily stored and transported in a very similar way to what is being phased out. And we are going to all need to keep the economy going in order to fund its initial development - if only to replace the enormous fossil fuel subsidies that we continue to destroy ourselves with. This energy is hydrogen; produced either from electricity or from biomass - or from fossil fuels with CCS. There is absolutely no alternative to the vast amounts of liquid and gaseous fuel the world consumes annually, and all the ways we transport and consume these fuels. And finally; it is cheaper than gasoline in a car or truck. In a few years it will be cheaper than natural gas. The energy transition is a sinister joke without hydrogen, and we all better become aware of this fact.
Just as a further point to note - most poorer countries use very little if any heating. They certainly use far less gas; and the energy they do use they will need for airconditioning when its hot, and then for a few hours in the night. Most of this will be adequately supplied by solar and some backup; and here again we will probably be waiting for the cost of electrolysis & renewables to further drop; but that won't take long. Driving I think is going to edge towards hydrogen; if only because of grid-reliability/grid storage issues and more technical details involved with storing energy. As I say, this will not be as expensive as it sounds, in a few years.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528891050000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'grid reliability grid storage issues and more technical details involved with storing energy', u'effect': u'is going to edge towards hydrogen'}], u'author_id': u'17280722', u'id': u'116939367', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GuyWarren', u'text': u'Current projections show that the Total Fertility Rate (number of children per pair of parents) is below 2 and dropping. Not a good thing or a bad thing, but it will stress our developed world and how we look after the elderly.
Watch the GIF on this wiki page. Somehow I doubt it, to be honest.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528839672000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16564559', u'in_reply_to': u'116917411', u'id': u'116917705', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'zavaell', u'text': u'You talk standard economics, and until we break from that no change for the better can come about.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528839403000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1347038', u'in_reply_to': u'116880507', u'id': u'116917593', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Niklas2811', u'text': u'Every house, hut and flat roofed building in the tropics needs to have a photovoltaic set, an appropriate battery, a basic electric cooker, a water pump or access to same, LED lighting. How else will we be able to afford the cost of keeping all the elderly and other such non wealth creating jobs. No problem if the renumeration is not needed for totally living on and it would do away with all the complications and poverty traps of present welfare systems.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528889072000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18523441', u'id': u'116937035', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'longlivedpr', u'text': u'Money doesn't have to come from somewhere. That is only true of commodity money like gold.
Modern (fiat) money can be, and is, created out of thin air. Money is mostly a social construct that can be modified to suit society's needs.
Resources, on the other hand, do have to come from somewhere. Many attempts have been made to create a utopian society where everyone is equal and all work for the common good, but all failed because of greed for money or power.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528888101000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'greed for money or power', u'effect': u'all failed'}], u'author_id': u'2600028', u'in_reply_to': u'116898928', u'id': u'116936102', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Kennyryan1', u'text': u'When Al Gore uses a bulldozer to fill in his swimming pool and hot tub then talk to me about downsizing', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528827695000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17975026', u'id': u'116912250', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'zavaell', u'text': u'Needs can, and have to be, addressed in different ways and that is what is crucial as you say.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528839003000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1347038', u'in_reply_to': u'116887162', u'id': u'116917437', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'derekcolman', u'text': u'I think you unwittingly pointed out the problem. UBI would encourage people to work less or not at all.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528887585000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2600028', u'in_reply_to': u'116914494', u'id': u'116935568', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Borjigin', u'text': u'It started operationally on the 26th March 2018 after six years of planning and testing. All alternative systems to the IMF, BIS, Comex are operational and even the UK has signed up.
China commenced selling/buying oil in yuan futures exchangeabe for gold. In weeks it has taken 12% of the world's oil market. All commodities will follow.
The transition will be anything but friendly and I recommend that you research this subject.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528883714000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12101753', u'in_reply_to': u'116924417', u'id': u'116931883', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'longlivedpr', u'text': u'There are other ways of displaying status apart from conspicuous consumption. 
For example, conspicuous physical fitness. This has already started to happen among the urban wealthy who are no longer impressed by big cars and big houses. In a big city, is hard to become physically fit without spare time, money, and discipline (3 qualities of high status individuals)
It's not even a new concept. Some ancient societies frowned upon luxury and considered physical fitness the ultimate status symbol. 
There are other options too: Conspicuous knowledge, conspicuous charity, conspicuous work, conspicuous leisure, and so on. None of them need to involve excessive consumption.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528825187000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12396895', u'in_reply_to': u'116874675', u'id': u'116910599', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'zavaell', u'text': u'You seem unable to perceive the point made, which makes your position even more dangerous.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528838939000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1347038', u'in_reply_to': u'116884838', u'id': u'116917411', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Anastasi Gerling', u'text': u'Oh... my... god... this is the best idea I heard in the last year. Thank you for sharing, really', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528838917000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18317596', u'in_reply_to': u'116898928', u'id': u'116917403', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'tater', u'text': u'In broad terms, the challenges we face and the changes in the way we live that we need to make are understood. description: Simon Lewis and Mark Maslin: Does the arrival of the Anthropocence mean we’re doomed to societal collapse? Not if we break the mould of ever-greater production and consumption
og_fields.og:description: Simon Lewis and Mark Maslin: Does the arrival of the Anthropocence mean we’re doomed to societal collapse? Not if we break the mould of ever-greater production and consumption
og_fields.og:title: How universal basic income and rewilding could save the planet | Simon Lewis and Mark Maslin
text:
Enough concrete has been produced to cover the entire surface of the Earth in a layer two millimetres thick. Enough plastic has been manufactured to clingfilm it as well. We produce 4.8bn tonnes of our top five crops, plus 4.8 billion head of livestock, annually. There are 1.2bn motor vehicles, 2bn personal computers, and more mobile phones than the 7.5 billion people on Earth.
The result of all this production and consumption is a chronic, escalating, many-sided environmental crisis. From rapid climate change to species extinctions to microplastics in every ocean, these impacts are now so large that many scientists have concluded that we have entered a new human-dominated geological period called the Anthropocene. 
This dangerous new epoch ends the unusually stable planetary conditions over the past 10,000 years that allowed farming and complex civilisations to emerge. With the spectre of rapid environmental change leading to societal collapse looming, what is to be done?
Using modern science to reanalyse human history can help us understand future problems in more fundamental ways. Our analysis shows that just five successive types of human society have spread worldwide: hunter-gatherer, agriculturalist, mercantile capitalist, industrial capitalist and, following the second world war, today’s consumer capitalist society. 
Each subsequent stage relies on greater energy use and greater generation and flows of information and knowledge. These result in a much larger population, rising per capita productivity and greater collective agency. Seen in this light, a new sixth type of society will require both greater energy provision and improved systems to communicate knowledge and manage information. 
To usher in a new way of living, the core dynamic of ever-greater production and consumption of goods and resources must be broken, coupled with a societal focus on environmental repair. Two increasingly discussed ideas do just this. 
Universal Basic Income (UBI) is a policy whereby a financial payment is made to every citizen, unconditionally, without any obligation to work, at a level above their subsistence needs. Small-scale trials of UBI show most people would still work, but UBI could break the link between work and consumption. We all do it, saying: “I work so hard, I deserve that fancy meal, new gadget, or long-haul flight.” Consumption is the payback for being ever-more productive at work. Indeed, it makes little sense to curb consumption when we know we will have to be ever-more productive at work regardless of our choices. 
UBI reduces dependency, giving people the agency to say no to undesirable work, and yes to opportunities that often lie out of reach. With UBI we could all think long-term, well beyond the next payday. We could care for ourselves, others, and the wider world, as living in the Anthropocene demands.
Another idea is Half-Earth – the simple but profound idea that environmental repair could come fromallocating half the Earth’s surface primarily for the benefit of other species. Half-Earth is less utopian than it first appears, as we have become an urban species. Mass-scale forest restoration is already underway, with commitments across 43 countries to restore 292m hectares of degraded land to forest, 10 times the area of the UK. 
And at a deeper level, our views on nature are forged by the society we live in. Acknowledging the Anthropocene re-establishes that humans are part of nature, and so rewilding projects, where large areas are managed to allow natural processes to run, are increasingly popular. Slowly, a new nature aesthetic is being born. 
But can we really escape booming production and consumption? The fate of species encountering vast new resources is exponential growth and then collapse, epitomised by the rapid expansion and eventual death of bacteria growing in a Petri dish. While rarely recognised, we humans have recently become the exception to this rule: birth rates on all continents are declining and the global population is on track to stabilise. More information, in the form of girls’ education, has done something truly extraordinary in the context of 4bn years of life. 
UBI would give people the right to choose when it comes to fulfilling their own basic needs, and rewilding Earth does the same of other species’ needs. This would be a legacy of a new chapter in Earth’s history that we could be proud of. 
… we can’t turn away from climate change. For The Guardian, reporting on the environment is a  priority.  We give climate, nature and pollution stories the prominence they deserve, stories which often go unreported by others in the mainstream media. At this critical time for humanity and our planet, we are determined to inform readers about threats, consequences and solutions based on scientific facts, not political prejudice or business interests. But we need your support to grow our coverage, to travel to the remote frontlines of change and to cover vital conferences that affect us all.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

description: Coal rebound and slowing efficiency gains in 2017 suggest Paris goals may be missed, says oil firm
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Coal rebound and slowing efficiency gains in 2017 suggest Paris goals may be missed, says oil firm
og_fields.og:title: Rise in global carbon emissions a 'big step backwards', says BP
text:
The renewed upward march of global carbon emissions is worrying and a big step backwards in the fight against climate change, according to BP.
Emissions rose 1.6% in 2017 after flatlining for the previous three years, which the British oil firm said was a reminder the world was not on track to hit the goals of the Paris climate deal.
Renewable power generation grew by 17% last year, led by wind and followed by what BP called “stunning” growth in solar. 
But strong economic growth led to above-average energy demand, coal use bounced back in China and efficiency gains slowed down, causing emissions to jump, the company’s annual statistical review of world energy found.
Spencer Dale, the group’s chief economist, said: “At first blush, from an energy transition perspective, these numbers potentially look a bit disappointing.”
The emissions rise was “slightly worrying” and a “pretty big backward step”, he said. “It suggests to me we are not on a path to the Paris climate goals.”
However, the economist said there was an inevitability to the backsliding, because 2014-16 had seen an exceptionally fast shift to greener power sources, led by short-term targets in China.
“I am more worried by the lack of progress in the power sector over the past 20 years, than by the pickup in carbon emissions last year,” he said. 
Dale said the power sector, in which BP has a limited presence, should do most of the heavy-lifting when it comes to future emissions cuts.
“It’s frustrating that so much energy is devoted to other bits of the [energy] sector where you get relatively little bang for your buck,” he said, in reference to emissions savings from switching from oil-burning cars to electric ones.
BP said the world’s appetite for oil remained strong, as it grew 1.8% last year. 
Production cuts by Opec and Russia had achieved their aim of bringing oil supply and demand back into balance, Dale said.
But he cautioned that oil prices – which recently hit $80 (£60) per barrel but have since fallen back to about $76 – were now so high they were beginning to curb oil demand.
“If we saw oil prices maintain at these levels, that would eat into oil demand,” he said. 
BP reported profits up 71% for the first three months of the year, off the back of the resurgent oil price.

description: Experts say almost 30 species of pyralid moths have flown in or been transported via the horticultural trade
headline: O
og_fields.og:description: Experts say almost 30 species of pyralid moths have flown in or been transported via the horticultural trade
og_fields.og:title: One new species of 'micro-moth' found in Britain every year
text:
They are often tiny, frequently brown and always challenging to identify but an average of one new species of pyralid moth each year is turning up in Britain, according to experts.
Almost 30 new species of this large family of “micro-moths” have been recorded over the last 30 years – either flying in themselves or being transported via the horticultural trade.
While the abundance of moths is in decline, more than 125 new species of moth have been spotted in Britain this century alone, with 27 species establishing themselves as breeding species.
People are being urged to spot and help document these new arrivals as part of this year’s Moth Night, an annual three-night event to record and celebrate moths, organised by Butterfly Conservation, the Centre for Ecology & Hydrology and wildlife publisher Atropos.
“Just because something is called a micro-moth, don’t assume it’s tiny and brown and dull and impossible to identify because some of these aren’t,” said Richard Fox of Butterfly Conservation. “Moths in general are a fantastic, interesting group of wildlife that’s still relatively diverse – there are hundreds of species in your back garden. Anyone who is interested in wildlife will find that exciting and inspiring.”
Newly arrived micro-moths include Musotima nitidalis, originally from Australia and New Zealand, which reached Britain in 2009 via the horticultural trade. The moth is now found in several locations in southern England, where its caterpillars feed on ferns such as bracken.
Many of the recent pyralid colonists have arrived naturally, probably assisted by climate change, including the beautifully coloured Evergestis limbata, which has settled along the south coast of England.
According to Fox, most of the new arrivals are entirely benign although one, the box tree moth, will be unpopular with gardeners for its caterpillars’ habit of devouring the leaves of box hedges.
Easy to see native pyralids include the day-flying mint moth, which can be found among garden herbs and the small magpie – a surprisingly large black and white moth. Common migrants include the rush veneer and rusty-dot pearl.
The caterpillars of another group of pyralid moth, the china-marks, live in an air-filled bubble of spun leaves, sometimes below the surface of ponds or at the edge of streams.
As well as apps and online guides, there is a new guidebook on pyralid moths to help spotters. Mark Tunmore of publisher Atropos said: “New species are being added to the British list with regularity and we want to make sure that people are well equipped to identify these. We expect Moth Night 2018 to add to our knowledge of this group of moths.”

[{u'author': u'Carl123', u'text': u'BQSTART
Ok I can see that you are not interested in having a discussion, you just want to be 'right'.
BQEND
I responded to your comment. Perfectly reasonably, I thought.
BQSTART
Plenty of people understand the term 'spiritual but not religious'.
BQEND
Plenty people use the the phrase 'spirtual but not religious' - whether they understand it to mean very much, or anything specific, or the same thing that someone else mean by it, is a different question.
Some of these people are atheists who may not realise they are atheists, or can't quite admit it to themselves, or know very well that they are atheists but don't want to say the word out loud for fear of being judged too harshly. Others are committed theists invested in specific theological traditions/doctrines, but no longer associate with organised religion so consider that they are "not religious". Others may be pantheists or adherents of some other fringe theology which has no "religion" to speak of, so they are "not religious". Others may be Buddhist, and don't consider that their beliefs are, technically, "religious" because they involve no deities. Others may have given it very little thought at all, but just like the phrase because it has a nice ring to it and makes them sound interesting and deep, or because it distances them from religious people they object to, or because someone they admire used it about themselves so they've adopted it too. 
"Spiritual but not religious" is as fluffy and malleable a phrase as you could come up with. As I've pointed out to you before, "pause" is a completely inappropriate term (coined by contrarians who desperately wanted it to be so) for what was in truth merely a short-term slowdown. 
And when you consider that post-2000 warming has been at least as great - if not greater - than previously, it is obvious that the slowdown has been wiped out out by a corresponding speed-up. Why make a great song and dance about one, and remain silent on the other? That makes no sense at all. 
BQSTART
attributing it to natural variation
BQEND
As I've also pointed out to you before, the IPCC told us nearly 30 years ago that there would be short-term deviations from the long-term warming trend, due to natural factors. The important thing is that these have been temporary and in both directions, and there is no reason to think that will change.
BQSTART
You've acknowledged there is uncertainty
BQEND
That is no reason to start casting doubt on fundamental things that are settled.
BQSTART
That doesn't mean the rise was caused entirely or substantially by CO2!
BQEND
Scientists have looked hard for forcings that could plausibly be causing the warming trend. They can't find any other than CO2.
BQSTART
Yet global temperatures have dropped 0.67C in two years!
BQEND
Well, blow me down. 2018, with a (weak) La Niña, has been cooler than super El Niño year 2016.
In truth, even with a La Niña, 2018 to date has been one of the very warmest years in the instrumental record. Warmer even than almost all previous El Niños. Again, when the temperature drops, it's natural variability. When it rises, it's AGW. Just work through the logic (or lack thereof).
You've acknowledged there  is uncertainty; so the question remains about the degree of uncertainty, and that is where scientific opinion diverges and words like the "Precautionary Principle" come into play. 'Deniers' are usually simply doing their job as scientists. Science is meant to be open and contestable. It's meant to be able to be replicated and scrutinised. How can you not be suspicious when Phil Jones wrote: 
"We have 25 or so years invested in the work. Why should I make the data available to you, when your aim is to try and find something wrong with it?" !!!
That's what scientists are supposed to do! They're supposed to test and falsify theories. 
Why would you upend economies on the basis of a 'maybe/could/who knows what might happen' scenario? Wouldn't you prefer to see activism and funds directed at problems we face now?

description: At a gathering of fossil fuel executives at the Vatican, Pope Francis spoke much-needed common sense about climate change
og_fields.og:description: At a gathering of fossil fuel executives at the Vatican, Pope Francis spoke much-needed common sense about climate change
og_fields.og:title: Big Oil CEOs needed a climate change reality check. The Pope delivered | Bill McKibben
text:
You kind of expect popes to talk about spiritual stuff, kind of the way you expect chefs to discuss spices or tree surgeons to make small talk about overhanging limbs.
Which is why it was so interesting this week to hear Pope Francis break down the climate debate in very practical and very canny terms, displaying far more mathematical insight than your average world leader and far more strategic canniness than your average journalist. In fact, with a few deft sentences, he laid bare the hypocrisy that dominates much of the climate debate.
The occasion was the gathering of fossil fuel executives at the Vatican, one of a series of meetings to mark the third anniversary of Laudato Si, his majestic encyclical on global warming. The meetings were closed, but by all accounts big oil put forward its usual anodyne arguments: any energy transition must be slow, moving too fast to renewable energy would hurt the poor by raising prices, and so forth.
In response, Francis graciously thanked the oil executives for attending, and for “developing more careful approaches to the assessment of climate risk”. But then he got down to business. “Is it enough?” he asked. “Will we turn the corner in time? No one can answer that with certainty, but with each month that passes, the challenge of energy transition becomes more pressing.” Two and a half years after the Paris climate talks, he pointed out, “carbon dioxide emissions and atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases remain very high. This is disturbing and a cause for real concern.” Indeed.
It’s odd to have the pope schooling energy executives on the math of carbon
What’s really “worrying”, though, “is the continued search for new fossil fuel reserves, whereas the Paris agreement clearly urged keeping most fossil fuels underground”. And in that small sentence he calls the bluff on most of what passes for climate action among nations and among fossil fuel companies. Yes, Donald Trump notwithstanding, most countries have begun to take some steps to reduce demand for energy over time. Yes, oil companies have begun to grudgingly issue “climate risk reports” and divert minuscule percentages of their research budgets to renewables.
But no one has been willing to face the fact that we have to leave more than 80% of known fossil fuel reserves underground if we have any chance of meeting the Paris targets. No company has been willing to commit to leaving the coal and oil and gas in the earth, and almost no nation has been willing to make them do so. Instead, the big fossil fuel countries continue to aid and abet the big fossil fuel companies in the push for more mining and drilling. In Australia, the Turnbull government backs a massive new coalmine; in Canada, the Trudeau government literally buys a pipeline to keep the tar sands expanding; in the US, the federal government might as well be a wholly owned subsidiary of the fossil fuel companies.
In fact, as Francis points out, it’s not just that these companies and countries are committed to digging up the reserves they currently have. Even more insanely, they’re out there exploring for more. Companies like Exxon devote billions and billions of dollars to finding new oil fields, even though we have far more oil than we could ever safely burn.
All of this is morally wrong, as Francis points out. “Decisive progress cannot be made without an increased awareness that all of us are part of one human family, united by bonds of fraternity and solidarity. Only by thinking and acting with constant concern for this underlying unity that overrides all differences, only by cultivating a sense of universal intergenerational solidarity, can we set out really and resolutely on the road ahead,” he says.
Which is great – it’s the job of religious leaders to remind us to think beyond our own self-interest.
But Francis also understands that our current approach makes no mathematical sense. We can’t have a nice, slow, easy transition because we can’t put barely any more carbon in the atmosphere. We must solve the problem of energy access for the poor by using renewables, not fossil fuel, because “our desire to ensure energy for all must not lead to the undesired effect of a spiral of extreme climate changes due to a catastrophic rise in global temperatures, harsher environments and increased levels of poverty”. Above all, we’ve got to pay as much attention to actual reality as we do to political reality: “Civilization requires energy, but energy use must not destroy civilization!”
It’s odd to have the pope schooling energy executives on the math of carbon. But actually, no odder than NFL quarterbacks schooling politicians on racial injustice, or high school kids schooling a nation on the danger of guns. Amid the unprecedented wave of nonsense coming from DC, it’s good to remember that there are still people of all kinds able to pierce through the static and the shouting. Good common sense speaks even more loudly when it comes from unexpected corners.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

And incredibly malicious to boot. I guess if DC had written that 30 years ago he'd have used a pen dipped in green ink.
He pretends that the short-term economic benefits for but a small % of world population should trump the need for us all to work to stop the onrushing locomotive of accelerating global warming. To bolster his bent arguments he sells us blatant falsehoods. That's deeply deranged.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529080363000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14769888', u'in_reply_to': u'117028785', u'id': u'117035242', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'The higher we let global temperature rise the greater the risk of temperatures going really high.
From a 3/2016 study:
BQSTART
In combination with previous findings, results suggest the permafrost region will become a carbon source to the atmosphere by 2100 regardless of warming scenario. 1
BQEND
And from the NSIDC
BQSTART
But if the Earth continues to warm, and a lot of permafrost thaws out, the Arctic could become an overall source of carbon to the atmosphere, instead of a sink. 
This is what scientists refer to as a "tipping point." We say that something has reached a tipping point when it switches from a relatively stable state to an unstoppable cycle. 
In this case, the Arctic would change from a carbon sink to a carbon source. If the Arctic permafrost releases more carbon than it absorbs, it would start a cycle where the extra carbon in the atmosphere leads to increased warming. 
The increased warming means more permafrost thawing and methane release. 2
BQEND
Yet the study I linked to went on the say “that 65%–85% of permafrost carbon release can still be avoided if human emissions are actively reduced.”

No point in asking; none of the climate change denier trolls can produce any evidence for their statements that can't immediately be rebutted, which is why they never produce any.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529071837000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16462578', u'in_reply_to': u'117028678', u'id': u'117029900', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Northforce', u'text': u'There's has been negligible global warming over the past 20 years with a large increase in CO2, this appears to be a travesty.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529069631000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18157694', u'in_reply_to': u'117028026', u'id': u'117028547', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidFTA', u'text': u'I'd better start by apologising for my language, then ask for a reference to whatever this "scientist" you mention who reckons stratospheric sulfate injection won't be a problem.
The reason I'd be interested in hearing about this "scientist" you mention is because there's a pretty solid body of work to say that stratospheric sulfate injection is among the most stupid ideas possible. There's a pdf of a presentation given by Rutgers U climatologist Alan Robock that explains just how moronic it is at https://www.aps.org/units/fps/meetings/april2009/upload/geoengineering-robock09.PDF, which goes into detail about how partial reflection of incoming sunlight back to space will cause rapid localised cooling and weakening of the water cycle (less evaporation means less rain means droughts), plus destruction of stratospheric ozone (up in the sky, ozone protects us from solar UV) and generation of surface level ozone (ozone here at the surface is toxic, and a carcinogen; much better to have ozone up in the sky where it blocks UV and we don't breathe it).
Better "geoengineering" ideas would be to stop disrupting natural CO2 drawdown processes, such as terrestrial and marine primary productivity (trees and algae respectively). This would be done by encouraging reforestation, and stop whale-hunting (https://www.esa.org/esablog/research/poo-pump-whales-as-ecosystem-engineers/). 
Given that rapid warming of ocean surfaces is also disrupting marine overturning (further disrupting nutrient recycling by upwelling) I'd also suggest that Lovelock & Rapley's "ocean pipes" idea be revisited.

description: IPCC says ‘rapid and far-reaching’ steps required to combat climate change
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: IPCC says ‘rapid and far-reaching’ steps required to combat climate change
og_fields.og:title: Leaked UN draft report warns of urgent need to cut global warming
text:
The world is on track to exceed 1.5C of warming unless countries rapidly implement “far-reaching” actions to reduce carbon emissions, according to a draft UN report leaked to Reuters.
The final draft report from the UN’s intergovernmental panel on climate change (IPCC) was due for publication in October. It is the guiding scientific document for what countries must do to combat climate change.
Human-induced warming would exceed 1.5C by about 2040 if emissions continued at their present rate, the report found, but countries could keep warming below that level if they made “rapid and far-reaching” changes.
• Sign up to receive the top stories in Australia every day at noon
Under the 2015 Paris climate agreement, almost 200 countries signed up to limit global temperature rises to well below 2C above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5C.
Climate scientist and Climate Analytics director Bill Hare said the draft report showed with greater clarity how much faster countries needed to move towards decarbonisation under various temperature situations and that the impacts of climate change greatly increased between 1.5C and 2C of warming.
Necessary actions include making the transition to renewable energy, powering the transport sector with zero carbon electricity, improving agricultural management and stopping deforestation. 
“This IPCC report shows anyone drawing from published papers that there are big differences between 1.5 and 2 degrees warming in both natural and human systems,” Hare said. “Two degrees warming and the tropical reefs have basically no chance – 1.5 degrees, they have a small to modest chance of survival.
“There’s a range of commentary that comes out of the report that provides a stronger narrative for us to act than ever before.”
He said it showed that if emissions continued on their present pathway, there was no chance of limiting global temperature rises even to 3C.
Economic modelling in the draft report showed that the dangers for economic growth, particularly in developing countries, were significantly greater at 2C than 1.5C.
The Greenpeace International executive director, Jennifer Morgan, said the moment of truth had come for leaders and the feasibility of achieving the Paris goals was a political choice.
“This choice must be driven by a moral obligation that binds us together. Through international cooperation, real ambition and working with communities, our leaders still have the time to do what they must,” she said.
“That means saying no to fossil fuels and standing up for forest and ocean protection with decisions that prove they understand the urgency. It means cutting down on meat and dairy consumption, and changing the way we produce our food.”
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.

comments:
[{u'author': u'TBombadil', u'text': u'There is a small area of wasteland near where I live that is owned by the local council. They finally decided to turn it into a wildflower meadow. The cut it regularly for a year or two to deplete the soil so that crops that used to grow there could not regenerate. They then sowed it with a mixture of wildflower seeds that flowered at different times of the year so that a regular supply of nectar was available throughout the season. They now cut it twice a year once in early spring before the flowers start to grow and then again in mid October once all the flowers have died back. 
I have recorded 20 species of butterfly on this one small area and numerous other bees, hoverflies, beetles and spiders. All those insects and seeds attract birds, including an almost permanent flock of Goldfinches. Despite being seeded we are now finding other flowers such as orchids appearing on the meadow. Any person or council with bits of land that is not used for some other purpose should really consider turning it into a wildflower meadow. 
Nettle patches can run out of control but are a wonderful resource for insects, particularly for insects that predate on aphids. Aphids that are specific to nettles will breed on the nettles and they will provide food for aphid eaters and bodies for predator wasps to lay eggs on. If you have any flower, fruit or vegetables under attack by aphids grow a nettle patch and you will soon have a growing army of assistant gardeners to help you tackle the problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529459464000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3382782', u'in_reply_to': u'117084199', u'id': u'117206678', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LonnieHodowal', u'text': u'Insects are dying off for one reason: too many people.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529452552000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16871054', u'id': u'117205223', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrishove123', u'text': u'I feel that one of the major contributors is being totally overlooked. and this is vehicle kill.You look at how many vehicles there are on the UK roads 31.7 million (https://www.statista.com/statistics/299972/average-age-of-cars-on-the-road-in-the-united-kingdom/), and say just for argument's sake they each kill an average of ten or twenty insects per day.That is a lot of dead insects every year.And that is just cars, add to that another 4,007,331 vans. (https://www.smmt.co.uk/2016/04/largest-ever-number-of-vans-recorded-on-british-roads-as-commercial-vehicle-show-2016-opens/)Then add all the busses, motorbikes, electric vehicles, pushbikes, lorries and you have a horrendous amount of insects killed, and with car ownership going up every year, I can't be bothered to put a citation, but believe me it is there, we have a major insect killing machine on our hands called the public highway..', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529443397000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4623221', u'id': u'117202822', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swiftie77', u'text': u'In 1970’s one in four of the world population was at risk from malnutrition. Today that figure is one in ten with a population increase of 1.5 billion over that period.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529439738000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16249374', u'in_reply_to': u'117161699', u'id': u'117201582', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swiftie77', u'text': u'Given that a ban is now in place and that a partial ban on topical use on flowering crops is now two years in; when do you see any improvement bring measurable?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529439264000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16249374', u'in_reply_to': u'117177563', u'id': u'117201388', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swiftie77', u'text': u'The study in Germany has to be seen in the context of how it was done. It doesn’t say that this trend applies to areas outside those fixed locations so you can’t use the data to extract a national or multi regional trend. Useful study but limited.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529438588000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16249374', u'id': u'117201160', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swiftie77', u'text': u'Agreed at last some one has realised the obvious', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529437659000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16249374', u'in_reply_to': u'117086963', u'id': u'117200820', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Barbearian', u'text': u'Blanket ban on pesticides. Unlikely though, seeing the civil servant-businessman-politician axis running the show.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529427874000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2134650', u'id': u'117196950', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'minesboggled', u'text': u'It would be more efficient if we wipe the slate by adopting a new economic model, one centred on ecology - the economy that sustains life instead of profits.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529421398000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100481637', u'in_reply_to': u'117191924', u'id': u'117192990', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RTCevennes', u'text': u'This is also linked to the problem of plastics in the oceans killing the whales , fish turtles and other creatures, but nobody is connecting this to the oil companies. As well as polluting the air they are responsible for all the plastic which is made from oil.We should press for laws "The polluters should pay" to clean the air and collect the plastic.I read recently that two huge new chemical complexes are being constructed near Houston to convert oil to plastic.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529419586000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16788628', u'in_reply_to': u'117174954', u'id': u'117191924', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Marjakuusi', u'text': u'Again, I assumed you'd know what words mean. I thought I was dealing with a flawed analysis, not complete unawareness. Isn't gonna be the one sorting that out. Good luck', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529403832000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15024183', u'in_reply_to': u'117157281', u'id': u'117178009', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'HenkTennekes', u'text': u'I recognized the environmental hazards of neonicotinoid insecticides such as imidacloprid in 2009 when I read an article by Spanish ecotoxicologist Francisco Sánchez-Bayo on the dose-response characteristics of the compounds in arthropods in the journal Ecotoxicology. There were many similarities with the dose-response characteristics of carcinogenic nitrosamines. The effects are reinforced by exposure time and low exposure levels are effective upon prolonged exposure. Imidacloprid is persistent in soil and prone to leach from soil. Surface water in Holland was widely contaminated with imidacloprid. All ingredients for massive insect decline were there. I studied birds in decline and found out that all of them depended on insects, at least during breeding. When I presented the data to a group of experts called together by ornithologist Maarten Bijleveld in the summer of 2010 in Paris, David Gibbons of the RSPB brushed aside my thesis that imidacloprid was causing a catastrophe in the insect world. I have got the emails to prove it. I eventually decided to publish my data in a book, which I gave the title Disaster in the Making. Reviews appeared in the Independent and the Ecologist. Had my work been taken seriously there and then, an ecological crisis might have been prevented. It is ironic to read David Gibbons' statements on insect decline. I think he owes me an apology.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529403477000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'imidacloprid', u'effect': u'a catastrophe in the insect world'}], u'author_id': u'11632653', u'id': u'117177563', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'minesboggled', u'text': u'However uncomfortable, deflection of any kind risks concealing what it is that causes all human-induced environmental problems. 
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jun/19/james-hansen-nasa-scientist-climate-change-warning
The ‘real hoax is by leaders claiming to take action’. Absolutely it is. Were that not the case, we wouldn’t be in our current environmental predicaments, would we? Over 30 years of political limpness, expressing nothing but inaction on climate change - denial. And it's not just restricted to climate change - over 60 years since we were warned about there unrestrained use of pesticides. Ditto for other polluting chemicals, even those that enter food chains - including ours. We’ve been truly shafted by corporate-driven ‘governments’ who couldn’t give a toss about the environment therefore couldn’t give a toss about society. The chilling reality of what they’ve become. James Hansen, once again, is correct. 
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jun/11/brussels-criticised-over-delays-in-banning-toxic-chemicals
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jun/01/antibiotic-apocalypse-eu-scraps-plans-to-tackle-drug-pollution-despite-fears-of-rising-resistance
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/dec/20/european-commission-guilty-negligence-diesel-defeat-devices-draft-report-dieselgate
And the solution is so blatantly obvious. So simple. 
Why not cut polluting emissions generally? We don’t need the marketed shiny lifestyles that rob our environment - our life support system - to pay a minority of profiteering psychotics obsessed with control and ‘power’. Like all living things, we need an economy that supports life. An economy that promotes equity and quality of life - clean air to breathe, clean water to drink, food safe to eat, accommodation, education and life opportunities that promote the meaningful in human cultures. We don’t need bent politicians who allow corporations to dictate the rules designed to parasitise societies for profit. Society doesn’t need those types of ‘investors’.
We need a new economics.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529401265000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'all human induced environmental problems'}], u'author_id': u'100481637', u'in_reply_to': u'117085919', u'id': u'117174954', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Scullsworth', u'text': u'Wheres Jeremy Clarkson to call it all out as the concerns of lentil knitters? The knob.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529399943000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10792573', u'id': u'117173445', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'tytoalba1', u'text': u'An interesting juxtaposition with the article about the claims being made by an extraordinarily irresponsible pesticide company, also visible on the Guardian Environment news feed. From the article above:
And then there is the issue of urban spread. Housing schemes continue to encroach on our woods and heaths so that streets and buildings generate light pollution that leads nocturnal insects astray and interrupts their mating. “That is the reason we see most changes to insect life in south-east England, for that is where we see the greatest spread of cities and towns,” said Leather.
The simple reality is that there are multiple causes of insect population decline. Loss and disruption of habitat is bound to be a major factor. For all the ranting about insecticides, the extent of their effect on wild insect populations (and honey bees) is the subject of considerable uncertainty. We need more science.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529369124000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'117156009', u'id': u'117160622', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jayson Carmichael', u'text': u'Different ways of housing people needed. I can't have a battle of wits with an unarmed man. Goodbye.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529359918000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11054335', u'in_reply_to': u'117134107', u'id': u'117157281', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'toandfro', u'text': u'Genocide?? Don't be ridiculous. That's the kneejerk reaction that politicians fear when they try to have a sensible debate.
The 'replacement rate' for the UK is around 2.05, ie the average births per woman (fertility rate) that would result in a stable population. The actual fertility rate of UK people is less than 2.0. Which means that the current population growth is due entirely to net immigration. Therefore if a policy of zero net immigration were introduced, the long-term effect on population would be a slide downwards. Managing the change slowly over a long term is the right way to go, because we know from Japan's situation that rapid changes create their own difficulties.
So, no need for any of the draconian measures you mention. Just a proper reaction to the current situation. The exploding populations in many parts of the world each need different solutions. But fundamentally those countries need solution to be implemented at source. The 'west' simply cannot absorb the billions seeking a better life. But we can help them have it at home. Global population growth is unsustainable and that is crystal clear. Wildlife population declines are pretty much universal across the world and across species, genus etc.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529331618000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'117123207', u'id': u'117139042', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'Whilst there is nothing wrong with highlighting this catastrophe I do wish the guardian would chose some fresh ways to explore the harm we are doing to our planet & our food supply. The use of pesticides & herbicides isnt just killing wildlife as described, its in our food chain. Its not only effecting wildlife its effecting us too.
Look at fish farmed salmon, or rather don't if you don't want nightmares. Poring pesticides into the water to kill parasites & ethoxyquine as antioxidant in fish food to produce . Salmon the worlds most toxic food. 
Then there's Glyphosate poisoning our soils There is evidence to show that glyphosate in the food chain is having serious adverse effects on our health.
Unless you have access to previously untouched/uncultivated land, I don't think our food supply is safe. You can't get away from chemical residues anywhere. Tonnes of waste & chemicals are pored into our oceans each year, it is heavily polluted with micro plastics & residues, we poor gallons of pesticides into our fish farms & herbicides are washed into our oceans from agricultural runoff. Its no wonder farmed salmon look like this.But its not just effecting farmed fish, its effecting wild salmon too
Just recently I read a post on face book about the Tanzanian government planning a dam in the great Selous game reserve a world heritage site  It cynically pointed out that perhaps this will not go ahead due to its world heritage status, but the Tanzanian government has started felling trees anyway under the excuse its going to be flooded anyway we may as well cut it down & use it. 
Its a shame the guardian isnt posting articles like this more or opening articles like the knepp farm article for comment.
