Can we have a habitable climate now?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528329698000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18309811', u'in_reply_to': u'116667940', u'id': u'116687310', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FischerPrize', u'text': u'Non-EU passenger arriving in Europe from the UK have exactly the same arrival process as those arriving directly from a on-EU country.
Virgin is not owned by IAG. It is owned by Richard Branson and Delta Airlines, although KLM-Air France are about to purchase 30% from RB - if that still goes ahead.
IAG is a European company, headquartered in Madrid, with an executive office at the BA HQ at Heathrow. But the ownership is less than 50% British - but at the moment as an EU airline can fly from anywhere in the EU (including the UK) to the USA.
The UK will leave the Open Skies agreement when Brexit happens. From that point there is no Open Skies between the UK and the USA, unless an agreement is reached before then. The EU-USA Open Skies agreement will continue as before, but obviously will not include the UK. If BA were a truly European airline as you say, they would not be allowed to fly between the UK and the USA (unless the Americans agree to that), but would be allowed to fly from the EU to the USA.
I agree though that post-Brexit there will be a lot less demand to fly to or from the UK.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528301421000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2453816', u'in_reply_to': u'116646761', u'id': u'116676356', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ginen', u'text': u'This is upsetting.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528298892000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2853287', u'id': u'116674395', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ThanksNeolibZombies', u'text': u'BQSTART

Do you really think, given what I've written above, that I fly? I know the internet is full of utter dishonesty, but I find it incredible that you would think it likely I flew.
A carbon tax is about accounting for the costs of our actions. It wouldn't stop flying, but it would make the alternatives more attractive and it would significantly reduce the rapid expansion in such unconscionable activities. And yes, of course it would have to be global eventually to be fully effective, but that is something that would need to build up through a process of mutual trust. I don't for one moment think this obviously sane and rational policy is likely to happen before we are suffering some of the more truly dire consequences of our inaction.
You complain about jobs in the air industry, but what do you think people are going to do if they choose not to fly? Jobs will be created in other industries instead. And note that we aren't even talking about losing jobs that are currently there, just not expanding airports further.
And yes, of course I'm prepared for the costs of luxury goods flown in by airfreight to go up. BQENDBut that seems misleading as the 3% is for global use - in the UK we are at more like 7% of emissions from aviation, I think, and that would be a large proportion of our available carbon budget. Globally, if everyone flew at the same levels we do even now that would likely be catastrophic.
You describe a series of cuts we could make in other areas, all of which are sensible, but why would we be happy to make these more difficult changes before making the much easier reductions in our aviation use? As an individual, far and away the easiest change you can make to reduce your carbon emissions is to choose not to fly.

description: Editorial: A third runway at Heathrow airport is ultimately indefensible on environmental grounds
og_fields.og:description: Editorial: A third runway at Heathrow airport is ultimately indefensible on environmental grounds
og_fields.og:title: The Guardian view on Heathrow expansion: better never than so late | Editorial
text:
The decision to go ahead with the third runway at Heathrow was taken two years ago; Chris Grayling’s confirmation yesterday marked the point when it seemed to its promoters that enough of the opposition on the ground had been defeated, so it was safe to proceed with a final vote in three weeks’ time. If that is won, and all goes according to plan, the bulldozers will go in around 2021, when the inevitable cycle of cost overruns and slipping deadlines can begin, 31 years after the project was first mooted. By then the UK may be two years into a lengthy “transitional” post-Brexit period, and the bright economic forecasts which are used to justify the plan may be no more use than hot air balloons.
There is a case that air travel has made life better for many people and that more of it would continue to do so. Nearly two-thirds of Heathrow’s present traffic is leisure flying. Mass tourism has boosted the economy of many countries and greatly enlarged our experience of the world, and perhaps our sympathies as well. However unpleasant the experience of a modern airport can be, through which we are run like rats in a maze of shopping malls and security checks, it still seems better to many of us than being trapped in our own countries all year round. Heathrow as it stands today is an unimposing portal to Britain. Failing to expand it is simply sabotaging the country. Beyond that, the country is dependent, like all others, on air freight. So the plans for expansion are in some ways well motivated. We can even overlook the fact that they are promoted by Mr Grayling, a man notoriously unable to make even trains run on time.
Much of the opposition is simply nimbyism. Those West London Tory MPs who claim to be opposed to Heathrow’s third runway on environmental grounds, and then propose that it be built onto Gatwick or Stansted instead illustrate this clearly. There is some amusement to be derived from the rumoured machinations to allow the foreign secretary (the MP for local Uxbridge) to be out of the country on the occasion of the vote, so that he does not have to live up to his stated determination to oppose it even if he has to lie down in front of the bulldozers, but this is a frivolity, like most things about Mr Johnson. The serious objections to the plan remain, as they have been for most of this century, the environmental ones. The simple fact is that it is impossible to combine a commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 80% by 2050 with the strategic encouragement of air travel.
Mr Grayling’s statement made much play of technological advances. Aircraft will be quieter, cleaner, and greener, he said. It is entirely possible that they will be quieter, and the promise of an enforceable night time curfew when even the quieter planes will be silent must have done much to still some of the opposition from under the flight path. But the lasting damage the planes do is silent and far from the airport. It is their emissions in the upper atmosphere which drive climate change and all its disastrous effects. Nor can those be confined to the poorer parts of the world, as we’re already seeing. As the world warms, the price of mass tourism will be paid in mass migrations. It is true that aircraft have got lighter and more fuel efficient, but this is of no benefit to the environment if there are more of them, flying more often – and that is the underlying logic of the Heathrow expansion. In the long term, which gets closer every day, the only answer to the problem of fossil fuels is to keep them in the ground. Doing so demands that we keep aircraft on the ground as well. MPs should reject this plan when it comes to the vote.

article_tags: [Population, World news, Children, Society, Environment, United Nations, Climate change]
description: Letters: Arthur Erken from the United Nations Population Fund and Robin Maynard from Population Matters respond to a Guardian editorial on family planning
og_fields.og:description: Letters: Arthur Erken from the United Nations Population Fund and Robin Maynard from Population Matters respond to a Guardian editorial on family planning
og_fields.og:title: Respecting women’s rights and the planet key to family planning | Letters
text:
I read with interest your editorial (One child, two children or too many? Planning families is not easy, 4 June). The United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) strongly agrees that “crude attempts to raise and lower birthrates are unlikely to produce sustainable solutions”. Instead, they are more likely to violate internationally agreed human rights standards and cost women their freedom or lives.
UNFPA promotes the view that family planning should always be firmly based on the right of all individuals to control their fertility and therefore determine freely the number of their children, which your sensible recommendations on education and empowerment of women and greater access to family planning support.
This right was proclaimed 50 years ago, in May 1968, at the international conference on human rights. The principle of informed free choice, without any coercion, is essential to the long-term success of family planning.
Experience has repeatedly shown that challenging population dynamics (as a result of high or low fertility) are best addressed by respecting women’s rights. Sadly, more than 200 million women lack access to modern contraception, with about $700m needed to meet their demand for something that will save and transform their lives. This requires a collective will and funding to provide women with the means to exercise their right to determine their family size.Arthur ErkenDirector, division of communications and strategic partnerships, UNFPA, the United Nations Population Fund
• Your editorial on the implications of family size and population erroneously bought into the narrow economic narrative that this is simply an issue of productivity, resources and dependency ratios. It is partly about those things – but far more importantly and fundamentally it is about our planetary crisis. In the era of climate change and with the “sixth mass extinction” well under way, we must recognise that each one of the extra 15,000 people added to our global population every hour places more demands on our already stressed planet and its ecosystems. Everyone on Earth deserves a fair, sustainable share of our planet’s resources – but that human right will only be possible if we learn to moderate both our numbers and consumption.
Yes, there are challenges associated with lowering birthrate and promoting smaller families. Those are infinitely easier to solve than the environmental devastation exacerbated by the increasing billions of people on our finite planet. This is solvable through ethical, non-coercive means and the available technology of family planning – but only if we grasp the nettle now and take positive action.Robin MaynardDirector, Population Matters

article_tags: [Environment, Climate change, Climate change, Climate change scepticism, Tony Abbott, Australia news, Science]
description: The Australian Environment Foundation has secured a former prime minister to speak. But what does it actually do?
og_fields.og:description: The Australian Environment Foundation has secured a former prime minister to speak. But what does it actually do?
og_fields.og:title: Inside the AEF, the climate denial group hosting Tony Abbott as guest speaker
text:
Securing a former prime minister to speak at your organisation is no doubt a coup for many groups.
Singapore’s Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy recently got Kevin Rudd. Australia’s Nelson Mandela Day committee has snaffled Julia Gillard for their next annual lecture.
What about our most recent former PM, Tony Abbott?
Next month, Abbott will deliver the “2018 Bob Carter Commemorative Lecture” to the Australian Environment Foundation (AEF), where the ticketing site says he’ll talk about “Climate Change and Restraining Greenhouse Gas Emissions”.
The AEF is an “environment charity” that promotes views that wind turbines make you sick, that human-caused climate change isn’t really a thing, and that environmentalists (the other sort) are killing farmers, fisheries and the economy. 
Abbott’s lecture will no doubt pick up from his speech in London in December, where he delivered a suite of climate science denial talking points to the Global Warming Policy Foundation.
So who, or what, is the AEF? To look into its history, and the people involved with it, is to take a deep dive into Australia’s climate science denial network.
But first let’s look at the AEF right now because, as an “environmental charity”, Abbott’s next port of call doesn’t seem to do very much.
Latest figures available from the Australian Charities and Not-for-Profits Commission show that in 2016, the charity declared an annual income of just $1,175.
The AEF’s YouTube channel has just 11 subscribers and has posted only one video, from December 2016.
In May 2017, the AEF lent its logo to a letter to US President Donald Trump to offer “enthusiastic support” for his commitments to withdraw from the UN Paris climate agreement. But between July 2017 and February 2018, there was virtually nothing posted on its website.
Much of that website, including the “Climate News” section, is content from former Institute of Public Affairs fellow Alan Moran and postings that variously dismiss human-caused climate change and renewable energy, in particular wind power. 
The charity has two other trading names listed with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission – the Australian Climate Science Coalition (ACSC) and ListenToUs – but both of these seem to be defunct.
The ACSC at one time was receiving cash from a US affiliate, the American Climate Science Coalition, itself an offshoot of the International Climate Science Coalition. The ACSC received $107,000 from its American donors in 2009 and 2010, after which the donations stopped.
The ACSC didn’t do any actual climate science, but did host talks from folks like climate science denier and self-titled “high priest of climate scepticism” Christopher Monckton, who once compared then Australian government climate policy advisor Professor Ross Garnaut to a Nazi. 
The AEF’s ListenToUs website was an attempt to generate an online social media campaign against carbon pricing. But now, either the AEF has a new line in promoting “Male Strippers Melbourne” and “Home Cleaning Melbourne” or some sort of hackery or lapsing of domain names has eventuated.
When Abbott delivers his lecture, he’ll be introduced by Dr Peter Ridd, the controversial marine scientist sacked from James Cook University for alleged multiple breaches of its code of conduct. 
Ridd has been a director at the AEF since 2005. That’s a neat segue into the AEF’s history.
In late 2004, the Institute of Public Affairs – by then already pushing out climate science misinformation – held its “Eureka forum” to work out how to push back against “environmental fundamentalism” that, it claimed, was “denying farmers, foresters, fishermen, prospectors, miners, beekeepers, 4WD enthusiasts and others access rights, property rights, water rights”.
As part of this push back, the AEF was formed in early 2005 with the Institute of Public Affairs as its business address. Then IPA boss Mike Nahan and IPA staffer Jennifer Marohasy were both founding directors. These days the IPA says it has nothing to do with the AEF.
Over the years, the AEF has consistently promoted climate science denialism. The group has campaigned against marine parks, carbon taxes, climate science and wind farms, which it says make people sick.
For several years, the AEF gained a little notoriety thanks to TV celebrity Don Burke serving as its chairman.
The AEF’s current chair, lawyer Tom Bostock, was also a board member of the Lavoisier Group – another collection of conservative white males that came together in 2000 to fight Australia’s engagement in United Nations climate agreements and to attack the science of human-caused climate change.
Another AEF director is Tom Quirk, a former director at the IPA and a member of the ACSC advisory panel when that project was a thing. Quirk is involved with another effort to convince right wingers that human-caused climate change science is a massive con. 
The unincorporated “Climate Study Group”, of which Quirk is a member, has been running a series of odd adverts in the Australian.
The half-page ads have evoked the philosopher Socrates and some cod-psychology to claim sea levels are not rising, global warming isn’t caused by rising levels of greenhouse gas, and we should all be preparing for a coming ice age.
So what of Abbott’s lecture? The AEF says it “established the lecture series to commemorate the life and work of Bob Carter”, who was an AEF director at the time of his death in 2016 (Carter was affiliated with 10 or more climate science denial groups around the world). 
Abbott’s lecture will be the second in the “series” – the first was delivered in November 2016 by Canadian denialist Tim Ball (that’s the one YouTube video on AEF’s channel).
At the time, Ball was in Australia with former One Nation senator Malcolm Roberts.
Ball’s speech was a classic of the climate denial genre, mixing conspiracy theories, hatred of “leftists” and disregard for any evidence contradicting a view that climate change is the “biggest deception in history”.
Ball claimed the United Nations, led by a favourite enemy of climate science denialists, Maurice Strong, was attempting to exert global control over people’s lives to push a socialist agenda. Ball even used a slide of a quote from Strong, supposedly uttered at the 1992 Rio Earth summit, which read: “Isn’t the only hope for this planet that the industrialised civilisation collapses? Isn’t it our responsibility to bring that about?”
This quote is widely used among climate science deniers as evidence of the nefarious motives of the UN. The quote was actually from two years earlier, when Strong was talking to a journalist about the plot of a novel he hoped to write (incidentally another Maurice, Tony Abbott’s former lead business advisor Maurice Newman, has also used the fake quote in a 2015 opinion column in the Australian. Until recently, One Nation also ran the quote on its website).
I emailed three of the listed AEF directors – Ridd, Bostock, and Alan Oxley, the former Hawke-era diplomat and now chairman of the APEC Study Centre at RMIT University. 
I asked about the charity’s activities, how they secured Abbott’s appearance and the charity’s apparently defunct projects (including the Melbourne strippers) but I didn’t get a response.
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

article_tags: [Immigration and asylum, UK news, France, Europe, Emmanuel Macron, Refugees, Climate change]
description: Letters: What happens while cases are reviewed, asks Dick Taverne; Libby Ruffle calls on European leaders to accept their obligations
og_fields.og:description: Letters: What happens while cases are reviewed, asks Dick Taverne; Libby Ruffle calls on European leaders to accept their obligations
og_fields.og:title: Harsh immigration rules still apply – and Macron is no hero | Letters
text:
On 21 May you published my letter about Owais Raja, one of the numerous cases of immigrants who have been deprived of their indefinite leave to remain under paragraph 322(5) of the immigration rules, because of errors in their tax returns, even though the HMRC found them not to be deliberate. The Home Office has now announced a welcome review. But what happens while the review takes place? Under para 322(5) the victims may no longer face the threat of immediate deportation, but they are barred from earning a living or access to the NHS. They cannot pay for food, their rent or any urgent medical treatment. Are they and their families to beg and sleep on the streets? Surely there must be an immediate, at the very least temporary, restoration of their leave to remain while their cases are reconsidered?Dick TaverneLiberal Democrat, House of Lords
• Timothy Garton Ash (1 June) is not the only one to fear for the future of the European project. However, I find fighting talk about reclaiming “European sovereignty” as depressing and shortsighted as Brexit. Mass migration is not a “threat” to Europe; it is a complex human struggle driven by war, poverty and climate breakdown, issues in which we are globally complicit. The approval in April of a new immigration law cuts asylum application deadlines, doubles detention times and will introduce a one-year prison term for entering France illegally. In northern France, police are confiscating tents and removing shoes from refugees. This does not make Macron “impressive” and “compelling”, it makes him cruel and miserly – the same as all other European leaders who are overwhelmed by their obligations and so retreat to identity politics. We might feel reassured pretending this emperor is the one wearing shiny new clothes, but we have a greater responsibility to our neighbours – people, not “juggernauts” about to “trample us”. Less “courage”, fellow Europeans, perhaps, and more compassion.Libby RuffleWoodbridge, Suffolk

This would take some of the load off daytime power supplies, perhaps giving some slack for a more reliable night-time supply.', u'recommendation_count': u'16', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929731000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14859390', u'id': u'116510276', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DesertStorm17', u'text': u'Utter garbage, either you or your brother have an issue with reality. Perhaps both.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929725000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18150046', u'in_reply_to': u'116509510', u'id': u'116510271', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'hogsback', u'text': u'Pedant point: white panels (and ice) don’t reflect heat as such. They reflect back light and stop it being converted into heat at the surface. The sun emits negligible amounts of thermal infrared (which is what we usually think of as radiant heat).', u'recommendation_count': u'16', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527931909000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4346048', u'in_reply_to': u'116511109', u'id': u'116511352', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DownhamDave', u'text': u'That is concrete, steel and glass. London is often a few degrees warmer than the countryside and that's for temperature in the twenties.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527931901000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15494403', u'in_reply_to': u'116509999', u'id': u'116511348', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID1340579', u'text': u'Good to see the Guardian reporting on people NOT dying for a change!', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929611000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3735563', u'id': u'116510215', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'apaliteno', u'text': u'How much difference is painting a roof really going to make in such extreme heat? Although the temperatures are very high it does appear to have one saving grace-it's a rather dry heat', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929584000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10617025', u'id': u'116510203', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LomasNX', u'text': u'“India's renewable energy sector is amongst the world's most active players in renewable energy utilization, especially solar and wind electricity generation.As of 31 March 2018, India had grid connected installed capacity of about 69.02 GW non-conventional renewable technologies-based electricity capacity exceeding the capacity of major hydroelectric power for the first time in history” - Wikipedia Sounds like India should help others.', u'recommendation_count': u'16', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527931790000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16377660', u'in_reply_to': u'116507605', u'id': u'116511308', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FlamingoWader', u'text': u'A semi basement can be several degrees cooler than higher floors. I took advantage of this in Northern India in 2012. Churches here too feel cooler in summer so are a good place to be.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929417000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17507621', u'id': u'116510123', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MrakS', u'text': u'That was my point. That chap could afford air con and was boss of a building site. He wasn't going to die.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929361000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4072239', u'in_reply_to': u'116509328', u'id': u'116510091', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SimonAlfred', u'text': u'"....poor resource management...."They would have been far wealthier if it wasn't for the empire. Your point about deforestation was also a million miles off given how the empire exported millions of tonnes of timber from India during its rule.', u'recommendation_count': u'23', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527931750000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4284671', u'in_reply_to': u'116510396', u'id': u'116511291', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Philippe Drevet', u'text': u'At the beginning of the text it is not an air-conditionning but a desert cooler that consume little electricity. Google the term "desert cooler" to understand better', u'recommendation_count': u'25', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527931704000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13391742', u'id': u'116511270', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'madtom1999', u'text': u'Phase change materials can work well for air conditioning. Ironically putting solar panels on roofs to power the air conditioning can have a better cooling effect than the air conditioning by insulating the often poor roof. Well thought out housing designs may cost a little bit more but pay for themselves long before the building goes out of fashion.', u'recommendation_count': u'14', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929310000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1175869', u'in_reply_to': u'116508365', u'id': u'116510075', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'scruggs', u'text': u'Maybe stop people in the UK overusing air conditioning everywhere so that India can use it when they really need it.', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929294000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3189704', u'in_reply_to': u'116508365', u'id': u'116510068', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NoMoreMrNice', u'text': u'It's a fair point re the global emissions (although, unfairly, India are going to have to do without some of the west's energy extravagances).
But the problems with air conditioning are local as well as global. They literally heat up the city to cool a room. It isn't a viable solution to just aircon the tropics towards pleasanter temperatures', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527931675000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3919949', u'in_reply_to': u'116509906', u'id': u'116511254', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Waterllili', u'text': u'Oh, I see- I did not know that- thanks. Ok, what about allow drinking when temperatures raise over 30 regardless of the month of the year? heat-related deaths start at outdoor temperatures most of us may feel comfortable in, for example just under 25°C in London.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929160000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17964816', u'in_reply_to': u'116509545', u'id': u'116510013', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'madtom1999', u'text': u'Because powered air conditioning raises the local temperature to the point it nullifies the air conditioning.Air conditioners can just about lower the temperature indoors to 15C below outside. Houston Texas is more than 15C warmer than the surrounding desert in summer.', u'recommendation_count': u'17', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929123000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1175869', u'in_reply_to': u'116508361', u'id': u'116509999', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DownhamDave', u'text': u'India was wealthier and in better shape when we left than many places. However it spent fifty years barely progressing.', u'recommendation_count': u'27', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527931669000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15494403', u'in_reply_to': u'116508341', u'id': u'116511252', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'apaliteno', u'text': u'It says "up to 5 degrees"-I suspect it's dependent on other factors outside of one's immediate control and likely to be far less, normally. My property in central Luzon, not so much a house as a slow cooker, becomes unbearably hot by evening. The house a few yards away is noticeably cooler, probably due to its avoiding the afternoon sun', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527931511000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10617025', u'in_reply_to': u'116510760', u'id': u'116511164', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NoMoreMrNice', u'text': u'The parks thing seems to be the same reason ours are locked overnight - fears of what might go on in unmonitored public spaces. https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/no-garden-city-parks-here-locked-through-the-day/articleshow/61558017.cms
And, as here, the fact of it being locked probably adds to the sense of it being unsafe. Hopefully they learn otherwise from this trial.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929044000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3919949', u'in_reply_to': u'116509304', u'id': u'116509971', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'vladAlban', u'text': u'India is well aware of the most economic way to generate power - and knows it isn't coal. A report a year ago said they had cancelled 14GW of new coal power-stations, as the price of solar had fallen to make it cheaper than coal - and India is quite a good place for solar pv.
Of course there are many priorities in India - electricity is very important, but not at the scale used in the US or EU. A small amount of electricity in each home will make a massive difference to lives, with lighting,clean cooking and food refrigeration. Air-con uses a lot of power, whether it's renewable or fossil fuel, for limited gains.
Even more important is provision of clean water and sanitation to everyone. That will save far more lives than painting roofs white, but will also cost a lot more. That needs to be a government priority.', u'recommendation_count': u'23', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1527929033000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4232186', u'in_reply_to': u'116507605', u'id': u'116509968', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SimonAlfred', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

description: ‘Common sense’ policies such as free water and reflective roof paint save lives as temperatures near 50C
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: ‘Common sense’ policies such as free water and reflective roof paint save lives as temperatures near 50C
og_fields.og:title: India slashes heatwave death toll with series of low-cost measures
text:
One morning last week, Mohammad Javed wheeled an air conditioner on to the pavement outside his catering business in Delhi, placed his chair a metre away, sat down and did not move all day. When the machine ran out of water, he asked passing boys to fetch a bucket. When he had to give directions to workers in the building across the lane, he shouted. Every few minutes, he took a long swig from his water bottle and spat the contents on to the ground without swallowing. “Ramadan,” he explained.
Northern India, like neighbouring Pakistan, is in the grip of a heatwave, with temperatures reaching 47C. A blanket of hot air has settled on Delhi clearing pavements across the usually busy capital. India is particularly vulnerable to temperature increases associated with climate change. Since 1992, about 25,000 Indians are estimated to have died because of heatwaves. Yet the country is quietly optimistic that it can prevent at least some of those deaths.
In the past two years, the numbers dying from heat-related illnesses has fallen sharply, from 2,040 in 2015 – when roads melted in the searing heat – to half that the following year and to a little over 200 in 2017, according to government data.
Public health advocates say this has been a triumph of common sense. A combination of public awareness campaigns, training for medical staff and simple policy changes – such as unlocking the gates of public gardens during the day –have averted thousands of deaths for little cost.
The catalyst was a heatwave in May 2010 in Ahmedabad, the largest city in the western state of Gujarat, that killed more than 1,100 people, and prompted authorities to seek help. “The first thing was making people aware that heat can kill,” said Parthasarathi Ganguly, a professor of public health and former World Health Organisation official.
“India is a tropical country, so people are used to heat: they take it as a natural phenomenon. They say, it will be hot – what’s new?”
Ever wondered why you feel so gloomy about the world - even at a time when humanity has never been this healthy and prosperous? Could it be because news is almost always grim, focusing on confrontation, disaster, antagonism and blame?
This series is an antidote, an attempt to show that there is plenty of hope, as our journalists scour the planet looking for pioneers, trailblazers, best practice, unsung heroes, ideas that work, ideas that might and innovations whose time might have come.
Readers can recommend other projects, people and progress that we should report on by contacting us at theupside@theguardian.com
Under Ahmedabad’s action plan – first implemented in 2013, when temperatures rose so high it risked triggering organ failure – school days were reduced, government work programmes ceased, and free water was distributed in busy areas. White reflective paint was applied to roofs in slum communities, cutting temperatures in homes by up to five degrees.
In hospitals, staff were trained to identify early signs of heat stroke, including dizziness or severe diarrhoea. Instead of waiting in stifling wards, patients were rushed to dedicated cool rooms equipped with fans, ice packs and, electricity supply permitting, air conditioning.
“Doctors don’t go on vacation any more when it’s hot,” said Anjali Jaiswal, of the US-based National Resource Defense Council, which advised on the plan. “They watch the temperature and make sure the hospital is staffed.”
Ahmedabad already had plenty of charities willing to distribute water. “They see it as an act of god,” Ganguly said. The city government simply allocated each charity a zone, to ensure the whole city was covered. The gates of city gardens, usually closed in the daytime, were opened so that hawkers, traffic police and rickshaw pullers could seek shade. “The council didn’t spend a rupee,” Ganguly said.
The first test of the new system was in May 2014 when, he says, temperatures again reached the levels that had killed so many. “According to our initial estimates, 800 fewer people died,” he said. “In terms of cost per lives saved, it is one of the most effective interventions in public health until now.” Since then, 11 more cities have adopted similar heat action plans, and one is currently in the works for Delhi.
India’s national disaster management authority is aiming to reduce the death toll from excessive heat to zero. So far this year, government officials say, the heat has killed 11 people. Temperatures will drop across India at the end of this month with the arrival of the monsoon rains.
This article is part of a series on possible solutions to some of the world’s most stubborn problems. What else should we cover? Email us at theupside@theguardian.com

Why was it warmer? Why colder?"
My country has the world's continual human civilisation and the climate has changed during the 60,000 years that humans have been here. From 60,000 to 20,000 years ago the climate was colder and there were valley glaciers in Tasmania and snow melt fed rivers draining inland from the Australian Alps, Barrington Tops and the New England Plateau. At this time atmospheric CO2 was between 190 and 200 ppm resulting in a reduced greenhouse effect compared to that of the last 9,000 years. The world was in a glacial period. The oceans were 120 metres lower and it was possible to walk from Hobart at the southern latitude equivalent of Toronto to equatorial Port Moresby.
19,000 years ago Northern Hemisphere high latitude summer insolation (NHHLSI) peaked causing the vast continental glacial icesheets that covered North American to just south of the Canadian border and northern Eurasia to start melting. The meltwater from this regional warming stopped the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) stopping the flow of cold dense saline water to the Southern Ocean. In the absence of this cooling water, the Southern Ocean warmed oxidising carbon rich oceanic oozes and releasing CO2 which over the next 10,000 years increased astmospheric CO2 from 200 to 280 ppm causing global greenhouse warming, retreat of the vast North American and north Eurasian continental glacial icesheets and sea rise of 120 metres or more. As this CO2 rise and consequent global warming took over 10,000 years, the rate of warming was much slower than that which we have seen in the last century. The people of my country witnessed the inundation of wide continental shelves and found themselves separated from their people in New Guinea and Tasmania by dangerous seas.
We are currently in an interglacial period. There have been many such periods over the last 2.6 million years. Modern humans were around at the time of the last interglacial which was hotter than the current preindustrial interglacial was because NHHLSI was higher. The last 2.6 million years have seen alternations between glacial and interglacial periods initiated by NHHLSI changes but driven by changes in atmospheric CO2. 
Over the last 9,000 years of the current interglacial NHHLSI has slowly but steadily declined resulting in slow global cooling. The greenhouse warming of the last century and a half which has seen atmospheric CO2 increase from 280 to over 400 ppm has overwhelmed the slight cooling of a slowly declining NHHLSI resulting in the global warming we have seen over that period.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528164128000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'the global warming of the last two centuries'}, {u'cause': u'what', u'effect': u'the climate to change pre - human civilisation'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'a reduced greenhouse effect'}, {u'cause': u'northern hemisphere high latitude summer insolation', u'effect': u'the vast continental glacial icesheets that covered north american to just south of the canadian border and northern eurasia to start melting'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'global greenhouse warming'}, {u'cause': u'nhhlsi was higher', u'effect': u'was'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'slow global cooling'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'the global warming'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'116581006', u'id': u'116607375', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ramAustralia', u'text': u'You didn't research that one too deeply did you? "So whatever facts are presented, they get dismissed."
Don't be silly. In asking you to provide direct links or references to peer reviewed papers published in proper scientific journals, to substantiate your claims, I asking you to provide links to scientific papers that present facts. This you have yet to do.
"So how can they make their case if people refuse to listen."
People make their case for a particular scientific discovery based on the evidence as presented in a peer reviewed paper which people read rather than listen to. I don't refuse to read peer reviewed papers published in proper scientific journals.
"Yet the people that get called 'deniers' are usually not doing what 'warmists' do; they are not claiming absolute certainty about the future."
I know what science denial is, having done postgraduate studies in evolution, but have no idea what you mean by 'warmists'. "They" (the people you refer to as 'deniers') "are not suggesting drastic policy changes on future unknowns in an incredibly complex system."
Complexity is common in science but often boils down like the current global warming to one major cause. Treating that cause can achieved without major policy decisions but with sensible technological change as my country has shown in the recent past.
"They" (your 'deniers') "accept climate change; but they say the science is not settled."
Science is never entirely settled but rarely entirely unsettled. The cause of the global warming of recent centuries is settled. Which part of climate science are your 'deniers" saying is not settled?

 "then it is equally wrong to accept arguments for global warming by listening to media reports".

Very recent history - Australia re: refugees, Much of Europe re refugees - would suggest such actions by citizens to be either impossible or ineffectual.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528153125000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15326060', u'in_reply_to': u'116579288', u'id': u'116605509', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Stalga', u'text': u'The Saudis are a member of OPEC, they don't set production levels or price on their own, and we don't buy direct from them.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528115097000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17200335', u'in_reply_to': u'116567690', u'id': u'116583442', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"Here we have cities expanding into peri-urban agricultural land or grasslands/nature reserves."
My activism in the early 1970s and consequent employment led to the establishment of a number a large national parks and nature reserves from tall forested country to desert grasslands. Near to now and nearer to where I now live, my daughter declared Australia's largest peri-urban national park 500 metres from my house and 11 km from the city centre and extending to Sunshine Coast hinterland.
"People clear fell their blocks to plant their spikey minimalist gardens."
After I felled the Brazilian Pepperbush, Chinese Celtis, Viburnum, Pride of Bolivia, Poinsianna, African Tulip, Queen Palm and Alexander Palms, I added to the native species that were already there. They now total over 150 species. Some are a bit spikey, particularly the Citrus australis or Round Lime.
"Then they build their six star energy efficient homes,"
Our small home was built in the early '70s. It already had good roof insulation and a reverse cycle air conditioner when we bought it early this century. The larger of those 150 plus native species provide good shade in summer when the sun is directly overhead and allow the sun to angle under their canopy at this time of year. We also have large secure screens front and back which allow a cooling through breeze. So we only use that air conditioner on those days when the wet bulb temperature exceeds 34-35 degrees C and at such times a set of solar panels covers its energy use and that of the overhead fan. Unlike my washing machine it has no stars on its side wall.
"buy an electric car"
My fuel efficient Corolla is now getting old and may soon be up for replacement but an electric car equivalent would be much more expensive than similar new fuel efficient small cars. However many cars are left at home in my commuter suburb while there owners catch public transport to work and an electric car left at home could be charging from those rooftop solar panels.
"then pat themselves on the back about how 'green' they are." 
I've never used your term "green" but if their homes, like mine are energy efficient, and they're charging their electric cars from their rooftop solar panels, and if like me their growing large native trees some of which are spikey, they are paying their part in reducing net CO2 emissions, which is a good thing. If like me they also have a rich native plant biodiversity at all canopy levels, they are also providing important habitat for native animals, which is also a good thing.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528114991000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'my activism in the early 1970s and consequent employment', u'effect': u'the establishment of a number a large national parks and nature reserves from tall forested country to desert grasslands'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'116565447', u'id': u'116583345', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'When you say "If they" (peer reviewed papers published in proper scientific journals) "are linked on a sceptic blog, they are dismissed as coming from a 'denier blog'", the example you give of what you call a 'sceptic blog' is No Tricks Zone which is misnomer as it's full of tricks. I was once provided with a link to that website to provide further links to peer reviewed papers published in proper scientific journal to substantiate my correspondent's claim. You should really try to keep up.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528113648000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'rises in sea levels'}], u'author_id': u'2160929', u'in_reply_to': u'116564150', u'id': u'116582083', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Thorlar1', u'text': u'Of course the military is going to approach the problem from within their bias confirming echo chamber, that's what interest groups do. Wouldn’t expect our dinosaur government can find any of that information in their happy clapper bibles.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528150716000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18539905', u'in_reply_to': u'116595608', u'id': u'116604825', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TWOBOBS', u'text': u'You might want to ask why all these climate alarmists, particularly the wealthy ones, live in such massive, energy intensive houses? In fact they often own multiple energy intensive homes. Richard Branson says he believes in AGW...yet he owns an airline! Not to mention a tropical island retreat. Why are banks still funding multi-million coastal developments? Why are true believers still buying them? Where and how does the concerned environmentalist Al Gore live? Why do climate scientists fly around the world to conferences? If it is true, then why are the most ardent promoters of it not living their lives in accordance with their beliefs? This is all a very dangerous strategy. If the whole thing collapses, the left is finished for good, science is finished, and the environmental movement has been seriously damaged. No wonder they won't brook any opposition.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528150586000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13547697', u'in_reply_to': u'116588551', u'id': u'116604783', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TWOBOBS', u'text': u'All of them are eminent professors. How did they get to their positions if they don't have expertise and substantial publishing records!! Take off your blinkers! Just consider the situation. If the politics means that counter views will not receive funding, and papers will not get funded, then how can sceptics do the research to test the theory? The reality is there are many, many papers that do challenge the data and the conclusions, but whoever writes/cites them gets dismissed as 'deniers'! If they are linked on a sceptic blog, they are dismissed as coming from a 'denier blog' http://notrickszone.com/2017/01/02/crumbling-consensus-500-scientific-papers-published-in-2016-support-a-skeptical-position-on-climate-alarm/ 
Which is, no doubt, exactly what you'll do. So whatever facts are presented, they get dismissed. So how can they make their case if people refuse to listen? Yet the people that get called 'deniers' are usually not doing what 'warmists' do; they are not claiming absolute certainty about the future. They are not suggesting drastic policy measures on future unknowns in an incredibly complex system. They accept climate change; but they say the 'science is not settled'. They are not convinced that humans are causing it. If humans are the main factor, then I ask you again: what caused the climate to change pre-human civilisation? Why was it warmer? Or colder? Are you suggesting that if we weren't here, the climate would have remained stable forever? By the way, why do you think the marketing term changed from global warming to climate change? Can't you see the weaselling out? Now, hot or cold, dry or wet...climate change! Why didn't they just start from the position that "the climate can change rapidly, we need to develop adaptation and social/ecological resilience strategies". We are also vulnerable to other threats. Why fixate on CO2? What about asteroids? Or super-volcanoes? Or pandemics? Or cyber attacks? Or war? Or, or, or... There are many other apocalyptic things we can dwell on if we choose to....why CO2? What are the politics behind it? We are not really in control of this planet! The 'deniers' say the warmists cannot prove that CO2 will have/has had the effect that they are claiming. Hansen's own failed predictions  support that claim. The IPCC quote from the other thread supports that claim. Climategate showed the corruption. The vicious attacks on scientists who simply have other views shows the politicisation and cult-like thinking. That's what I don't like. The 97% consensus claim has been debunked over and over again, but people will not listen! Because you want action on something, because you think something is a noble cause, or because your job depends on it, doesn't mean a lie or an error can be used to justify it. Our armed forces-very much including Australia's- have not been in a defensive war since WW 2; that's why people hate us, not because of our freedoms, because we kill so many millions in wars of aggression.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528141876000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we kill so many millions in wars of aggression', u'effect': u'why people hate us not because of our freedoms'}, {u'cause': u'our freedoms', u'effect': u'why people hate us not because we kill so many millions in wars of aggression'}], u'author_id': u'14790303', u'in_reply_to': u'116580386', u'id': u'116601187', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'guest90', u'text': u'An absolutely brilliant book on this aspect of climate change, which cannot be missed if you are in any way interested (its a great read) is 'Tropic of Chaos' by Christian Parenti. It basically has the entire story from a geopolitical standpoint - lots of detail and very interesting predictions for various different countries. Also a really good interview with him here (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ELqZe6Xqwzc). 
From my perspective - and I wish people would get this - we need to recognise that batteries are not going to work for all sectors (pretty obvious) and that hydrogen is basically humanities only hope for full-on decarbonisation. 
And by 'hydrogen' all I mean initially is building hydrogen refuelling stations - they produce the hydrogen on-site and therefore require renewable energy, and so in this regard are fairly simple once you have found suitable locations for them.
So the situation is: Toyota are increasing production capacity to 30,000 cars per year by 2020, and will going to keep going up from there, and then there are 4 or 5 fuel cell/FCEV manufacturers building factories in China. And Korea, which will probably ramp up production in line with Toyota.
So this is what needs to happen - governments need to have the balls to build hydrogen refuelling stations and get off their fossil fuel imports - which shouldn't even need to be at all painful as the cost of hydrogen per km in the EU should easily reach 5c/km dispensed - and in fact just to prove this Bulgaria are building 10 stations by 2025. And this is a country (admittedly with good solar resources) that is right next to Russia and therefore has very low petrol prices to begin with.
So absolutely no argument about the financial viability or the economic basis - it really does point to the level to which the fossil fuel industry is pulling the strings policy-wise. And just to make clear: the amount of tax received by EU governments for fuel is miniscule when compared to income tax and other taxes; it is not that they are scared of losing this money. They are just either not up to speed on the issue or are essentially on the side of various oil lobbies.
We need to start understanding that hydrogen does not have an alternative for energy storage, winter heating, pre-existing transmission networks, industry heat & feedstock and yes - transport; because just as an example we would need 50% of the copper ever mined if we wanted to hook everything up to wires.
For those wanting to check up on the continuing decline of hydrogen production costs versus natural gas, Cédric Philibert who is a senior analyst at the IEA outlines the issues from a European perspective in a recent article (https://twitter.com/reupdateinfo/status/1000336768317771776) - this is the route we have to take - and then Equinor is confident that floating offshore wind will reach 3-4c/kWh by 2030 (so slightly better than figures he provides, although he does work for the IEA). 
Australia has far better renewable resources and recent investments there mark the start of a large export industry. 
We cannot keep avoiding hydrogen.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528130951000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'just as an example we would need 50 % of the copper ever mined if we wanted to hook everything up to wires', u'effect': u'we need to start understanding that hydrogen does not have an alternative for energy storage'}], u'author_id': u'17280722', u'id': u'116595608', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'The meteorologists are losing sleep over climate change. Just get on and do what is necessary as an indy and nag the local council.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528111073000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'in_reply_to': u'116567541', u'id': u'116579624', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'cnog01', u'text': u'So we can’t talk about the fact that climate change may lead to security threats and plan for them?

In these circumstances of course we need to consider security threats. We could move to zero emissions and those threats would remain.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528111068000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'climate change', u'effect': u'security threats and plan'}], u'author_id': u'12188930', u'id': u'116579619', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"All of them are eminent professors. "Take off your blinkers."
I don't have blinkers. I am more than willing to read the peer reviewed papers by these eminent professors which substantiate your claims about global warming and climate change and which have been published in proper scientific journals. But you won't provide references or links to these papers.
"Just consider the situation. If the politics mean that counter views will not get funding, the papers will not get funded, then how can sceptics do the research to test the theory."
All scientists are sceptics who do research to test their hypothesis. So all scientific research is done by sceptics. A scientific theory or fact is an hypothesis which has been tested independently by many researchers who as a result realise that it describes what really happening. All scientist revel in counter arguments but not counter views because science is not about views but instead is based on evidence. Scientists do not get funding for their views counter or otherwise but are funded on the quality of their research proposal and the quality of the work they have produced and published up to that time. Research grants award by research grant committees have nothing to do with politics and everything to with the quality of the proposals and of the proposers. description: Warning about conflicts, wars and mass migration is the wrong way to approach things
og_fields.og:description: Warning about conflicts, wars and mass migration is the wrong way to approach things
og_fields.og:title: Don't turn to the military to solve the climate-change crisis| Nick Buxton
text:
The Australian Senate’s declaration last month that climate change is a “current and existential national security risk” was clearly intended to inject much-needed urgency into the country’s climate policy stalemate. Bringing together the unusual bedfellows of military generals and environmentalists to warn about the dangers of climate change, it has the possibility to break though Australia’s culture wars on the issue. However, by framing climate change as a security matter, it also has significant consequences in shaping how we respond to a warming planet. As the climate crisis unfolds, is the military the institution we want to turn to for solutions?
The Australian Senate inquiry was initiated by the former Greens senator Scott Ludlam and heard from diverse actors, including humanitarian agencies and defence strategists. It examined the likely impacts of extreme weather on military infrastructure, the economy and the wider region. It concluded that “climate change is exacerbating threats and risks to Australia” and called for improved military preparedness, better studies of “risks” to Australia, and enhanced coordination between government agencies.
The question rarely asked is whose security are we talking about - security of what, for whom and from whom?
In this, Australia is following a well-worn path forged by the European Union and the United States. The Pentagon in 2003 was the first to talk about climate security, framing climate change as a “threat multiplier” that would exacerbate conflict, terrorism, mass migration and social instability. In 2008, the EU concurred saying that global temperature increases of more than 2 degrees (current predictions suggest we are heading for more than 3 degrees) would “lead to unprecedented security scenarios”.
Security is a modern day weasel word – who can be against security? The question rarely asked is whose security are we talking about - security of what, for whom and from whom? The US, EU and now Australian strategies, though, clearly state they are talking about the security of their respective nations in the face of “threats” usually coming from the consequences of climate change in neighbouring countries. 
The submission from Australia’s Department of Defence to the inquiry put it this way: “When climate impacts are combined with ethnic or other social grievances, they can contribute to increased migration, internal instability or intra-state insurgencies, often over greater competition for natural resources. These developments may foster terrorism or cross-border conflict.”
They argued that this “could lead to an increase in the demand for a wide spectrum of Defence responses including maintaining law and order following disasters”. The image they paint is a dystopian one, which assumes that climate change disruptions will lead to a dog-eat-dog world, causing conflicts and wars, and prompting millions to migrate – and this will require the military to deal with the ensuing chaos. 
The effect of this approach is to turn the victims of climate change into potential threats and to make a militarised response to the impact of climate change the default response. The Australian Senate report is more nuanced than some US Pentagon reports in advocating for a range of strategies, including additional climate finance and better disaster resilience planning. 
But by blurring the distinction between the military’s ideas of security and other “human security” approaches, it embraces and reinforces a military response to climate change. This can be seen in the report’s strong appeals to the military to expand its role in disaster relief, even though this typically is the most costly form of relief and can end up militarising humanitarian disasters as the world witnessed graphically in New Orleans in the aftermath of hurricane Katrina where deployed National Guards ended up shooting at flood victims. 
The Senate report has less focus on the way the impacts of climate change will vary dramatically depending on the level of poverty and vulnerability of the affected community. Nor does it challenge the economic structures or laws that have led to this inequality and vulnerability, such as the role of Australia’s trade policies in undermining rural livelihoods and disrupting food systems. This is not surprising. After all, the essence of “security” is to secure what already exists. This means securing a world order in which Australia’s per capita income is 25 times that of nearby Kiribati or Solomon Islands and where even in Australia 2.9 million people live under the poverty line. It is an approach that seeks to build walls to exclude the dispossessed rather than tackle the underlying causes that cause people to migrate – shown today most visibly in Australia’s inhumane treatment of refugees in Nauru.
 Australia’s experience of unprecedented heat waves and fires in recent years has already shown that climate change will have a big impact on the country and the wider region. But how those impacts play out will depend to a great degree on how we choose to respond. An approach that relies on military forces and barbed wire will worsen the crisis and create a world no one wants to live in. Real security emerges from recognising our interdependence, tackling injustice and inequality, and working together to protect those who are most vulnerable.
• Nick Buxton works at the Transnational Institute based in the Netherlands and is co-editor of The Secure and the Dispossessed: How the Military and Corporations are shaping a climate-changed world (Pluto Books, 2015)

og_fields.og:title: What is the carbon bubble and what will happen if it bursts?
text:
Investments amounting to trillions of dollars in fossil fuels – coal mines, oil wells, power stations, conventional vehicles – will lose their value when the world moves decisively to a low-carbon economy. Fossil fuel reserves and production facilities will become stranded assets, having absorbed capital but unable to be used to make a profit. This carbon bubble has been estimated at between $1tn and $4tn (£3tn), a large chunk of the global economy’s balance sheet.
Investors with high exposure to fossil fuels in their portfolios will be hurt, as those companies and assets cease to be profitable. Jobs will be lost in fossil fuel production and related industries. If the bubble bursts suddenly, as a new paper in Nature suggests it might, rather than gradually deflating over decades, then it could trigger a financial crisis. 
Arguably yes, in that it corrects what has long been a market failure. Currently, fossil fuel prices do not reflect the environmental damage the fuels do, in climate change and air and water pollution. If they were priced to take these external factors into account, they would cost much more and businesses would seek alternatives – that is the idea behind carbon pricing. However, adding those external costs at a stroke would send energy prices soaring, with far-reaching effects across the economy. That is why economists prefer to phase in more realistic pricing for carbon-rich fuels over time. And the converse is also true: if renewables and energy efficiency were to result in an unexpected plunge in demand for fossil fuels, independently of government actions, that could send fossil fuel prices through the floor, triggering a crisis among the millions of investors in those assets.
Probably, but it could encourage some countries to pump out more, at least in the short term. For instance, if demand for fossil fuels drops suddenly then the OPEC countries could flood the market with cheap oil and gas, leaving those with more expensive assets – shale, tar sands, Arctic drilling – unable to compete.
Again, not quite. Lots of other actions are still needed, not least because the world could adjust to lower fossil fuel demand with a glut of energy production. The transition to a low-carbon economy is happening, but still much too slowly. At current rates, we will smash through the 2C ceiling promised under the Paris agreement, with rises of 3C and higher forecast. Without strong further commitments on climate change from major nations, we will reach our emissions targets too late and face a future of locked-in global warming that will result in floods, droughts, heatwaves and losses to global agriculture.
China relies on high-cost fuel imports at present and is benefitting from its investments in renewables, as is Japan, which has also invested heavily in energy efficiency. The EU is likely to be another winner as it has also moved early to pursue a low-carbon path.
Middle Eastern oil-rich states have built their economies on fossil fuels, so would need to diversify, which some are beginning to talk about. Russia could see its domestic fossil fuel industries collapse. Canada and the US could also be at risk: with their production of high-cost unconventional oil and gas from tar sands and shale, they are vulnerable both to a drop in demand and a drop in fossil fuel prices, unless their industries have invested in renewable energy and greater efficiency.
A reversal of major nations’ support for low-carbon technology and a reversion to an over-reliance on fossil fuels, which in many cases would have to involve large taxpayer subsidies for the latter.

Your speculation (specious 'assertation') that the AMOC in the mechanism for heat getting to the depths is also nonsense, as is covered here, both in terms of some of the mechanisms for heat transfer, and most noticeably that thermal expansion due to ocean's warming has not been due to the AMOC (an area where it has actually contracted) and expansion has occurred elsewhere.

Great questions - what is the materiality of the study? This is known in Buddhist and Vishnu and Jain beliefs. Not news chaps. Look into the religions of India for your answers.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528372531000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'id': u'116702808', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dappler', u'text': u'You always read stuff here and there about ocean stratification and how dangerous it was for more rapid climate change, and it makes you idly wonder if acidification preceded stratification and this was at least partly exacerbated by a die off of organisms such as these, which was then masked by a mass extinction.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528371789000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4535565', u'id': u'116702103', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jhoptoad', u'text': u'This is why science is endlessly fascinating.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528371649000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10189992', u'id': u'116701986', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bonzetta', u'text': u'Could be good to leave the krill to do their water mixing & get eaten by whales, rather than hoover them up for human purposes.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528367826000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2888811', u'id': u'116698891', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Malware', u'text': u'Animals are providing a lot of free support of the ecological system and we should probably be wary of exterminating fauna with the abandon presently exhibited. Norway, a leading salmon farming nation, is destroying shrimp populations with its measures against salmon lice, that contribute to crustaceans also dying.', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528367290000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4243084', u'id': u'116698449', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CitizenWise', u'text': u'I’m just a prawn in the game of life...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528899557000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10551993', u'in_reply_to': u'116945365', u'id': u'116947393', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'norfolk1810', u'text': u'You seem very proud of your total ignorance of the basic facts about the issue on which you comment. Does make you look foolish though.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528897336000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4767901', u'in_reply_to': u'116923779', u'id': u'116945365', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CitizenWise', u'text': u'We know the exact biomass of shrimp in the sea do we-, Prawn crackers!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528871483000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10551993', u'in_reply_to': u'116816407', u'id': u'116923779', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Northforce', u'text': u'Both you and Dennis Horne are incorrect.Its very clear what Trenberth said, no matter what kind of pedantic spin you put on it.You should stick to preaching to the choir.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528736689000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18157694', u'in_reply_to': u'116808825', u'id': u'116856717', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GoldenAppleCorps', u'text': u'You don't know what stratified means do you? Perhaps you should learn some basic biology before questioning well established facts.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528633176000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4767901', u'in_reply_to': u'116772794', u'id': u'116810637', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gpwayne', u'text': u'Dennis Horne was correct. 
You should make familiarise yourself with the parts of a sentence i.e. subject and predicate. The subject of Trenberth's statement is the measurement of accumulating heat at the earth's surface. The predicate - that informs the subject - is the failure to figure out where the heat was, since they knew perfectly well the energy accumulation hadn't stopped, nor had it reduced.
The use of the word 'travesty' is also key to understanding the statement, since it is defined as 'a false, absurd, or distorted representation of something'. Clearly, this cannot apply to heat, which is a passive phenomena and not a representative of anything except radiation; it applies only as a characterisation of their failure to figure out where the heat had gone.
Then they found it, and the whole issue was consigned to history, (except for climate change deniers, since they don't have any science to back up their idiotic claims).', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1528629808000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2947466', u'in_reply_to': u'116795041', u'id': u'116808825', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Northforce', u'text': u'Wrong..He said.."[Trenberth in Climategate1, 2009] The fact is that we can’t account for the lack of warming at the moment and it is a travesty that we can’t"
