No place to land a helicopter.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529378641000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'117082142', u'id': u'117162461', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'From the article above it's obvious that at least one of the expedition members was neither white nor a man.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529378436000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'117086081', u'id': u'117162425', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'I appreciated the fact you bravely took the time to leave your comment here on what was probably an unexpected overwhelming critique of ythis expedition. I do fully understand the importance of these pristine habitats & I as much as the next person I care deeply about ensuring they are preserved. Which was on my part the reason for my concerns posted on this forum.
I do fear the direction wildlife conservation is taking as a whole & some times the arrogant righteous attitude occasionally displayed by science professionals. I do sometimes struggle to understand the relevance of cataloguing organisms as a means to conserve them over simply respecting those ecosystems right to exist. I feel perhaps that some times it is the wrong approach to attempt to provide a "value" in terms how will it benefit Humans rather than encouraging a respect for nature as a life support system. 
Evidently if those ancient pristine habitats/ecosystems have been lost, then we are unable to learn anything about how the natural world works or how to help reestablish them. Perhaps had the article offered greater insight into the actual discoveries & not come across as a ego-trip for a privileged few it may have been received better. 
I would still highlight my concerns regards exactly how science intends to preserve this wonderful gem without commodifying it & therefore damaging the very thing you seek to protect. I personally feel the past models of monetizing nature hasn't helped to preserve them. Of course with modern technology the wall of stone isnt a barrier to those that may wish to exploit it for profit. As you point out perhaps its the duty of journalists like yourself to highlight the dangers of logging to dwindling pristine natural places like Lico. We require a cultural change in our attitudes to the natural world so we "value" it as whole not its select parts, I feel that's where conservationists & journalists can help most.
In this sense i think this article missed a very rare opportunity to do that.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529373179000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'117149277', u'id': u'117161488', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AnVeMi', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

Deposited there by birds, no doubt.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529348516000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17324734', u'id': u'117149370', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'davjon', u'text': u'Thats the end of that place then, now it has been discovered, it will be only a matter of time before humans destroy the unique habitat', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529348494000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4054190', u'id': u'117149363', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JeffreyBarbee', u'text': u'Dear Readers,
Its encouraging and exciting to have so many people comment on this story. 
This was a fast, early look at an expedition that took years in the making and was put together to place the most comprehensive set of relevant local and international scientists on top of what is likely one of the most interesting mountains found in Africa in a long time. Shrill calls to the contrary, it is only through understanding these forest systems and treasuring them through science that we will be able to protect them. 
Time is running out. 
It was heartbreaking on this expedition to see the destruction of nearby Mount Socone, a forest every bit as magical as Lico’s but with no protective wall. We spent time in both forests. In only three years at least half the Socone forest has been cleared for short term agriculture and timber. Millions of years of evolution, countless numbers of plants and animals, all lost for just a few years of cultivation that could have been financed by the cost of the laptop you wrote your angry missive on.
The truly sad fact is that the forests of Mozambique are disappearing. They are being wiped out today by slash and burn agriculture as well as the international appetite for rare and beautiful hardwoods. If we are going to save Mozambique’s mountain forests, as so many of you are clearly keen to do, it is going to take a global community to value them. The very people who sound upset here on this forum are the ones who need to write and pressure countries like China, Mozambique and mail-order wood sellers in Europe and the USA to end the legal and illegal trade in tropical hardwoods. Mozambique is losing thousands of trees per day.
On this expedition animals were studied, cliffs were climbed and holes were dug (and carefully filled in) in order to understand how to protect this and many other mountain repositories of diversity and climate resilience, two commodities we will need a lot of in the near future. We came to Lico to help our global community understand how forests store carbon so that nations and their people responsible for climate change can fund poorer countries to keep their forests standing - all in order to deal with the carbon pollution the first world creates every day by living beyond the planet's means. Without understanding how this carbon cycle works, and passing on funding for forest communities to preserve their precious trees, a future without rainforests is probably what awaits us all. 
There are so many important questions here on Lico to grasp but one from this forum really shouts at me: How did the fish get up the cliff? Well possibly they were marooned there so long ago that the ground was as high as the top, which is a very long time ago indeed. Only through scientific understanding can we know how to protect these places. Furthermore, every confirmed new species, like a fish or a mouse, or even a new beautiful butterfly, gives these forests a better chance of gaining some sort of critical official protection. 
They have none at all today.
Countless species are being wiped out in this region without anyone recording them. What we are losing we do not know, but because of this and other expeditions there is hope that some sort of protective status can be conferred before it is too late. 
There are many more unanswered questions about Lico which will be uncovered as more science is done. From the pots found on top, to the forest’s age, to how it might act as a baseline for other rainforest carbon traps and in-turn be valued so communities in Mozambique see these trees as something other than board-feet of timber or in the way of a new maize field. It is a race against time. The two fish in the gauze of Vanessa’s collection could save their entire species. 
It is this journalist's belief that we are not protecting forests by turning a blind eye to them and leaving them alone in these times of climate change and global environmental upheaval. Not only are people felling trees daily, but we need to study and listen to these incredibly ancient and resilient systems that have survived so much. Our own very survival may well depend on the lessons we learn from their longevity.
It’s true that this story leaves many more questions than answers, but that is usually the nature of science. As more information comes to light we will be updating you all, possibly here at the Guardian but definitely through our not-for-profit environmental and scientific reporting initiative: www.allianceearth.org. Feel free to find out more there, or just write us a very mean letter or a nice one. We like them too. 
One last thing. In the 1000 words I was granted to explain this rather immense undertaking I didn’t even get a chance to mention the rodents of unusual size. 
But thats a story for another time.

just to be recognized by their peers with some 'unique' thesis (the ultimate academic prize).We don't need this knowledge but the earth needs to retain its mysteries.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529302895000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2425070', u'id': u'117117080', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'Whats sad & absurd is that you only see the natural world in terms of value & property.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529286771000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'117110415', u'id': u'117113054', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R Anon', u'text': u'Pot kettle scenario i think.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529332828000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17206208', u'in_reply_to': u'117114333', u'id': u'117139766', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JeanEmarre', u'text': u'BQSTART

 Seriously though I can't wait to read more about their scientific discoveries.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529285928000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17776092', u'id': u'117112895', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jonationalist', u'text': u'There were pots up there', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529331890000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16208710', u'in_reply_to': u'117103910', u'id': u'117139212', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'apaulD', u'text': u'Pristine. I think my uncle is still pottering away up there somewhere, but postal services are a bit hit+miss as well.What the Portuguese did for us ... f.all boet.(We) Uncle + I were last up that way in,...? an open-tourer Landy+caravan combo [late 1960s] from (then) Salisbury Rhodesia,now Harare Zimbabwe. No lack of helpers at a good rate in them days - food and daily stipend paid cash (daily).Maputo's gone [to the dogs] completely- uncle had a Night Club - La Boom-Boom, wonder if Max Fox + his bevy of lovelies still around? Doubtful, he'd be in his 90's now . Nowadays, (if you eventually mange a tourist visa) when visiting Mocambique in re-invented, Darkest Africa, you take your own minder, or three, let local police know your whereabouts daily, and a lorra-lorra water purifying tabs, if you can find any clean (ish) water.Lovely country. Tourism would help it back on its feet and give locals some chance of a life after all the wars they've lived through over the last 250+ years of colonial rape and pillage.Nice article, but lacks a bit of human insights and depth, Prof. 1/10 (F-)Nice Butterfly but.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529301596000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11012332', u'id': u'117116584', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RobertAussie', u'text': u'People who are prepared to do difficult things at great personal cost and labour for very small economic reward are actually in very short supply.

People who do easy things for large economic reward (for instance, buy property, wait for the market to rise, then sell it) are in oversupply.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529284758000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11730493', u'in_reply_to': u'117110375', u'id': u'117112640', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'juniornaturel', u'text': u'and Moose', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529328814000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100492197', u'in_reply_to': u'117137168', u'id': u'117137208', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LastDuckinOz', u'text': u'There's probably a ladder round the back the locals use to get a break from all the scientists studying them.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529301405000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18146197', u'in_reply_to': u'117107663', u'id': u'117116515', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Leadguitar', u'text': u'What a stupid comment..!!', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529284247000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17456691', u'in_reply_to': u'117110375', u'id': u'117112496', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'juniornaturel', u'text': u'we seek Mouse & Squirrel', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529328769000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100492197', u'id': u'117137168', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'astasolillja', u'text': u'Undisturbed Forest: A forest ecosystem with the principal characteristics and key elements of native ecosystems such as complexity, structure, and diversity and an abundance of mature trees, relatively undisturbed by human activity. Human impacts in such forest areas have normally been limited to low levels of hunting, fishing and harvesting of forest products. Such ecosystems are also referred to as "mature," "old-growth," or "virgin" forests.
It doesn't become undisturbed just because some humans walked through it and touched some animals.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529300322000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'just some humans walked through it and touched some animals', u'effect': u"it does n't become undisturbed"}], u'author_id': u'3119151', u'in_reply_to': u'117103910', u'id': u'117116140', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ticktockbibimbap', u'text': u'Did they not teach you not to assume? 'leave it alone''Already killing the animals''Not untouched by humans now is it?'
But, who is to say that it's natural state is to be free of human intrigue? We are of this world, we are a perfectly natural component within it. Our behaviour is not dictated by a malicious outside source. Our brains evolved rapidly and naturally in this sphere, this 'natural realm'. It is our manifest destiny, how can it not be...we are the only species with the guile and ingenuity to manifest.
So, all that we do, as humans, both creative and destructive, is framed by our evolution on this planet, by the forces at work on this planet, we are not above nor below the natural flow of things. Neither evil nor good, because nature is above and beyond the adolescent binary of good/evil. Thus by association, human beings are also above that petty binary.
We got clever quick, the world exists for us to find it; exactly the same principles will be applied to space exploration. What is the alternative - to remain in shivering terror up a tree, baffled by everything, horrified by the night? We dance within the theatre of nature, thus everything we do or seek to do...is perfectly natural.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529326205000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'nature is above and beyond the adolescent binary of good evil', u'effect': u'neither evil nor good'}], u'author_id': u'18347049', u'id': u'117135257', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dudley Lucas', u'text': u'The planet was not created for us, we evolved here. Apply that to the Cosmos, dearie me...endless fascination and surprises.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529325690000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18347049', u'id': u'117134863', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Paul Jordan', u'text': u'It is hardly "useless research" to explore an isolated environment where new species are likely to be found. Was it "useless research" for Darwin to visit the Galapagos Islands?', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529297127000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11442955', u'in_reply_to': u'117114996', u'id': u'117115224', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Filipio', u'text': u'Point being? The article stated the original team (which does't include either anthropologists or archaeologists) was going to approach the former for dating info about the pots. 
Archaeology is the disciple that does this kind of research, not anthropologists. And a range of dating methods are potentially useful, not just those handled by technicians in a lab. When it comes to pots specifically, for example, comparative analysis of pottery form & appearance with known artefacts from elsewhere is a longstanding method for relative dating - particularly as procedures for absolute dating -- and luminescence tends to be used for pottery -- can be expensive. An archaeologist can advise on whether comparable artefacts from assemblages elsewhere are (sufficiently) relevant.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529282148000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12225275', u'in_reply_to': u'117093183', u'id': u'117111948', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ounceoflogic', u'text': u'fantastic pictures. er... not.and we still wonder: “What would a forest like that look like?”', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529324630000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3523211', u'id': u'117134034', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jfw321', u'text': u'Can’t say it’s untouched by humans now.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1529297066000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17631050', u'id': u'117115201', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: A ‘dream team’ of scientists scaled Mount Lico and found a wealth of new species
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: A ‘dream team’ of scientists scaled Mount Lico and found a wealth of new species
og_fields.og:title: Mozambique: the secret rainforest at the heart of an African volcano
text:
Standing in a pit in the red soil of a mountaintop forest in northern Mozambique, Dr Simon Willcock was dirty but very excited. “Undisturbed forest is incredibly rare,” he said. “That is why we scaled a 125-metre-tall cliff with a pickaxe.” Willcock, from Bangor University in Wales, knew of no other rainforest in Africa that scientists can confidently say has not been disturbed by humans. “It’s a unique site in Africa,” he said, plunging the axe down into the chest-deep hole with a whump.
Like a villain’s fortress in an old James Bond movie, Mount Lico rises vertically from the land around it, the ancient centre of a volcano with the forest nestled in its crater. It was discovered by Dr Julian Bayliss, who examined satellite imagery looking for an undisturbed tropical rainforest. When he spotted Lico on Google Earth, he said, the forest on top “was isolated and appeared totally undisturbed”. With a smile, he added: “That makes it very exciting.”
Bayliss, from Oxford Brookes University, had form:  he is known for having found Mount Mabu, the largest rainforest in southern Africa, as well as a number of new species of butterflies and other creatures in the area since then.
Rainforests are the oldest living biomes on Earth and contain roughly half the known species of life. They also store more carbon for longer than any other living system. Some tropical rainforests date back to the dinosaur age, but virtually all show signs of past human activity. Bayliss wondered if there were mountaintop forests that might be untouched. He remembers thinking: “What would a forest like that look like?”
The answer was Lico. But the mountain’s formidable geography – its circling rock wall rises 700 metres above the plain – raised a whole new series of questions in terms of accessibility. Bayliss decided to focus on a “shorter” cliff of about 125 metres on one side, and to put together an expedition that would place scientists on the top of Lico via that vertical rock. But how would they be able to get up there?
It took two years to assemble the 28-person dream team of biologists, logistical crew, plant experts, and researchers for the first expedition that took place last month, led by Bayliss. Funded in part by Ranulph Fiennes’s Transglobe Expedition Trust, UK-based Biocensus, as well as the African Butterfly Research Institute, the project was an academic partnership between 13 universities, museums and research institutions on three continents.
From his home office in a converted chapel in the Welsh mountains, Bayliss contacted Jules Lines and Mike Robertson, professional climbers widely regarded as two of the best in the UK. Robertson famously ascended the Eiffel tower solo in protest against French oil company Total (and was subsequently arrested by the French police). Lines is known in climbing circles as The Dark Horse for his solo climbing without a rope.
The climbers scaled the rock face above the scientists’ basecamp and secured two ropes from the top all the way down to the bottom. Patiently they taught the scientists how to get up and down safely. “Learning to ascend a 125-metre cliff in the jungle is a lot to ask of people,” said Robertson, with a certain understatement, holding the safety line for 29-year-old Ana Gledis da Conceição Miranda, a Mozambican biologist working at the Pringle and EO Wilson laboratory.
Like most of the researchers, she struggled with the rope ascenders but didn’t give up. “These scientists are bloody gritty and determined; it’s impressive,” Roberston said.
Ferrying gear and supplies, the two climbers went up the ropes more than 40 times. Despite a medical emergency as a result of an extreme infection, everyone was able to get up and down the ropes safely. But the risk remained. “There is no rescue here,” said Lines, taking a break at the top. “We are it.”
Bayliss believes Lico could be one of the most pristine forests on Earth. Willcock and his colleague, Dr Phil Platts from the University of York, dug for two days to get to the forest bedrock to read the soil layers like a history book of Lico’s past. Every fire that ever burned here, many of the plants that grew, even millions of caterpillar droppings are all recorded in the soil. (Caterpillars are everywhere on Lico, so numerous in the trees above that their droppings fall like a dry, soft rain.)
“This forest provides a unique insight into the effects of climate change on forests over time,” said Platts, shovelling from the pit.
After 10 days of discovery, the team was back at base camp in Lico’s shadow. The hole in the forest had been refilled, the topsoil replaced, and Colin Congdon, a veteran lepidopterist, was comparing finds with Bayliss. Among their small translucent papers was Lico’s first confirmed new species: a butterfly. The scientists expect it will be far from the only one. There is a line-up of potential new species to be confirmed in the months to come, from snakes to frogs, toads, a snake-like amphibian called a caecilian, a shrew, a snub-nosed rodent, more butterflies, crabs and even a flowering plant. Cataloguing potential new fish species, Vanessa Muranga, a 27-year-old marine biologist from Mozambique’s Natural History Museum, had two wrapped in gauze in front of her. “It’s so exciting when you find something that might be new,” she said.
Lico contains other mysteries, too, including partly buried ancient pots that the team discovered near the source of the main stream. According to the local community, no one in memory or legend has ever been on top of the mountain. How did the pot-makers get up the sheer cliff? Was the land around Lico higher then? Could the soil analysis help date them? Anthropologists from Mozambique’s Natural History Museum are investigating.
From a South African herpetologist to a Brazilian biogeographer, a botanist with the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, to a mammal expert from Swaziland, the expedition to Lico represented a successful collaboration between local and international research institutions. This, according to Hermenegildo Matimele, curator of the National Herbarium of Mozambique in Maputo and Bayliss’s Mozambican counterpart on the expedition, was the greatest thing about it.
On the last night of the expedition, the scientists gathered around the base camp’s fire to share a celebratory drink. Perched on a packing crate with a big smile, Bayliss expressed satisfaction that everyone had made it off the mountain with their precious samples. And, he added with characteristic understatement, “it’s great, too, that nobody died”.
 The expedition was funded by the TransGlobe Expedition Trust, Biocensus, The African Butterfly Research Institute, DMM Climbing, and Marmot tents. 
The photojournalist’s travel was paid for by Alliance Earth. 
… in the fight to protect the environment. By keeping the Guardian’s environmental coverage open and accessible, we can report on the changes needed to avoid climate and natural catastrophe. The choices made by individuals are important, but we need to work together for the systemic transformation that will make a real difference. As well as reporting the facts about what is happening now, we investigate the causes and talk to the people trying to make the future better. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. description: Inquiry will explore the carbon impact, resource use and water footprint of growing throwaway ‘fast fashion’ sector
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Inquiry will explore the carbon impact, resource use and water footprint of growing throwaway ‘fast fashion’ sector
og_fields.og:title: MPs to examine environmental footprint of UK fashion industry
text:
MPs are to investigate the environmental impact of throwaway “fast fashion” in the UK amid growing concerns that the multi-billion pound industry is wasting valuable resources and contributing to climate change. 
The inquiry, launched on Friday by the House of Commons environmental audit committee, will explore the carbon impact, resource use and water footprint of clothing throughout its lifecycle and supply chain. 
Inviting evidence on how the influential sector should remodel itself to be both “thriving and sustainable”, it will look at how improved recycling rates of clothing could slash waste and pollution. 
“Fashion shouldn’t cost the Earth” said Mary Creagh MP, chair of the committee. “But the way we design, make and discard clothes has a huge environmental impact. Producing clothes requires climate-changing emissions. Every time we put on a wash, thousands of plastic fibres wash down the drain into the oceans. We don’t know where or how to recycle end-of-life clothing.” 
Despite recent troubles on the UK high street, the fashion sector has continued to grow. According to the British Fashion Council, the UK fashion industry contributed £28.1bn to national GDP in 2015, up from £21bn in 2009. But the globalised market for fashion manufacturing has facilitated a “fast fashion” phenomenon; a proliferation of cheap and cheerful clothing, with quick turnover that encourages consumers to keep buying, the committee warns. 
The raw materials used to manufacture clothes require land and water, or extraction of fossil fuels, while carbon dioxide is emitted throughout the clothing supply chain and some chemical dyes, finishes and coatings may be toxic. Research has found that plastic microfibres in clothing are released when they are washed, and enter rivers, the ocean and even the food chain.
Last year the fashion designer Stella McCartney condemned her own industry as “incredibly wasteful and harmful to the environment.”
A report from the Ellen MacArthur Foundation put the annual cost to the UK economy of landfilling clothing and household textiles at about £82m. It warned that if the global fashion industry continues on its current growth path, it could use more than a quarter of the world’s annual carbon budget by 2050.
Key to the inquiry is how consumers could be encouraged to buy fewer clothes, reuse clothes and think about how best to dispose of clothes when they are no longer wanted. An estimated 300,000 tonnes of fashion waste goes straight into landfill each year, despite growing efforts to encourage consumers to recycle their worn and unwanted clothing.

description: Annual carbon emissions, excluding unreliable data, higher than ever, report says
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Annual carbon emissions, excluding unreliable data, higher than ever, report says
og_fields.og:title: Record emissions keep Australia on path to missing Paris target
text:
Australia’s emissions over the past year were again the highest on record when unreliable data from land use and forestry sectors are excluded, according to new data from NDEVR Environmental.
If the country’s greenhouse gas emissions continue on their current trajectory, Australia will miss its Paris target by a billion tonnes of CO2, which is equal to about two years of Australia’s entire national emissions.
NDEVR replicates the federal government’s National Greenhouse Gas Inventory (NGGI) quarterly reports, but releases them months ahead of the official data. Previous NDEVR reports’ figures have been within 1% of the official figures when they are eventually released.
The latest figures include the first three months of 2018 and show Australia’s national emissions up to March were the highest since records began in 2002.
It projects that emissions for the year to March, excluding land use emissions, will be 556.9 m tonnes.
Even with land-use data included, it projects emissions would continue their upward trend, taking Australia further away from its Paris commitment of a 26% to 28% reduction in emissions on 2005 levels by 2030. 
Although emissions from the electricity sector had fallen in the previous three quarters, the report identifies a slight increase of 1.7 m tonnes of CO2 in the most recent quarter, due to an increase in fossil-fuel based electricity generation throughout the national electricity market states.
The report also finds that fugitive emissions due to increased gas production and exports are at their highest levels ever.
As debate over the government’s proposed national energy guarantee continues, NDEVR projects that the Australian electricity sector would meet the proposed Neg target of a 26% cut on 2005 levels by 2030, five years ahead of schedule, simply if business as usual continues.
The reason for this is the ongoing investment in renewable energy developments as well as the impending decommissioning of large coal plants.
“Our indicative analysis shows that electricity emissions in a business as usual sense are decreasing faster than what the Neg projects anyway,” the NDEVR environmental managing director, Matt Drum, said.
Drum said while the government’s focus was on the electricity sector, emissions were rising across other areas of the economy in the absence of a working climate policy.
“The numbers speak for themselves. They’re heading in the wrong direction,” he said.
“It’s one thing to focus on the electricity sector – it’s 36% of our emissions. But that leaves 64% of the economy that is essentially untouched by policy or mitigation.”

article_tags: [Climate change, Climate change, Science, Florida, Environment, US news, Books]
description: In an extract from her new book Rising, Elizabeth Rush explains the threat from sea-level rise, which, for millions of Americans, is about to get very real, very quickly
og_fields.og:description: In an extract from her new book Rising, Elizabeth Rush explains the threat from sea-level rise, which, for millions of Americans, is about to get very real, very quickly
og_fields.og:title: Rising seas: 'Florida is about to be wiped off the map'
text:
In 1890, just over six thousand people lived in the damp lowlands of south Florida. Since then the wetlands that covered half the state have been largely drained, strip malls have replaced Seminole camps, and the population has increased a thousandfold. Over roughly the same amount of time the number of black college degree holders in the United States also increased a thousandfold, as did the speed at which we fly, the combined carbon emissions of the Middle East, and the entire population of Thailand.
About 60 of the region’s more than 6 million residents have gathered in the Cox Science Building at the University of Miami on a sunny Saturday morning in 2016 to hear Harold Wanless, or Hal, chair of the geology department, speak about sea level rise. “Only 7% of the heat being trapped by greenhouse gases is stored in the atmosphere,” Hal begins. “Do you know where the other 93% lives?”
This is a modal window.
A teenager, wrists lined in aquamarine beaded bracelets, rubs sleep from her eyes. Returns her head to its resting position in her palm. The man seated behind me roots around in his briefcase for a breakfast bar. No one raises a hand.
“In the ocean,” Hal continues. “That heat is expanding the ocean, which is contributing to sea level rise, and it is also, more importantly, creating the setting for something we really don’t want to have happen: rapid melt of ice.”
A woman wearing a sequined teal top opens her Five Star notebook and starts writing things down. The guy behind her shovels spoonfuls of passionfruit–flavored Chobani yogurt into his tiny mouth. Hal’s three sons are perched in the next row back. One has a ponytail, one is in a suit, and the third crosses and uncrosses his gray street sneakers. The one with the ponytail brought a water bottle; the other two sip Starbucks. And behind the rows and rows of sparsely occupied seats, at the very back of the amphitheater, an older woman with a gold brocade bear on her top paces back and forth.
A real estate developer interrupts Hal to ask: “Is someone recording this?”
“Yes.” The cameraman coughs. “Besides,” Hal adds, “I say the same damn thing at least five times a week.” Hal, who is in his early seventies and has been studying sea level rise for over 40 years, pulls at his Burt Reynolds moustache, readjusts his taupe corduroy suit, and continues. On the screen above his head clips from a documentary on climate change show glacial tongues of ice the size of Manhattan tumbling into the sea. “The big story in Greenland and Antarctica is that the warming ocean is working its way in, deep under the ice sheets, causing the ice to collapse faster than anyone predicted, which in turn will cause sea levels to rise faster than anyone predicted.”
According to Marco Rubio, the junior senator from Florida, rising sea levels are uncertain, their connection to human activity tenuous. And yet the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change expects roughly two feet of rise by century’s end. The United Nations predicts three feet. And the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates an upper limit of six and a half feet.
Take the 6 million people who live in south Florida today and divide them into two groups: those who live less than six and a half feet above the current high tide line, and everybody else. The numbers slice nearly evenly. Heads or tails: call it in the air. If you live here, all you can do is hope that when you put down roots your choice was somehow prophetic.
But Hal says it doesn’t matter whether you live six feet above sea level or sixty-five, because he, like James Hansen, believes that all of these predictions are, to put it mildly, very, very low. “The rate of sea level rise is currently doubling every seven years, and if it were to continue in this manner, Ponzi scheme style, we would have 205 feet of sea level rise by 2095,” he says. “And while I don’t think we are going to get that much water by the end of the century, I do think we have to take seriously the possibility that we could have something like 15 feet by then.”
It’s a little after nine o’clock. Hal’s sons stop sipping their lattes and the oceanographic scientist behind me puts down his handful of M&M’s. If Hal Wanless is right, every single object I have seen over the past 72 hours – the periodic table of elements hanging above his left shoulder, the buffet currently loaded with refreshments, the smoothie stand at my seaside hotel, the beach umbrellas and oxygen bars, the Johnny Rockets and seashell shop, the lecture hall with its hundreds of mostly empty teal swivel chairs – will all be underwater in the not-so-distant future.
**** 
One of the few stories I remember from the Bible vividly depicts the natural and social world in crisis. It is the apocalyptic narrative par excellence – Noah’s flood. When I look it up again, however, I am surprised to find that it does not start with a rainstorm or an ark, but earlier, with unprecedented population growth and God’s scorn. It begins: “When human beings began to increase in number on the earth.” I read this line and think about the 6,000 inhabitants of south Florida turning into 6 million in 120 short years. “The LORD saw how great the wickedness of the human race had become.” I think about the exponential increase in M&M’s, Chobani yogurt cups and grande lattes consumed over that same span of time. The dizzying supply chains, cheap labor and indestructible plastic. “So God said to Noah, ‘I am going to put an end to all people, for the earth is filled with violence because of them.’” And then the rain began.
I do not believe in a vengeful God – if God exists at all – so I do not think of the flood as punishment for human sin. What interests me most is what happens to the story when I remove it from its religious framework: Noah’s flood is one of the most fully developed accounts of environmental change in ancient history. It tries to make sense of a cataclysmic earthbound event that happened long ago, before written language, before the domestication of horses, before the first Egyptian mummies and the rise of civilization in Crete. An event for which the teller clearly held humans responsible.
****
Dig into geologic history and you discover this: when sea levels have risen in the past, they have usually not done so gradually, but rather in rapid surges, jumping as much as 50 feet over a short three centuries. Scientists call these events “meltwater pulses” because the near-biblical rise in the height of the ocean is directly correlated to the melting of ice and the process of deglaciation, the very events featured in the documentary footage Hal has got running on a screen above his head.
He shows us a clip of the largest glacial calving event ever recorded. It starts with a chunk of ice the size of Miami’s tallest building tumbling, head over tail, off the tip of the Greenland Ice Sheet. Then the Southeast Financial Center goes, displaying its cool blue underbelly. It is a coltish thing, smooth and oddly muscular. The ground between the two turns to arctic ice dust and the ocean roils up. Next, chunks of ice the size of the Marquis Residences crash away; then the Wells Fargo Center falls, and with it goes 900 Biscayne Bay. Suddenly everything between the Brickell neighborhood and Park West is gone.
The clip begins again and I watch in awe as a section of the Jakobshavn Glacier half the size of all Miami falls into the sea.
“Greenland is currently calving chunks of ice so massive they produce earthquakes up to six and seven on the Richter scale,” Hal says as the city of ice breaks apart. “There was not much noticeable ice melt before the nineties. But now it accelerates every year, exceeding all predictions. It will likely cause a pulse of meltwater into the oceans.”
In medicine, a pulse is something regular – a predictable throb of blood through veins, produced by a beating heart. It is so reliable, so steady, so definite that lack of a pulse is sometimes considered synonymous with death. A healthy adult will have a resting heart rate of 60 to 100 beats per minute, every day, until they don’t. But a meltwater pulse is the opposite. It is an anomaly. The exception to the 15,000-year rule.
From 1900 to 2000 the glacier on the screen retreated inward eight miles. From 2001 to 2010 it pulled back nine more; over a single decade the Jakobshavn glacier lost more ice than it had during the previous century. And then there is this film clip, recorded over 70 minutes, in which the glacier retreats a full mile across a calving face three miles wide. “This is why I believe we are witnessing the beginning of the largest meltwater pulse in modern human history,” Hal says.
As the ice sheets above Hal’s head fall away and the snacks on the buffet disappear, topography is transformed from a backwater physical science into the single most important factor determining the longevity of the Sunshine State. The man seated next to me leans over. “If what he says is even half true,” he whispers, “Florida is about to be wiped off the map.”
… we can’t turn away from climate change. The Guardian’s environmental coverage reports the scientific facts, social consequences and political choices that are shaping the fate of our planet. As the world's leaders turn their backs on the environment, we are at a crisis point. Individual consumer choices are important, but we need collective action to achieve the systemic change that will really make a difference. Our pioneering and our fearless reporting on the environment can play a vital role in that. But we need our readers’ support.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. A big, big error of judgement for a professional media man, attempting to influence public opinion on climate change, to instance the tragicomic energy trajectory of Germany. 
And such a comment on the day that the singular, one-and-only technology that can 'save' humanity from the worst of climate change is given a long overdue boost. If you want REAL, skilled, well paid, secure jobs, Owen, look to the 100 GW of new nuclear we'll be getting to decarbonise our electricity generation/heating, industrial process heat and transport fuel sectors: https://www.gov.uk/government/news/new-deal-with-industry-to-secure-uk-civil-nuclear-future-and-drive-down-cost-of-energy-for-customers
Yes indeed, abundant electricity and process heat from nuclear power plants can deliver carbon-neutral, liquid fuels for all our transport needs, including aviation and shipping.
We're 8 years away from the game-changer: the breakers being thrown on the first NuScale 720 MW nuclear power plant, comprising of 12 x 60 MW Small Modular Reactors. The contracts are signed, the customer is in place - it will happen and in 8 years, all this 'green-crap' will start to wither on the vine.
It takes 22,116 MW of the very latest 9.5 MW offshore wind turbines, at a capital cost of £41.9 billion, to deliver the same amount of intermittent electricity as the 24/7 electricity the 3,200 MW Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant will deliver at a [contracted] capital cost of £18 billion.
But 3,200 MW of NuScale SMRs will only cost £10.2 billion, so - why pay over 4X more for technologies that deliver a truly pathetic, grid-degrading, intermittent product that will forever require fossil-fuelled back up?

Our present life style, worldwide, is unsustainable. The planet owes us nothing. We have no entitlements. Today's children face a bleak future. CO2 and methane will see to that.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530195746000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16045352', u'id': u'117568627', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AndyPandy1968', u'text': u'First of all, the Heathrow expansion is zero to do with brexit. The 3rd runway has been planned for over 30 years, and 99% of all the work was done before the word brexit was invented. 
Secondly, most those objecting to the Heathrow expansion come from places nowhere near the place, with an overnight interest in environmental concerns, with arguments developed by preconceptions boosted by reading an article over breakfast in this mornings paper.
If anyone is going to argue with any credibility about pollution, they better include in the conversation closing down our car plants, our steelworks, and all other industrial activity. 
To pick on one thing, which for most arguing against it is probably 200 miles away, is parochial. Despite our decline, we still have loads of polluting factories and polluting commercial activity, where concrete was poured over green fields over 100 years ago. 
Heathrow is a huge employer in the South East. The fact is, it is the 6th biggest airport hub in the whole world. It started operations over 70 years ago. This seems to be resented by others not because of the environment, but because of sour grapes?
Heathrow is a British success story , which creates 70,000 jobs directly and probably 2 or 3 times that indirectly. All this generates a tax take which is shared by all. In fact, more of it probably goes north of Watford than stays in the area.
So if you are going to have an environmental argument, get it in context of all the polluting industries we still have. Also get it in context that whatever the objection is, air traffic will increase. Where it takes off and lands is the only question, and stopping Heathrow will either push it to Gatwick or Luton or quite possibly Paris, Amsterdam or Frankfurt which are the only other European airport hubs vaguely in the same league. 
This 3rd runway has been on the table for over 30 years, and all of the homes directly affected have already received huge payouts many years ago, which were taken and banked. 
Where I sit now, 17 miles from Heathrow, within 50 meters of this laptop there are 5 people employed by the airport.
It may be an abstract conversation for 24 hours for some, but for others it means the same as the Cowley car plant, or Port Talbot, or the Nissan factory in Sunderland etc. 
My grandma used to tell me 'Where there is muck there is brass' and of course this also means employment. This maxim has not changed. 
Heathrow is a vast topic with far more to discuss than can be covered in one article. The article above is parochial, naive and trite, with gaping chasms of missing information.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530195688000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the environment', u'effect': u'to be resented by others'}, {u'cause': u'sour grapes', u'effect': u'this seems to be resented by others not because of the environment but'}], u'author_id': u'12992447', u'id': u'117568567', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'initalyperora', u'text': u'Was the double negative necessary "deduct 1".

As for battery technology, the future as reported in the Guardian is beyond Lithium, and graphene is one likely driver of a significant leap forward - again R & D is money reliant but there is no shortage of that at the moment so you should expect significant developments in the not too distant future.
Only time will tell how quickly the possibilities crystalize, but crystalize they will.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530191942000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2858673', u'in_reply_to': u'117562104', u'id': u'117565454', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'reallyyousaidwhat', u'text': u'Ermm. description: MPs showed a Trumpian disregard for the planet by voting en masse for Heathrow expansion, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
og_fields.og:description: MPs showed a Trumpian disregard for the planet by voting en masse for Heathrow expansion, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
og_fields.og:title: Brexit Britain’s dash for growth will be a disaster for the environment | Owen Jones
text:
Many of those MPs who marched through the lobbies to vote in favour of expanding Heathrow this week – Labour parliamentarians among them – will speak eloquently, if pushed, about the threat of climate change. Unfortunately their words have been rendered meaningless by their vote. You cannot truly fear the impact of climate change and then opt to raise Heathrow’s emissions by 7.3m tonnes of carbon dioxide – a figure that, as Greenpeace notes, is equivalent to the annual total output of Cyprus.
The talk of promoting jobs and economic growth that swirled around the vote is self-destructive short-termism. According to the World Wide Fund for Nature, the floods, droughts and heatwaves that climate change will bring will cost the economy tens of billions of pounds, as well as hundreds of thousands of jobs, by 2050. By focusing on high-carbon infrastructure as a means to create jobs, we distract ourselves from exploring how we can create hundreds of thousands of skilled, well-paid, secure jobs in the renewable energy sector, as Germany has done.
A disastrous vote then, but also one that offers a revealing insight into what the Tory approach to Brexit means. According to her spokesman, Theresa May believes that expanding Heathrow “sends out an important message about global Britain and making the most of the opportunities which lie ahead of us”.
The airport’s chief executive, John Holland-Kaye, echoed the government rhetoric, lauding a “real Brexit bonus”. Clearly a hard Tory Brexit – grievously damaging economic relations with our nearest trading bloc – means a Trumpian hell-for-leather dash for growth at any cost. Who benefits from that growth, or what it means for the environment, are not high-priority questions. Indeed, on the same day as the Heathrow vote, the government rejected plans for a £1.3bn tidal lagoon in Swansea Bay, another potential source of jobs and growth that would help to counter global warming.
As the Committee on Climate Change (CCC) warns today, the Tory obsession with scrapping what David Cameron infamously called “green crap” will saddle us all with higher costs in the future. As for the “green Brexit” cynically trumpeted by Tory leadership wannabe Michael Gove, that was clearly yesterday’s soundbite.
Yes, climate change can seem like an abstraction – too technical, too distant. I admit my own brain tends to fade out when I hear about it. History may judge that one of the most disastrous consequences of the financial crash was that it distracted from the imperative of dealing with climate change: here-and-now crises of falling living standards, a lack of secure jobs and public sector cuts suddenly became more pressing and urgent.
Brexit, too, sucks in all the political oxygen, starving other crises of attention and giving the Tories a pretext to bet the farm on making departure from the EU look like it can work. But our government is legally bound to cut emissions by 80% by 2050, meaning our aviation emissions must be at the levels they were in 2005 – 37.5m tonnes – by mid-century. A Department for Transport report reveals we will already have hit 43m tonnes by 2030 after Heathrow expansion. Because we are signatories to the Paris agreement, we are obliged to limit a rise in global temperatures to well below 2C. But as Lord Deben – a former Tory minister and chair of the CCC – put it to the transport secretary, Chris Grayling, regarding Heathrow expansion: “We were surprised that your statement to the House of Commons … on 5 January 2018 made no mention of either of these commitments.”
If we’re going to abide by our targets, as well as expand Heathrow, that means deeper cuts in emissions in other parts of the economy. Where? As Deben has wryly noted, the CCC “has limited confidence about the options [for achieving the compensatory cuts needed]”.
Who will benefit most from this expansion? More than half of Britons don’t fly at all in any given year. Just 15% of Britons – disproportionately the most affluent – take more than 70% of all flights. House of Commons research suggests that having a second home and a household income of more than £115,000 are the best indicators of whether or not you are a frequent flyer. And as Labour’s Clive Lewis points out, many of the beneficiaries of a bigger Heathrow will be international transfer passengers whose money will never even make it into the UK economy (except maybe by buying the odd bottle of whisky in duty free). Is bulldozing communities, increasing noise pollution and noxious fumes, and above all accelerating climate change, a price worth paying for that?
Consider the challenges we must confront. Greenpeace’s chief scientist, Doug Parr, tells me: “We’re looking at scale-ups of water shortages, heatwaves and extreme weather across the world.” The Tories might laud their approach to Brexit as paving the way for Britain’s resurrection as a global trading nation. But the damage inflicted by climate change on our trading partners means we will suffer too. The impacts in Britain will be felt on agriculture, road and rail, electricity, water and sewage systems – all hit by rising temperatures. Look at the fire on Saddleworth Moor: other factors are at play, such as how the land is managed. But we can be sure that climate change will increase the likelihood of such disasters.
This week, our political elite sent a message to the future that will not be forgotten. They could have championed an ambitious route: one that invests in skilled green jobs as part of a new just and sustainable order. Instead a decision was taken to play Russian roulette with our planet for short-term, limited gain. In two generations’ time, what will those yet to be born make of a reckless decision taken when there was still time to act in the face of coming catastrophe? The Heathrow vote was a wanton act of vandalism and we will all suffer from this particular “Brexit dividend”.
• Owen Jones is a Guardian columnist
… we can’t turn away from climate change. For The Guardian, reporting on the environment is a  priority.  We give climate, nature and pollution stories the prominence they deserve, stories which often go unreported by others in the mainstream media. At this critical time for our species and our planet, we are determined to inform readers about threats, consequences and solutions based on scientific facts, not political prejudice or business interests. But we need your support to grow our coverage, to travel to the remote frontlines of change and to cover vital conferences that affect us all.
More people are reading and supporting our independent, investigative reporting than ever before. And unlike many news organisations, we have chosen an approach that allows us to keep our journalism accessible to all, regardless of where they live or what they can afford.
The Guardian is editorially independent, meaning we set our own agenda. Our journalism is free from commercial bias and not influenced by billionaire owners, politicians or shareholders. No one edits our editor. No one steers our opinion. This is important as it enables us to give a voice to those less heard, challenge the powerful and hold them to account. It’s what makes us different to so many others in the media, at a time when factual, honest reporting is critical.
Every contribution we receive from readers like you, big or small, goes directly into funding our journalism. This support enables us to keep working as we do – but we must maintain and build on it for every year to come. Support The Guardian from as little as €1 – and it only takes a minute. Thank you.

article_tags: [Conservation, Environment, Climate change, Biodiversity, Animals, Wildlife, World news, United Nations, Paris climate agreement]
comments:
[{u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'There's some interesting questions in there - a huge number of factors determine biodiversity and the number of species including evolution, time, isolation, climatic stability, time from a mass extinction event, geology, habitat diversity and temperature. 
If we destroyed two thirds of what we have now then eventually (as in literally tens of millions of years) you would probably see diversity restored to the sort of level we have now (dependent on other factors). It isn't really about managing with a third because a) ecosystems and species have value independent of their value to humanity in the view of many of us, b) ecosystems can collapse if species are removed (a good example is what would eventually happen to the Mauritian rainforest if the flying fox is driven to extinction - the rainforest would eventually shrink/ or collapse)
You have no way of knowing what species are 'important' - that isn't how ecology works, you might think that the Mauritian flying fox is unimportant but it turns out (As an example) that it is needed to spread seeds of forest plants (say a particular fruit tree) - so which is important - the tree or the bat or both. But then the bat is dependent on other plants and also on it's predators (as these prevent over dominance of certain species). And those species are dependent on others who are, in turn dependent on others and so on. And it's basically impossible to fully understand the dynamics of these ecosystems - you don't know what puling out each individual brick will do to the wall
Again you can't just simply discount things because you don't know what work they do - are rainforest species useful - they do a large percentage of the oxygen production of the world, cause rainfall patterns, soak up carbon - so which of them count as useful?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1531215504000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a ecosystems have value independent of their value to humanity in the view of many of us', u'effect': u"it is n't really about managing with a third b ecosystems collapse"}, {u'cause': u"you do n't know what work they do", u'effect': u"again you ca n't just simply discount things are"}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'rainfall patterns'}], u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'117904804', u'id': u'118064559', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Vlamingo', u'text': u'BQSTART

Literature analyses (e.g. Cook et al., 2013; Oreskes et al., 2004) generally find a stronger consensus than opinion surveys such as ours. This is related to the stronger consensus among highly published – and arguably the most expert – climate scientists...

No matter how you slice it, scientists overwhelmingly agree that recent global warming is to a great extent human caused

Or the fewer species that do all the work, including monodominant vegetation (Mangroves, redwoods, beech woodland, giant kelp, marram grass, turtle grass, Mora forests and all the rest that do most of the work). They ridiculous Cook study doesn't say 97% of climatologists agree Man is mainly responsible for warming
BQEND
Once again: if you'd prefer to say that 3% of peer-reviewed climate change papers dispute that humans are the main cause of warming, that's fine with me. We can both agree that Cook et al showed that.
BQSTART
And as I have linked to previously, an actual survey from the Netherlands revealed 65% of climatologists believe people are mostly (greater than 51%) responsible for the Earth's recent warming
BQEND
This is how the lead author of your linked study puts it:
BQSTART
The answers to the survey showed a wide variety of opinions, but it was clear that a large majority of climate scientists agree that anthropogenic greenhouse gases are the dominant cause of global warming. Consistent with other research, we found that the consensus is strongest for scientists with more relevant expertise and for scientists with more peer-reviewed publications. 90% of respondents with more than 10 climate-related peer-reviewed publications (about half of all respondents), agreed that anthropogenic greenhouse gases (GHG) are the dominant driver of recent global warming... 
Literature analyses (e.g. Cook et al., 2013; Oreskes et al., 2004) generally find a stronger consensus than opinion surveys such as ours. This is related to the stronger consensus among highly published – and arguably the most expert – climate scientists...
Furthermore, contrarian viewpoints were likely overrepresented in our study compared with others. 
No matter how you slice it, scientists overwhelmingly agree that recent global warming is to a great extent human caused. 
BQEND

The Earth has been warming intermittently since the Little Ice Age
BQEND
Recently the Earth has been warming rapidly. Global temperatures have risen 0.85 to 0.9C in just 50 years. That is major warming in anyone's book.
BQSTART
And the IPCC certainly seemed "surprised" about the pause in their 5th Assessment
BQEND
Why would they be surprised about a slowdown when - as you are now aware - they told us nearly 30 years ago that there would be temporary speed ups and slowdowns? 
BQSTART
the climate models didn't predict the pause as climate is, of course, unpredictable
BQEND
No, the reason they didn't predict the slowdown is because they are not designed to predict short term deviations caused by temporary factors (which, remember, occur in both directions).
Similarly, they didn't predict the subsequent speed up, which all but cancelled out the slowdown. Your response to that, learnt from conspiracy blogs, is just pathetic.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530775715000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'117820893', u'id': u'117826840', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Lawrie Griffith', u'text': u'There have only ever been three responses to tyranny and oligarchy throughout history.Acceptance.Democracy through representation and limits on the power of rogue individuals and power cliques.Revolution.We are moving into an age of tyranny by power cliques at the same time as we are running into the limits of the planet.If we don't get number two going, I suggest number three is inevitable.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530850918000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13793892', u'in_reply_to': u'117850558', u'id': u'117867718', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'BQSTART

If you're argument is based on that then you are arguing against yourself.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530774026000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the atmospheric heat has been absorbed into the oceans', u'effect': u'that this is'}], u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'117821257', u'id': u'117826171', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The photographs of streets flooding at high tide in Florida reminds me of streets I'd drive down when working on mosquitoes in Pinkenba that would flood on spring tides. John's from the same party as Campbell, but he would have been mad to have done otherwise.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530770123000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'117797263', u'id': u'117824770', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The carbon dividends proposal for the US economy reminds me of the Australian carbon price means tested refund which Tony Abbott at the Palmer United Party's insistence kept in place until the next election after he's abolished the price on carbon.
Tony's rationale was that by winning government by a considerable number of seats he had a mandate. While not being overtly in denial of the reality of climate change in the lead up to that election, Tony blamed the network cost propelled large increases in electricity costs to consumers on the carbon price which he called a tax and the Tapis crude oil market price generated large increase in price at the pump of petrol also on the carbon price. 
After the price on carbon was removed retail electricity electricity prices dropped 8% then soon rose by 40% due to more network costs but a a reduction in the price of Tapis crude out of Singapore saw petrol prices fall. Now six years later due to problems with supply from Venezuala world crude prices are up and petrol prices are back to what they were when we had a price on carbon.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530767708000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'more network costs but a a reduction in the price of tapis crude out of singapore', u'effect': u'then soon rose by 40 %'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'117797263', u'id': u'117824110', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Vlamingo', u'text': u'As for the rest of your linked Forbes article, it's full of bunk.
1) By claiming (in 2015) that warming has been "essentially nothing in the last decade and a half", Epstein digs himself into the exactly same hole I have outlined to you elsewhere. 
Three years later, the warming since 2000 is very much statistically significant and amounts to nearly 0.4C. Yet, according to Epstein, there was no warming for 15 of those 18 years. This is nonsense arising from the misuse of statistics.
2) Epstein takes issue with the 97% consensus, citing the same arguments as you. My reply is the same: if you'd rather say that 3% of climate science literature disputes that humans are the main cause of warming, that's fine with me.
3) Citing a handful of scientists who say their papers were wrongly rated by Cook et al means very little. As Cook et al only rated the abstracts, it's inevitable that they would get some wrong. That's why they checked their work by asking the authors to rate their own papers. And the correlation between the Cook ratings and those of the authors is very good.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530767124000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15902664', u'in_reply_to': u'117811255', u'id': u'117823986', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Vlamingo', u'text': u'Thank you for finally providing a link to politicians getting the 97% statistic wrong.
When Obama said there was a 97% consensus that "climate change is real, man-made and dangerous", I agree with you that he was not strictly correct about the last bit. It is very likely to be true, but it is not what Cook and other consensus studies focused on.
John Kerry may have made a similar mistake, but the quote in your link has some missing text in the middle - we would need to see the full text to be sure.
But while we're being strictly correct, I notice that neither mentioned "disaster" as you claimed (or catastrophic, etc).', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530765749000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15902664', u'in_reply_to': u'117811255', u'id': u'117823738', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"We CANNOT predict what the Earth's temperature will be. That is statistically impossible."
Are you talking as I was about the Earth's climate temperature. Once we know what our net CO2 emissions are and will be, we can. We can control what we do. Do you have a problem controlling what you do?', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530765094000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'117820819', u'id': u'117823631', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Vlamingo', u'text': u'BQSTART
Hansen said what he said. The New York Times and Wall Street Journal both reported what he said
BQEND
You are only digging yourself deeper into a hole. Despite being shown multiple times that the reporting is wrong, you remain deep in denial.
Once again... here's Hansen's written submission to the Senate subcommittee:
BQSTART
The warming* in Scenario A at most mid-latitude Northern Hemisphere land areas such as the United States is typically 0.5 to 1.0 degree C (1-3 F degrees) for the decade 1990-2000 and 1-2 degree C (2-4 F degrees) for the decade 2010-2020
BQEND
* refers to total warming since 1958.
And here's how the NYT reported this:
BQSTART
Average global temperatures would rise by one-half a degree to one degree Fahrenheit from 1990 to 2000 if current trends are unchanged, according to Dr. Hansen's findings. Dr. Hansen said the global temperature would rise by another 2 to 4 degrees in the following decade."
BQEND
You can stick your fingers in your ears all you like, but it won't alter the fact that there are  four reporting errors in one paragraph : wrong region, wrong temperature units, wrong decade and wrong baseline year.
Your WSJ link is paywalled, but feel free to quote from it and if it's also wrong we can set the record straight.
I don't know what cause you think you're serving by posting here, but frankly I don't think you're doing it any favours.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530764986000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15902664', u'in_reply_to': u'117811255', u'id': u'117823615', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'I do like The Gap and keep myself active in the adjoining national park that our girl declared some time back. Also track down seeds of some of 3,000 plant species in the local creek catchments to grow and assist in their revegetation.
It's good to slot back into structured learning. I see far many consequences of a lack thereof in these discussion boards. 
One of our boys lives in Redlands. It's also a nice spot. I visited the fresh and saltwater wetlands there when I worked on mosquitoes. We're proud of what our girl's achieved but worry she works too hard.
Thanks for the links. I'll give them a read. Eucalyptus grandis is indeed like the towering whitewashed spandrels of a cathedral. Why they call a tree, that grows on a steeply sloping mountainside at Mount Mee, a flooded gum I don't know.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530759986000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'117797263', u'id': u'117822804', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'magaman743', u'text': u'http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2014/11/where-global-warming-s-missing-heat', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530750042000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100470058', u'in_reply_to': u'117811409', u'id': u'117821257', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'magaman743', u'text': u'https://www.nature.com/news/climate-change-the-case-of-the-missing-heat-1.14525', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530749974000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100470058', u'in_reply_to': u'117811409', u'id': u'117821238', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'magaman743', u'text': u'https://earthdata.nasa.gov/user-resources/sensing-our-planet/missing-heat', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530749888000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100470058', u'in_reply_to': u'117811409', u'id': u'117821222', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'magaman743', u'text': u'I see where the confusion is coming from. The IPCC had said there had been no statistical increase in Earth's temperature from 1998 to 2012. This caused many alarmists to throw themselves off of a high building and set themselves on fire. So NOAA came to the rescue and ADJUSTED THE TEMPERATURE DATA. Seems they had made a big mistake. I will give you one guess as to what the "new, adjusted" data showed.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530749785000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'this', u'effect': u'many alarmists to throw themselves off of a high building and set themselves on fire'}], u'author_id': u'100470058', u'in_reply_to': u'117811409', u'id': u'117821206', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'magaman743', u'text': u'The IPCC was actually criticized by some alarmists for giving too much weight to the flattening of temperatures. This is why so much effort was put into trying to explain where the "missing heat" went. But now, you alarmists claim the pause didn't happen, the IPCC never addressed the issue, there has been no effort to try to explain why the pause happened, and all of the computer models have worked perfectly well in predicting 21st century temperatures.
You folks are not just alarmists. You are revisionists.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530748424000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100470058', u'in_reply_to': u'117812619', u'id': u'117820893', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'magaman743', u'text': u'We CANNOT predict what the Earth's temperature will be. That is statistically impossible.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530748154000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100470058', u'in_reply_to': u'117777855', u'id': u'117820819', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'CATO crank on the loose.
Alexander Joseph Epstein (/ˈɛpstaɪn/; born August 1, 1980)[1] is an American author, energy theorist, and industrial policy pundit.[2] He is the founder and president of the Center for Industrial Progress, a for-profit think tank located in San Diego, California.[3][4] Epstein is also the New York Times bestselling author[5] of The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels (2014), in which he advocates the use of fossil fuels like coal, oil and natural gas, for which he has been criticized.[6] Epstein is an adjunct scholar at the Cato Institute and a former fellow at the Ayn Rand Institute.[7][8]', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530733979000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'117811255', u'id': u'117815277', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Forbes? BQSTART

BQEND
Just another lie.

Do you speak Russian?', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530733815000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'117811255', u'id': u'117815200', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'Cayman Islands? Is that where Trump puts it?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530733661000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'117811446', u'id': u'117815122', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'imipak', u'text': u'If you're talking probabilities, you don't. No, you do not understand the butterfly effect because you are talking magnitudes. When things are sensitive to initial conditions, you cannot ascribe a probability to a magnitude of change.
Take any point on the Mandelbrot set in which the sequence is locked into a cycle. Do you know, ahead of time, if some second point that is close to the boundary is going to escape to infinity or be locked into another cycle? Or do you have to do the calculation to find out?
You say there's a probability. I say that by being close to the boundary, you are by definition in a pseudo-random zone and that it makes bugger all difference.
If you can't predict the path of the ball on a snooker table, after sufficient deflections, without knowing the precise position of every atom around Alpha Centauri, then by definition the change in position of one atom over four light-years away is very significant indeed.
The weather is a multi-trillion variable chaotic system. And you have this magic power to figure out what fluctuations matter? When you can't even manage a snooker ball?
Sorry, leave maths to us mathematicians. Go back to xfractint. What, you've not been at this that long? Incredible.
Now get off my lawn.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530731539000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'you are talking magnitudes', u'effect': u'no you do not understand the butterfly effect'}], u'author_id': u'2479766', u'in_reply_to': u'117763721', u'id': u'117814060', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'BQSTART
. And the IPCC certainly seemed "surprised" about the pause in their 5th Assessment... They got those 15 years wrong. Will the next 15 years be more or less predictable?
BQEND
As Vlamingo quoted directly from the first report...

BQSTART
As a result of the combined effects of forced and unforced effects on climate, a range of unpredictable variations of either sign will be superimposed on a trend of rising temperature".
BQEND... then that looks like another mistruth.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530728920000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2515806', u'in_reply_to': u'117810744', u'id': u'117812619', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'Who is suggesting we just hand the money to save land to the UN though? International treaties under UN purview is not giving money to the UN - any proposal to put land aside would be done on a national level - basically, as an example, EO Wilson was suggesting that land is bought up and put aside (primarily by national governemnts)', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1530728860000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'117811446', u'id': u'117812574', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID2310987', u'text': u'BQSTART
